questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents to OPD with an inability to focus on close objects over the previous few hours. However, she reports that she can see distant objects. On examination, she can move her eyes normally. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged in such a condition?

choices.text: Oculomotor nerve and long ciliary nerve
Short ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

questions.solution:
Option C: Short ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

  • Damage to parasympathetic ciliary ganglion and parasympathetic fibers in the short ciliary nerve impairs the ability to focus on close objects (accommodation). The short ciliary nerves innervate the orbit around the eye and are branches of the ciliary ganglion. Parasympathetic and sympathetic nerve fibers supply the ciliary muscle, iris, and cornea. Any damage to the short ciliary nerve can lead to loss of the pupillary light reflex or mydriasis.
  • The short ciliary nerves branch from the nasociliary nerve in the intraoral space through the ciliary ganglion. Together with long ciliary nerves, they innervate the entire globe, excluding the conjunctiva.

 

Option A: Ciliary ganglion and oculomotor nerve

  • These functions’ inability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. Because the patient can move her eyeballs normally, the oculomotor nerve is not damaged even if this nerve contains preganglionic parasympathetic fibers.
  • The ability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. Because the patient can move his eyeballs normally, the oculomotor nerve is not even damaged if this nerve contains.
  • The patient can see distant objects clearly because the long ciliary nerve carries sympathetic fibers to the dilator papillae. Damage to parasympathetic ciliary ganglion and parasympathetic fibers in the short ciliary nerve impairs the ability to focus on close objects (accommodation).

Option B: Oculomotor nerve and long Ciliary nerve

  • The ability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. The patient can see distant objects clearly because the long ciliary nerve carries sympathetic fibers to the dilator papillae.

Option D: Oculomotor and trochlear nerve

  • These nerves’ ability to move the eyeball normally indicates that the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves are intact. If the oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves have any damage, it will affect the movement of the eyeball.

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a 43-year-old male patient, the corneal reflex is absent on the left side but intact on the right side. Which nerve injury can result in the loss of the corneal reflex?

choices.text: The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
Option A: Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

Corneal reflex:

  • Corneal reflex is the blinking of the eye when the cornea is touched by a foreign body.
  • The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve forms the sensory limb of the corneal reflex, and the facial nerve forms the motor limb of the corneal reflex.
  • Loss of corneal reflex may result from injury of Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (afferent limb) or damage to the facial nerve (efferent limb).

​​​​​​​

Option B: Optic nerve

  • Lesion of the optic nerve causes loss of vision.

Option C: Oculomotor nerve

  • Its injury causes pupil dilation, ptosis, and lateral and downward deviation of the eye.

Option D: Abducent nerve

  • It is a pure motor nerve, and its lesion causes loss of abduction of the eye.

questions.text: Which pair of structures is most likely to be compressed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Option C: Azygos vein and thoracic duct

  1. This is a case of an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta, which passes through the aortic hiatus.

  2. The diaphragm has 3 opening

  3. Aortic opening

  4. Esophageal opening

  5. Caval opening

  6. The aortic hiatus or the aortic opening lies anterior to the body of the 12th thoracic vertebrae and between the crura. It transmits to the esophagus, the aorta, and the azygous vein. The aortic opening is not a true opening within the diaphragm. Rather, it is a gap behind the posterior margin of the diaphragm. Sometimes, the azygos vein is transmitted through the right crus.

Option A: Vagus nerve and azygos vein

  • Vagus nerve passing through esophageal hiatus at level T10

  • Aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein ( sometimes) are the only structures passing through the aortic hiatus at level T12

Option B: Esophagus and vagus nerve

  • Esophagus and vagus nerve passing through esophageal hiatus at level T10

Option D: Thoracic duct and esophagus

  • Esophagus passing through esophageal hiatus at level T10. 

  • Thoracic duct passing through the aortic hiatus at level T12

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented to the physician’s clinic with a sudden onset of neck pain radiating to the forearm for the past 1 day. He had been feeling a dull pain in the left upper back since playing golf two days earlier. The physician orders an MRI that reveals a cervical nerve root mass. Which of the following might be affected if the nerve root affected was C8?

choices.text: Adduction and Abduction of interossei muscles

questions.solution:
Option B: Flexors of wrist and fingers

C8 nerve root:

  • C8 nerve root supplies:
    • Pectoralis major (sternal head), Pectoralis minor, Triceps.
    • Flexor digitorum superficialis, pronator quadratus, flexor carpi ulnaris, extensor carpi ulnaris
    • Wrist and Finger flexors, e.g., Flexor pollicis longus and index Flexor digitorum profundus. Abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis.
    • Small muscles of the hand abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis.

Option A: Extensors of wrist and fingers

  • Wrist (and Finger) extensors are supplied by C6(7) through a radial nerve.

Option C: Small muscles of the hand

  • C8 supplies small muscles of the hand; T1, More precisely T1 and constitutes the ulnar nerve that gets involved by injury at the elbow.

Option D: Supinators

  • C6 supplies supinators

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is taken to the emergency room after dislocating his shoulder while playing soccer; After reducing the dislocation, he has pain in the shoulder area and cannot abduct the arm normally. An MRI of the shoulder shows a muscle tear. Which muscles are most likely to be damaged by this injury?

choices.text: The long head of the triceps

questions.solution:
Option D: Supraspinatus

  • The shoulder joint comprises three bones: the humerus, scapula, and clavicle.
  • The head of the humerus and glenoid of the scapula form a ball-and-socket joint. The supraspinatus muscle is located on the back of the shoulder, forming part of the rotator cuff.
  • The rotator cuff consists of Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and teres minor. The rotator cuff covers the head of the humerus and keeps it in place. These muscles help to lift and rotate the arm.
  • Supraspinatus muscle injury is the most common rotator cuff injury occurring during a shoulder dislocation, falling on the arm, and heavy lifting.
  • The muscle is involved in the arm's initial (15°) abduction before the action of the deltoid comes into place. Its function can be assessed by the "empty/full can test."

Option A: Choracobrachialis

  • It is involved in the flexion and adduction of the arm, not the abduction.

Option B: Long head of the tricep

  • It is involved in the extension of the forearm, not the abduction of the arm.
  • It is usually not I hired in shoulder dislocation.

Option C: Pectoralis major

  • It is involved in the humerus flexion and stabilizes the scapula.

questions.text: Which of the following is innervated by the ulnar nerve?
questions.solution:
Option D: Flexor carpi ulnaris 

  • Flexor carpi ulnaris is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm that flexes and adducts the hand.
  • It is located in the anterior compartment of the forearm.
  • It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus, the olecranon, and the posterior border of the ulna.
  • It is inserted at the base of the pisiform bone, the hook of the hamate and the base of the 5th metacarpal.
  • The ulnar nerve innervates it.
  • The ulnar nerve originates from C8-T1. It then runs down and passes behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus at the elbow.
  • After the ulnar nerve passes behind the medial epicondyle, it enters the forearm between the two heads of the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle.
  • The ulnar nerve may become compressed or irritated as it passes behind the medial epicondyle.
  • The ulnar nerve travels through the cubital tunnel under the medial epicondyle.
  • The nerve gives branches to the flexor carpi ulnaris and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus.
  • The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow.
  • Characteristic signs of injury to the ulnar nerve are the inability to grip paper between the fingers, with long-term cases resulting in ulnar claw hand deformity.

Option A: Flexor digitorum superficialis

  • The median nerve innervates flexor digitorum superficialis.
  • As the ulnar nerve does not innervate, it is not affected in this patient.

Option B: Biceps brachii

  • Innervation of bicep brachii is by the musculocutaneous nerve.

Option C: Brachioradialis

  • Innervation of brachioradialis muscle is by the radial nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. He has vomited twice during the past hour. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of amylase and lipase. The organ related to the given pathology is derived from which of the following primitive embryological structures?
questions.solution:
Option A: Foregut

  • This patient’s symptoms of epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and elevated levels of amylase and lipase are suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
  • The pancreas arises from the foregut.
  • The table below lists the structure originating from the foregut, midgut, and hindgut, along with their blood supply.

Option B: Midgut

  • Midgut gives rise to distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, ascending colon, proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.

Option C: Hindgut

  • Hindgut gives rise to distal one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum.

Option D: Notochord

  • Notochord degenerates during embryogenesis, and its only remnant is the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc.

questions.text: A 58-year-old diabetic, male presented with ptosis and down & out eye on left side. Which nerve is most likely to be involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Third cranial nerve

  • The damaged nerve is 3rd cranial nerve which is the oculomotor nerve.
  • Most eyeball muscles are supplied by the 3rd nerve except the lateral rectus and superior oblique, which are supplied by abducent (6th) and trochlear (4th) nerves, respectively.
  • Oculomotor is prone to ischemia in chronic diabetic and hypertensive patients, and its lesion can manifest as diplopia, ptosis, paralysis of eye adduction, and upward and downward gaze. However, pupils are usually spared in diabetic 3rd nerve palsy.

 

Option B: Second cranial nerve

  • The second cranial nerve (optic nerve) does not supply extra-ocular eye muscles.
  • It only supplies nerve fibers to the pupil.

Option C: Sixth cranial nerve

  • The sixth cranial (abducent) nerve only supplies lateral rectus muscle
  • Its paralysis manifest as limitation of outward movement of the affected eye and diplopia in the horizontal gaze.

Option D: Fourth cranial nerve

  • The fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve supplies only superior oblique muscle.
  • Its paralysis manifest as vertical diplopia that is more prominent on a downward gaze, e.g., walking downstairs, and the patient will have a contralateral head tilt.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is brought to the Neurology OPD with fluent speech but inability to repeat words, difficulty naming people and writing, though understanding what is told. CT brain is recommended. As the intern on duty, you suspect a lesion in which area of the brain?
questions.solution:
Option A: Arcuate fasciculus

 

  • This is a case of conduction aphasia, which might result due to damage of arcuate fasciculus. There is poor repetition of language and difficulty in naming. Comprehension of language is intact and so is fluency of speec
  • It connects Wernicke’s area present in the posterior superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (sensory area of speech) to Broca's speech area present in the prefrontal & premotor facial region of the cerebral cortex to integrate language understanding & skilled motor function.
  • The arcuate fasciculus is a major anterior/posterior tract.
  • The classical explanation for conduction aphasia states that damage to the arcuate fasciculus disrupts the transmission of information between the Wernicke area and the Broca area leading to impaired repetition.

Option B: Anterior commissure

  • It is a bundle of axons.
  • It connects the two temporal lobes of the cerebral hemispheres running along the midline.
  • It contributes to memory and senses.

Option C: Corpus callosum

  • It connects the two hemispheres of the brain and allows the information and signal to pass between the two hemispheres.

Option D: Fornix

  • It is a c-shaped nerve bundle and a part of the limbic system. It deals with memory.

questions.text: Which structure connects the sternum to the scapula?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clavicle

  • This is a case of a patient suddenly collapsed on the road, most likely due to cardiac arrest.
  • The doctor must check the patient’s response and pulse in such cases.
  • Emergency CPR must be started if the patient is unresponsive and all the pulses are absent.
  • Sternum or chest bone is attached to the scapula, which is present on the posterior surface with the help of the clavicle or collar bone
  • So that the weight of the upper limb is transmitted to the axial skeleton via the scapula, clavicle, and sternum.

Option A: Manubrium

  • The manubrium is the upper part of the sternum.
  • It articulates with the first rib and the clavicle.

Option C: First rib

  • The first rib does not articulate with the scapula
  • It articulates with the manubrium, which is the most superior part of the sternum to the first thoracic vertebra
  • It is a true rib.

Option D: Second rib

  • It is a true rib.
  • Does not articulate with the scapula.
  • It articulates with 2 thoracic vertebrae.

questions.text: Which of the following locations do you think fibrocartilage is present?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intervertebral disc

  • The features of fibrocartilage are perichondrium is absent, more visible collagen fibers, and few chondrocytes. Chondrocytes run in rows alternated by bundles of collagen fibers.
  • Fibrocartilage is the shock absorber that provides strength to cartilage and is found in the intervertebral disc.
  • It acts as a cushion between two vertebras and the principal joint between two vertebrae.
  • There is a total of 23 discs in the human supine which are 6 cervical, 12 thoracic, and 5 lumbar.
  • It provides flexibility to the supine without compromising on strength.
  • Components of the intervertebral disc are;
    • Inner nucleus pulposus.
    • Outer annulus.

 

  • Costal cartilage and nasal septum are made up of hyaline cartilage.
  • Islands of chondrocytes scattered in the hyalos matrix (collagen fibers not visible).
  • The presence of perichondrium is evident. Hyalos: Glass-like.
    • Collagen fibers are not evident to the eye (optical illusion).
    • Refractive index of Collagen fibers = RI of matrix

Option A: Costal cartilage

  • It’s the bar of hyaline cartilage which prolongs the ribs forward.
  • It increases the elasticity of the thorax.

Option B: Nasal septum

  • It is the cartilage and bone in the nose.
  • It divides the nasal cavity into the right and left portions.
  • It allows the air directly enter the lungs.

Options D: Pinna

  • Pinna has elastic cartilage.
  • Elastic cartilage: Prominent elastic fiber, perichondrium, is present.

questions.text: How long does the ovum remain viable after ovulation?
questions.solution:
Option B: 12-24 hours

  • LH surge occurs 36 hours before ovulation and LH peak occurs 12 hours before ovulation.
  • After ovulation, the ovum is viable for 12-24 hours.
  • Fertilization during this time frame maximizes the chances of conception.
  • Therefore, fertilization should occur within 24 hours of ovulation. Otherwise, degeneration of the ovum occurs, resulting in menstruation.
  • The window period for fertilization in females is 24 hours, and in males is 48 hours (as spermatozoa remain fertile for 24 - 48 hours after ejaculation).

Option A: 6-12 hours

  • After ovulation, the ovum remains viable for 12-24 hours.
  • Therefore, fertilization should occur within 24 hours of ovulation.

Option C: 26-30 hours

  • After ovulation, the ovum remains viable for 12-24 hours.
  • Therefore, fertilization should occur within 24 hours of ovulation.

Option D: 48 hours

  • After ovulation, the ovum remains viable for 12-24 hours.
  • Therefore, fertilization should occur within 24 hours of ovulation.

questions.text: A medical student is observing the contraction of skeletal muscle. He notices that each time he administers a stimulus, the muscle contracts for a short time until it relaxes. Upon increasing the frequency of the stimulus, the frequency of these contractions increases until a frequency is reached at which the muscle shows sustained contraction and does not relax. What is the underlying mechanism behind this kind of contraction?

choices.text: Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm
Increased activity of sarcoplasmic Ca++ ATPase

questions.solution:
Option B: Failure of Ca++ removal from the sarcoplasm

  • This type of sustained forceful contraction of a muscle is called tetanic contraction.
  • A tetanic is a sustained muscle contraction evoked when the motor nerve that innervates a skeletal muscle emits action potentials at a very high rate.
  • During this state, a motor unit has been maximally stimulated by its motor neuron and remains that way for some time.
  • This occurs when multiple impulses stimulate a muscle's motor unit at a sufficiently high frequency.
  • Each stimulus causes a twitch. If stimuli are delivered at a high frequency, the twitches will overlap, resulting in tetanic contraction.
  • With each stimulus, there is a release of Ca++ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) into the sarcoplasm.
  • This Ca++ should be pumped back into the SR for the muscle to relax, which fails to

Option A: Recruitment phenomenon

  • The recruitment phenomenon is a simple means of increasing the force of contraction of a muscle to recruit more muscle fibers.
  • Because all the muscle fibers within a motor unit are activated simultaneously, a muscle recruits more muscle fibers by recruiting more motor units.
  • Increasing the number of motor units will not lead to a tetanic contraction.
  • It will lead to a stronger and more forceful contraction.

Option C: Summation of the stimuli

  • Summation means adding together the individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction.
  • It will also lead to a stronger contraction but not a tetanic contraction.

Option D: Increased activity of sarcoplasmic Ca++ ATPase

  • Increased activity of sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum Ca++ ATPase (SERCA) leads to a decrease in sarcoplasmic Ca++
  • It leads to the transfer of sarcoplasmic Ca++ into the SR
  • This leads to the relaxation of the muscle
  • Once a stimulus comes, it leads to a stronger contraction of the muscle due to the release of already stored Ca++ stores in the SR.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete suddenly fell during his rehearsal half an hour before and presented to the emergency department. There is an increased heart rate of about 148 bpm and palpitations. The attending doctor prescribes him bed rest and some medication and writes down the Bowditch effect in diagnosis. What is true about Bowditch's effect on the heart?

choices.text: An increase in HR decreases relaxation.
An increase in HR increases relaxation.
An increase in HR decreases contraction.
An increase in HR increases contraction.

questions.solution:
Option D: An increase in HR increases contraction.

Bowditch’s effect:

  • Bowditch was a German physiologist.
  • He put forth the term Treppe, which means staircase.
  • If you increase the frequency of a stimulus to a muscle, each succeeding contraction would be stronger than the preceding one.
  • This effect has been called the staircase effect or Bowditch’s effect.
  • An increase in the frequency of stimulation results in increasing strength of contraction.
  • The physiological basis for this effect is increased sarcoplasmic calcium.
  • Strength of contraction of muscle ∝ amount of sarcoplasmic calcium.

Option A: Increase in HR decreases relaxation

  • Heart rate increases mean there is an increase in heart contraction.

Option B: Increase in HR increases relaxation

  • Heart rate increases are directly proportional to heart contraction, not relaxation.

Option C: Increase in HR decreases contraction

  • Heart rate increases cause increased heart contraction.

questions.text: Which adaptations will be appropriate for a lowlander to increase the work capacity at high altitudes?

choices.text: Increasing workload, decreasing duration of exercise
Increasing workload, increasing duration of exercise
Decreasing workload, increasing duration of exercise
Decreasing workload, decreasing duration of exercise

questions.solution:
Option C: Decreasing workload, increasing duration of exercise

  • Exercise increases oxygen requirements, which must be met in the face of this decreased oxygen.
  • Increased workload will increase severe O2 demand, which cannot be met at high altitudes due to low partial pressure of oxygen. Furthermore, it can precipitate pulmonary edema.
  • However, decreased workload and increased duration will produce a low-grade hypoxic drive. This hypoxia produces hypoxia-inducible factor-1α, which stimulates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) production. This promotes angiogenesis, augmenting blood flow and supplying more O2 to the tissues.
  • All these changes are helpful for acclimatization.

Option A: Increasing workload, decreasing duration of exercise

  • If the workload is increased, it will lead to severe hypoxia as the person has not yet established the metabolic changes required at high altitudes.

Option B: Increasing workload, increasing duration of exercise

  • If the workload is increased, it will lead to severe hypoxia as the person has not yet established the metabolic changes required at high altitudes.

Option D: Decreasing workload, decreasing duration of exercise

  • Increased duration of exercise is necessary to keep a low-grade hypoxia drive. If a person exercises for a shorter duration, his oxygen demand will be met soon after rest, and it will not induce the changes required to meet the oxygen demand at a high altitude.

questions.text: Which of the following advice should be given to the patient about the ascent to high altitude?

choices.text: Ascent to high altitude causes respiratory acidosis
Ascent to high altitude causes polycythemia due to dehydration
Acute mountain sickness starts to develop on the 7th day of ascent

questions.solution:
Option D:  Acetazolamide may be given prophylactically

  • At high altitudes, the partial pressure of the oxygen in the atmosphere (pO2) falls.
  • As pO2 falls, the partial pressure of the oxygen in the arterial blood (PaO2) also decreases, which stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors.
  • Stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors causes an increase in respiratory rate. This leads to respiratory alkalosis due to increased excretion of carbon dioxide.
  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.
  • Acetazolamide helps acidify the body by increasing the excretion of bicarbonate in the urine (metabolic acidosis) to counter respiratory alkalosis at high altitudes.
  • Acetazolamide can be taken prophylactically to prevent acute mountain sickness.

Option A: Respiratory acidosis

  • Ascent to high altitude cause pO2 to fall below 60 mmHg.
  • This fall in pO2 causes an increase in the respiratory rate.
  • Hyperventilation causes the carbon dioxide to wash out from the body and causes respiratory alkalosis.

Option B: Polycythemia due to dehydration

  • A decrease in PaO2 stimulates the kidneys to secrete erythropoietin leading to increased red blood cell production.
  • As a result of an increase in erythropoietin levels, polycythemia develops.

Option C: Acute mountain sickness starts to develop on the 7th day of ascent

  • Acute mountain sickness begins to develop within 4-24 hours of ascent to high altitude.
  • Hyperventilation begins to decrease after 4 days due to the desensitization of peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: A professor is explaining the physiology of countercurrent multiplication. Countercurrent multiplication in the kidneys is the process of using energy to generate an osmotic gradient that enables you to reabsorb water from the tubular fluid and produce concentrated urine. This mechanism prevents you from producing liters and liters of dilute urine every day. It is the reason why you do not need to be continually drinking to stay hydrated. The prime driving force for this system is?

choices.text: Reabsorption of Na+ in the thick ascending limb
Action of ADH via aquaporin channels

questions.solution:
Option B: Reabsorption of Na+ in the thick ascending limb

  • The thick ascending limb is permeable to Na+, K+, and Cl- but impermeable to water. Due to this factor, the solutes move out from the tubule into the medullary interstitium.

  • Na+, K+, and Cl- co-(NKCC) transporter is responsible for the movement of ions.

  • It is a co-transport in which the other two ions move due to the potential energy stored in the Na+ concentration gradient.

  • Thus, the prime driving force is the reabsorption of Na+ or differential permeability of Loop of Henle.

Option A: Medullary hyperosmolarity

  • Medullary hyperosmolarity can be said to be the driving force for ADH action. Because water can only move passively (driven by an osmotic gradient).

Option C: Action of ADH via aquaporin channels

  • ADH is not the driving force for the countercurrent mechanism.

Option D: Urea recycling

  • Urea does not drive water reabsorption as it is an ineffective osmole. It equilibrates between medullary interstitium and tubular fluid. Thus, it increases the hyperosmolarity of the interstitium and gets excreted in high concentrations in urine.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the physician's clinic with a complaint of recent weight loss. Further examination reveals thyroid gland is smaller than normal. On further testing, she has an elevated plasma thyroxine (T4) concentration and a low plasma TSH concentration. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: A lesion in the anterior pituitary that prevents TSH secretion
The patient is taking thyroid extract

questions.solution:
Option D: The patient is taking thyroid extract.

  • This patient has a recent complaint of weight loss with elevated thyroid hormones and decreased level of TSH. These findings are likely due to exogenous thyroid hormone intake, which causes decreased TSH levels due to negative feedback inhibition.

Regulation of Thyroid hormone synthesis:

  • The thyroid hormone secretion is regulated by the feedback effect of the thyroid hormones at the anterior pituitary and hypothalamus. Therefore, when thyroid hormones are synthesized in excess, there is feedback inhibition of the TSH release by the anterior pituitary thyrotropes and hypothalamic TRH release. Conversely, when the thyroid hormone synthesis is decreased, there is a loss of feedback inhibition leading to activation of the TSH release by the anterior pituitary thyrotropes and hypothalamic TRH release.
  • If a patient is taking thyroid extra, i.e., exogenous thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), the increased levels of thyroid hormones cause feedback inhibition of TSH, hence, decreasing TSH secretion. This results in hypoplasia of the thyroid gland, known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.
  • Effect of variations in the concentrations of thyroid hormone-binding proteins in the plasma on various parameters of thyroid function after equilibrium has been reached.

Option A: A lesion in the anterior pituitary that prevents TSH secretion

  • The anterior pituitary secretes TSH that stimulates the thyroid follicles to secrete thyroid hormones.
  • A lesion in the anterior pituitary results in decreased TSH secretion and subsequently leads to decreased T4 secretion.

Option B: Graves’ disease

  • In Grave's disease, the thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs) stimulate the thyroid gland's TSH receptor, leading to hyperactivation.
  • As a result, there will be increased secretion of thyroid hormones, resulting in feedback inhibition of the thyrotropes in the anterior pituitary. Therefore, the TSH levels will be low, and thyroid hormones will be elevated.
  • Due to continued stimulation by the TSIs, also known as long-acting thyroid stimulators, there will be thyroid glandular hypertrophy or goiter.

Option C: The patient is taking propylthiouracil

  • Propylthiouracil is an Antithyroid substance (PTU = propylthiouracil; MMI= Methimazole)
  • Propylthiouracil inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by blocking the enzyme thyroid peroxidase leading to loss of oxidation of iodide. As a result, there will be a decrease in thyroid hormone concentration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with involuntary, painful muscle contractions in her hands and feet for three days, accompanied by tingling. She has a history of thyroidectomy. Lab tests reveal hypocalcemia. The described muscle activity, when voluntary, mirrors a physiological condition in which muscles achieve maximum tension without subsequent relaxation, similar to post-tetanic potentiation. Which of the following is typically implicated in facilitating this response in muscle tissue?

choices.text: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

questions.solution:
Option C: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

  • In the clinical scenario above, a woman has presented with involuntary muscular contractions. Her past thyroid surgical history suggests hypoparathyroidism, while her laboratory investigations show hypocalcemia. Hence, she has presented with tetany (carpopedal spasm) due to hypocalcemia. These muscle spasms are much similar to the physiologic tetany in muscles. The only difference is that tetany has involuntary muscular contractions in hypocalcemia, while tetanic contractions are voluntary in normal muscles.

  • When the nerves send a weak signal to contract a muscle, the motor units in the muscle that contains the smallest muscle fibers are stimulated in preference to the larger motor units. As the signal increases in strength, larger motor units also begin to be excited.
  • Gradually, the frequency of muscle contraction also increases, and there comes the point at which a new contraction occurs before the preceding one ends. This second contraction is added partially to the first, increasing the total strength of the contraction. When the frequency reaches an optimum level, the successive contractions fuse, and the muscle tension reaches its peak with no relaxation observed, the action appears to be completely smooth; this is called tetanization. A sustained muscle contraction remains in this stage for some time.
  • Post-tetanic facilitation is the neuronal phenomenon in which a neuron is more easily excited after a brief period of activity. It occurs after tetanic stimulation of the presynaptic neuron. It is due to the buildup the calcium ions in the presynaptic membrane caused by the prior neuronal activity. Subsequent neuronal impulses release neurotransmitters more readily due to this pre-placed calcium from the previous stimulus.

Option A: Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

  • During the depolarisation stage of the action potential, the membrane becomes suddenly permeable to sodium ions. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up, allowing many positively charged sodium ions to flow into the cell's interior. It causes the normal resting negative potential to change into a positive potential. Hence, these channels play a significant role in the depolarisation and repolarization of the nerve membrane.

 

Option B: Opening of transmitter-gated potassium channels

  • Transmitter-gated or ligand-gated potassium ion channels are activated upon binding a neurotransmitter, hormone, or second messengers to the ion channel. They are involved in fast synaptic transmission in the nervous system. The flow of ions across the membrane will either depolarize or hyperpolarization.

 

Option D: Electrotonic conduction

  • It is the passive flow of a change in electric potential along a nerve or muscle membrane. It occurs in response to insufficient stimulation to trigger an actively propagated action potential but instead generates depolarisation in a small area of the membrane.

questions.text: Which statement best describes a functional role for the lateral hemispheres of the cerebellum?

choices.text: Control and coordinate movements of the axial muscles, as well as the shoulder and hip
Control movements that involve distal limb musculature
Function with the cerebral cortex to plan, execute and coordinate movements
Stimulate motor neurons through their connections to the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Option C: Function with the cerebral cortex to plan movements

  • From a functional point of view, the Cerebellum is divided into three parts:
    • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe)
    • Spinocerebellum
    • Cerebrocerebellum
  • Cerebrocerebellum
    • Includes the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres.
    • They interact with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements
    • It receives inputs from the cerebral cortex and pontine nuclei and sends outputs to the thalamus and red nucleus.

Option A: Control and coordinate movements of the axial muscles as well as the shoulder and hip

  • The paleocerebellum (or spinocerebellum) consists mainly of the vermis, an axial structure, and is superimposed on the archicerebellum in amphibians, reptiles, and birds.
  • The paleocerebellum is connected to the spinal cord and controls postural muscle activity by influencing muscle tonus
  • The cortex of the vermis coordinates the movements of the trunk, including the neck, shoulders, thorax, abdomen, and hips.

Option B: Control movements that involve distal limb musculature

  • Control of the distal extremity muscles is by the intermediate zone of cerebellar hemispheres, located adjacent to the vermis.

Option D: Stimulate motor neurons through their connections to the spinal cord

  • Signals generated in the primary motor cortex travel down the corticospinal tract (green) through the spinal white matter to synapse on interneurons and motor neurons in the spinal cords ventral horn.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the composition of the organ of Corti?

choices.text: A single row of inner hair cells and a single row of outer hair cells
3-4 rows of each inner and outer hair cell.
A single row of inner hair cells and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.
A single row of outer hair cells and 3-4 rows of inner hair cells

questions.solution:
Option C: A single row of inner hair cells and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.

                                        Organ of Corti

  • The organ of the Corti is located on the basilar membrane.
  • It contains hair cells which are the auditory receptors.
  • It is spiral in structure and extends from the base to the apex of the cochlea.
  • The hair cells are arranged in four rows.
  • There are 20,000 outer hair cells and 3500 inner hair cells.
  • Only a single row of inner hair cells is located towards the center of the cochlea, and 3-4 rows of outer hair cells.
  • The covering of the rows is by a tectorial membrane in which the tips of outer hair cells are embedded.
  • The process of hair cells penetrates through reticular lamina supported by the rods of Corti.
  • The sensory neurons innervate the inner hair cells.
  • 4-10% of neurons innervate the outer hair cells.
  • These neurons form the cochlear part of CN VIII.
  • The sensory neuron cell bodies are around the hair cells' bases in the spiral ganglion within the modulus.
  • The efferent fibers terminate at the outer hair cells rather than the inner hair cells.

Option A: A single row of inner hair cells and a single row of outer hair cells.

  • The hair cells are arranged in 4 rows.
  • One row of inner hair cells and 3 rows of outer hair cells (not a single row).

Option B: 3-4 rows of each inner and outer hair cell.

  • Only 1 row of inner hair cells is present instead of 3-4 rows.
  • 3-4 rows of outer hair cells are present.

Option D: A single row of outer hair cells and 3-4 rows of inner hair cells.

  • One row of inner hair cells is present.
  • 3-4 rows of outer hair cells are present.
  • This option gives the opposite composition.

questions.text: Which of the following represents normal 'Y' descent in the JVP?

choices.text: Isovolumetric relaxation of the right ventricle

questions.solution:
Option C: Opening of the tricuspid valve

  • “y” wave indicates a fall of right atrial pressure due to the opening of the tricuspid valve leading to the ventricular filling.

Option A: Atrial diastole

  • P wave on ECG indicates the atrial diastole followed by atrial systole.

Option B: Closure of the tricuspid valve

  • Its closure produces the first heart sound, which is pronounced as Lub.

Option D: Isovolumetric relaxation of the right ventricle

  • It is masked under the QRS complex and does not appear on ECG.

questions.text: What is the primary mediator of malignancy-associated hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP)

  • PRP was discovered as a product of human cancers that are of squamous cell origin and that are associated with hypercalcemia.
  • Normal tissues also express this protein – skin keratinocytes, lactating mammary epithelium, placenta, and fetal parathyroid glands.
  • The gene for PTHrp and PTH is on paired chromosomes

Option A: Parathyroid hormone (PTH)

  • PTHr PRPses hypercalcemia in patients with lung cancer through paraneoplastic association, not PTH.

Option C: Interleukin - 6 (IL-6)

  • Interleukin-6 is an inflammatory cytokine that does not affect calcium regulation in the body, and it does not cause hypercalcemia.

Option D: Calcitonin

  • Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland that acts opposite to PTH and regulates blood calcium levels by decreasing it.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding digestion and absorption of fat is not correct?

choices.text: The stomach secretes a lipase enzyme that plays a role in the digestion of fat.
Most of the lipids are digested by pancreatic lipase.
Bile acids emulsify lipids in the small intestine, increasing the surface area for digestion.
Chylomicrons are directly absorbed into the bloodstream.

questions.solution:
Option D: Chylomicrons are directly absorbed into the bloodstream.

  • Chylomicrons are absorbed into lymphatic vessels and enter the bloodstream via the thoracic duct.

Digestion and absorption of fat:

  • Ebner glands present on the dorsal surface of the tongue secrete lingual lipase. The stomach also secretes lipase. Lingual lipase and stomach lipase play a small role in the digestion of ingested lipids.
  • Bile acids emulsify lipids in the small intestine, increasing the surface area for digestion.
  • Most of the digestion of lipids occurs in the duodenum by the action of pancreatic lipase that digests triglycerides into free fatty acids and monoglycerides.
  • Cholesterol esterase present in the pancreatic juice is responsible for the hydrolysis of cholesterol esters, phospholipids, and esters of fat-soluble vitamins.
  • The hydrophobic products of lipid digestion are solubilized in micelles.
  • Micelles bring the digested lipids in contact with the enterocytes.
  • Fatty acids, monoglycerides, and cholesterol diffuse across the cell membrane into the enterocytes.
  • Inside the enterocytes, lipid products are re-esterified into triglycerides.
  • Triglycerides and cholesterol esters are coated with phospholipids and apoproteins to form chylomicrons.
  • Chylomicrons are transported out of the cell by exocytosis into the lymphatic vessels.
  • Chylomicrons enter the bloodstream via the thoracic duct.

Option A: The stomach secretes a lipase enzyme that plays a role in the digestion of fat.

  • Lingual lipase and stomach lipase play a small role in the digestion of ingested lipids.

Option B: Most of the lipids are digested by pancreatic lipase.

  • Most of the digestion of lipids occurs in the duodenum by the action of pancreatic lipase that digests triglycerides into free fatty acids and monoglycerides.

Option C: Bile acids emulsify lipids in the small intestine, increasing the surface area for digestion.

  • Bile acids emulsify lipids in the small intestine, increasing the surface area for digestion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood analysis still shows a normal glucose level. Which of the following processes is mainly responsible for the blood glucose maintenance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liver gluconeogenesis

  • The patient is in starvation, given that he has not taken any food for the past 3 days.
  • During short-term fasting, the liver produces and releases glucose mainly through glycogenolysis. However, during prolonged fasting, glycogen is depleted, and hepatocytes synthesize glucose through gluconeogenesis using lactate, pyruvate Pyruvate, glycerol, and amino acids.
  • Glucagon released during starvation will cause the activation of gluconeogenic enzymes in the liver, which will maintain the blood glucose needed for the functioning of vital organs such as the brain, heart, and RBCs. Therefore, the answer is liver gluconeogenesis.
  • The Fed state is mainly related to glycogen metabolism, while the fasted state shows a gluconeogenesis process from gluconeogenic substrates.
  • The figure below shows the role of the liver in the fed and fasting state under hormonal control.

Option B: Dietary Glucose

  • Dietary glucose can provide blood glucose up to 2 hours after feeding. The extra glucose consumed in food gets deposited in the liver and muscles as glycogen and fats in adipose tissues.

Option C: Muscle glycogenolysis

  • The glycogenolysis inside the muscles gives glucose-6-phosphate as an end-product, not D-Glucose, due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in muscles. Hence, muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose directly.

Option D: Liver glycogenolysis

  • Glycogen breakdown in the liver can maintain blood glucose for 12-18 hours. After that period, liver gluconeogenesis is the primary source of blood glucose during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman complains of epigastric pain that is relieved after meals but worsens after 1-2 hours. Investigations suggest bacterial infection of intestinal cells, leading to the production of large amounts of ammonia (NH3) as a result of metabolic activities. This NH3 can rapidly diffuse into the intestine and the portal vein, entering the circulation. What is the probable cause for the absorption of NH3 in this scenario?

choices.text: Conversion of NH3 to ammonium ion in the blood
Decreased concentration of bicarbonate in the blood

questions.solution:
Option B: Conversion of NH3 to ammonium ion in the blood

  • This patient presents with epigastric pain after a meal. This is a typical case of peptic ulcer disease most likely caused by H.pylori.
  • Usually, intestinal bacteria produce average amounts of ammonia in the body as a byproduct of their metabolism. Once a bacterial infection of intestinal cells occurs in the body, there is overproduction of ammonia. The body cannot excrete excess ammonia, so it goes into circulation.
  • Once ammonia enters circulation, it starts accepting protons. NH3 is a weak base that readily accepts a proton to produce the ammonium ion as (NH3 + H+ → NH4+), with a pKa of 9.5. Thus, at pH 7.4, most of the NH3 will be present as an ammonium ion.

Option A: Decrease blood pH

  • A decrease in blood pH is less likely to happen. Because the absorption of H+ ions will tend to increase, not decrease, and that will cause the pH of blood to increase.

Option C: Decreased concentration of bicarbonate in the blood

  • With the decrease of hydrogen ions, carbonic acid will dissociate to produce more bicarbonates, so instead of a decrease in the concentration of bicarbonate in the blood, there will be an increase in the concentration of bicarbonate.

Option D: Increased expiration of CO2

  • As we know, carbonic acid will dissociate with the decrease of hydrogen ions to produce more bicarbonates. More CO2 will go towards carbonic acid, so inspiration will increase rather than expire.

questions.text: In Hyperhemolytic conditions or chronic hemolysis, hemoglobin is oxidatively degraded to release free heme from ferric hemoglobin. This free heme can accelerate tissue damage by promoting peroxidative reactions and activation of inflammatory cascades. Which of the following protein binds to free heme to inhibit these effects.
questions.solution:
Option analysis:

  • Ceruloplasmin: protein for transport of copper in blood
  • Haptoglobin: protein produced by the liver that the body uses to clear free hemoglobin (found outside of red blood cells) from circulation
  • Hemosiderin: is a Brown golden pigment made of aggregates of several ferritin. It carries higher iron content but Release iron more slowly ass compared to ferritin
  • Hemopexin: is a β1-globulin that binds free heme and inhibits its deleterious oxidative effects.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the process of gene expression in different cells of the body. His finding points out that although all the cells of the body have the same genetic information in their nucleus the genetic material is selectively expressed depending on the specific type and function of the cell in the tissue. The figure below shows the technique used by the researcher for this purpose. Which of the following genetic techniques is shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
• Microarray is also known as ‘chip’. It’s a small chip on which lots of probes can be placed and thus multiple
    mutations can be detected. Its like a chip in computer where lots of information is present on a small ‘chip’

CHIP

(Chromatin Immuno Precipitation)

RNA interference (RNAi)

(Gene Silencing technique)

RFLP

(Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism)

technique for detecting Protein DNA interaction

and Histone modifications

technique to inhibit protein synthesis at the level of translation, by using micro RNA , which inhibits target mRNA

Method to identify polymorphism in DNA using Restriction endonuclease enzyme which cut at the palindromic sites.

Here picture is showing you only the chip. ChIP technique may or may not use the gene chip (microarray). So the best answer here is chip or microarray.

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints. Blood glutamine was found to be increased. Also, uracil levels were raised. what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency:

  • In the urea cycle, ammonia combines with carbon dioxide and forms carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate combines with ornithine and forms citrulline. The enzyme responsible for the reaction is carbamoyl phosphate synthase and ornithine carbamoyl transferase, respectively.
  • If the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is deficient, it leads to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood and carbamoyl phosphate from in liver mitochondria .
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased uracil synthesis (see fig).
  • Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are all increased in OTC defect.

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency presents with the symptoms of refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, etc.
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is the most common urea cycle disorder.
  • It is characterized by decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen.
  • CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CPS-I deficiency:

  • CPS-I enzyme is involved in the urea cycle. It is present in the mitochondria.
  • It leads to elevated ammonia levels in the blood, which can have toxic effects on the brain.
  • It does not lead to elevated levels of orotic acids in the blood.

Option B - Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency:

  • Arginosuccinate synthase enzyme is a part of the urea cycle. It is involved in the synthesis of argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase.
  • If citrulline is increased, then it means that Arginosuccinate synthetase is the deficient enzyme.

Option C - CPS-II deficiency:

  • CPS-II is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine.
  • It is activated by ATP and is inhibited by UMP.
  • Its deficiency is associated with the decreased synthesis of pyrimidine.

questions.text: Which DNA repair mechanism is employed by the CRISPR/Cas9 technology, allowing researchers to edit specific parts of the genome selectively?
questions.solution:
Option C: Non-homologous end joining

CRISPR

  • The CRISPR system represents a form of acquired immunity of bacteria to infection by bacteriophages, which complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases.
  • CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to be foreign (or any complementary) DNA.
  • Within bacteria, this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex degrades and inactivates targeted DNA.
  • Uses gene deletion, gene editing, and even modulation of gene transcription.
  • CRISPR-mediated gene therapy works on the basis of both homologous and non-homologous end joining DNA repair mechanisms.

Option A: Base Excision Repair

  • Base Excision Repair involves the excision of a single base rather than the nucleotide and is most commonly used to repair damage caused by endogenous DNA insult.
  • It is especially important for cellular response to oxidative DNA damage.
  • CRISPR technique does not use a base excision mechanism for gene editing.

Option B: Nucleotide excision repair

  • Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the main pathway used by mammals to remove bulky DNA lesions such as those formed by UV light, environmental mutagens, and some cancer chemotherapeutic adducts from DNA.
  • Deficiencies in NER are associated with the extremely skin cancer-prone inherited disorder, xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • It is not the gene-editing method of the CRISPR technique.

Option D: Mismatch repair

  • Mismatch repair is a process that corrects mismatched nucleotides.
  • DNA mismatch repair (MMR) guards the integrity of the genome in virtually all cells.
  • Mismatch repair (MMR) proteins are essential for repairing DNA errors (e.g., point mutations) that are generated during DNA replication.
  • Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancers (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome are the best examples.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient presents with episodes of pain, especially in the hands and feet, a decreased ability to sweat (hypohidrosis), clusters of small, dark red spots on the skin called angiokeratomas, corneal opacity (cloudiness of eyes), episodes of seizures in the recent past. On histopathology examination and urine examination following image was obtained :





Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the above-mentioned patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Alpha galactosidase

  • The features given in this case, like, absent sweating, particular skin lesions, and corneal findings or hearing loss due to Fabry neuropathy, all are suggestive that the case as mentioned above is of Fabry's disease. It's a lysosomal storage disease.
  • Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive disease.
  • The onset of the disease is common in childhood; moreover can occur at the age of 60-80.
  • It is due to a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase.
  • The urine examination showing the maltase cross appearance is diagnostic of Fabry's.
  • The histopathology shows the zebra bodies. The concentric onion skin bodies are typical in Fabry's. But can also be seen in Neiman pick disease.
  • Enzyme replacement is the treatment.

Option A: Ceramidase

  • Ceramidase is used to catalyze the hydrolysis of ceramide to sphingosine and fatty acids.
  • Ceramidase deficiency cause Farber disease which is a lipid storage disease.
  • Fabry's is caused by the deficiency of alpha-galactosidase. So, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Beta galactosidase

  • Fabry's is caused by the deficiency of alpha-galactosidase.
  • Beta-galactosidase produces glucose by cleaving lactose.
  • The deficiency of beta-galactosidase causes beta galactosidosis, which is a lysosomal storage disorder.
  • Fabry's is caused by the deficiency of alpha-galactosidase. So, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Alpha glucosidase

  • It is an enzyme that is present at the brush border of the small intestine and hydrolyzes the alpha-1, 4-bond of starch or disaccharides to produce an alpha-glucose molecule.
  • Alpha-glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease.
  • Fabry's is caused by the deficiency of alpha-galactosidase. So, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy was hospitalized after experiencing a seizure, lethargy and dehydration. The infant had reduced food intake due to a stomach infection, and the blood glucose level upon admission was 28 mg/dl. Urine analysis revealed the absence of ketone bodies but the presence of various dicarboxylic acids. What could be the underlying cause of fasting hypoglycemia in this case?

choices.text: Defect in converting acetyl CoA to glucose
High production of ATP and NADH
Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

questions.solution:
Option D: Low acetyl-CoA production

  • MCAD deficiency results in decreased production of acetyl-CoA due to impaired oxidation of medium chain fatty acids (<12 C in length).
  • As acetyl-CoA is an allosteric activator of gluconeogenic enzyme pyruvate carboxylase, hence, glucose levels fall.
  • MCAD patients have non-ketotic hypoglycemia during starvation due to a lack of availability of ketone body substrate acetyl-CoA and dicarboxylic acidosis.
  • Acetyl CoA cannot be used for the net synthesis of glucose.
  • In MCAD deficiency, ketogenesis is decreased due to low acetyl CoA due to impaired fatty acid oxidation, which also means low ATP and NADH synthesis (option B), both of which are also needed for gluconeogenesis.

Option A: Defect in converting acetyl-CoA to glucose

  • Acetyl CoA cannot be used for the net synthesis of glucose.

Option B: High production of ATP and NADH

  • ATP and NADH are produced in the electron transport chain.
  • ATP is used to store and transport energy to the cells of the body.
  • During the overproduction of ATP, the liver uses ATP to produce glycogen.

Option C: Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

  • Acetoacetate is a ketone body that provides energy to the body cells.
  • Excess conversion of acetyl-CoA to acetoacetate leads to an increase in ketone bodies in the blood.
  • Increased ketone bodies level in the blood cause ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient is diagnosed with Alport syndrome. Further testing would reveal a defect in which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
• In Alport syndrome, There is defect in type IV collagen that changes composition of the basement membrane kidney glomeruli.
  • Due to absence of a function basement membrane, the kidneys are unable in properly filtering waste products from blood and both proteins and blood can enter the urine.
  • Type IV collagen is also found in inner ear so it is important for hearing and for the eye.
  • A mutation in α1-antitrypsin will lead to emphysema, mutations in fibrillin lead to Marfan syndrome, and mutations in β-myosin heavy chain can lead to FHC (Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)

questions.text:
A 15-day-old baby is brought to the clinic by his mother with the complaint of frequent vomiting. He has recently started feeding on breast milk. An appropriate diagnosis is made, and the patient is discharged after the resolution of the symptoms. A few days later, the baby presents to the clinic again with jaundice. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular examination shows the following findings:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Galactosemia

  • The cataract shown is an Oil Drop Cataract, which is characteristic of Galactosemia.
  • These clinical manifestations of the liver affected when milk is the diet is typical of Classical Galactosemia.

Option B: Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus

  • In Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus, jaundice and hepatomegaly are observed, but cataract is never there.

Option C: Hereditary Fructose Intolerance

  • Bilateral cataracts rule out the possibility of Hereditary Fructose Intolerance, although other symptoms exist in both these diseases.

Option D: Gaucher's disease

  • Gaucher's disease is a sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of β-Glucosidase or β-Glucocerebrosidase with an accumulation of Glucosylceramide.
  • Clinical features include No mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy visits the clinic accompanied by his parents with a history of failure to thrive. Physical examination shows jaundice and splenomegaly. A CBC shows a microcytic, hypochromic anaemia (haemoglobin - 7.3 g/dL). Fetal haemoglobin accounts for most of the haemoglobin. A peripheral blood film is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: β-thalassemia

  • Peripheral smear given in the case shows hypochromic, microcytic RBCs, with anisocytosis, poikilocytosis and target cells; along with clinical features suggests the diagnosis of β-Thalassemia
  • Unpaired α-chains precipitate in red blood cells, accounting for ineffective erythropoiesis and increased hemolysis.
  • In homozygous β-thalassemia, fetal haemoglobin (haemoglobin F) accounts for most of the haemoglobin, although increased levels of haemoglobin A2 are also present.

Option A: G6PD deficiency

  • It presents with normocytic anaemia rather than microcytic anaemia, as seen in this case.
  • It occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents such as dapsone, nitrofurantoin, and fava beans.

Option B: Sickle cell anaemia

  • The absence of sickle cells on the peripheral smears of this patient effectively rules out sickle cell anaemia.

Option D: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • Hypochromic microcytic cells are also found in IDA, but jaundice and splenomegaly effectively rule it out.

questions.text: A 7 Yr old girl child with a known case of Non-Hodgkins lymphoma on Cyclophosphamide now presents with sudden onset fever and petechiae. Bone marrow examination revealed Hypercellular Lymphoblastic cells. Which of the following Lymphoid malignancy described here arise from thymic cells?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pre – T cell ALL

  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphomas (ALLs) are neoplasms composed of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells, which are referred to as lymphoblasts.
  • About 85% are B-ALLs, which typically manifest as childhood acute "leukaemias."
  • The less common T-ALLs tend to present in adolescent males as thymic “lymphomas.”
  • ACUTE LYMPHOBLASTIC LEUKEMIA:
    • The most frequent type of leukaemia in children.
    • Usually presents with sudden onset of Fatigue/fever/petechiae with Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy, and Sternal Tenderness (+).
  • DIAGNOSIS:
    • Bone marrow examination (IOC)
    • Blood investigations
    • Immunophenotyping.

Option A: Hairy cell leukaemia

  • In a particular kind of malignancy known as hairy cell leukaemia, the bone marrow overproduces lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). Cancer of the blood and bone marrow, hairy cell leukaemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of hairy cell leukaemia include infections, tiredness, and pain below the ribs:
    • Weakness or feeling tired.
    • Frequent infections.
    • Easy bruising or bleeding.
    • Shortness of breath.
  • In hairy cell leukaemia, a CBC test may show all levels of these cells are too low. Another type of blood test might involve looking at your blood under the microscope.
  • Treatment options for hairy cell leukaemia include the following:
    • Watchful waiting, if feasible.
    • Rituximab.
    • Vemurafenib

Option B: Burkitt lymphoma

  • A rare, fast-growing type of leukaemia (blood cancer) in which too many white blood cells called B lymphocytes form in the blood and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms of Burkitt's lymphoma include:
    • Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpit, or groin.
    • Fever.
    • Night sweats.
    • Nausea.
  • Diagnoses of Burkitt's lymphoma and Burkitt's leukaemia may involve biopsies and imaging tests, such as CT scans or MRI scans.
  • The central nervous system form of Burkitt's lymphoma may be treated with intrathecal chemotherapy. The fluid between the membranes of the spinal cord and the brain is where doctors inject this treatment.

Option C: Pre – B cell ALL

  • Pre-B cell ALL is the most common type of leukaemia to present with renal infiltration as the presenting sign.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Bone or joint pain
    • Limping
    • Fever
    • Pale skin
    • Red or purple spots called petechiae on the skin
  • In the early stages of development in the bone marrow, B-lymphocytes are where ALL develops in 75–80% of adult cases. Therefore, the condition is known as precursor B-cell ALL or Pre-B-cell ALL.
  • Immunotherapy (monoclonal antibodies or CAR T-cell treatment) may be possible for patients with B-cell ALL.

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic man comes in with a 6-day history of productive cough and fever. The temperature is 38.7°C (103°F), the heart rate is 32 beats per minute, and the blood pressure is 126/86 mm Hg. The patient's cough worsens, and he starts coughing up a lot of foul-smelling sputum. An X-ray of the chest reveals an infiltrate in the right upper and middle lobes. A CBC reveals leukocytosis (WBC = 38,000/mL), with 80% of neutrophils being slightly immature and toxic granulation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of leukocyte alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following best describes the hematologic condition of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Options:

Option D: Leukemoid reaction

  • Neutrophilia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count greater than 7,000/L.
  • In acute infections, neutrophilia can be so severe that it can be misdiagnosed as leukaemia, particularly chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML), which is referred to as a leukemoid reaction.
  • The following are clues to the benign (or reactive) nature of a leukemoid reaction:
    • The cells in the peripheral blood smear are more mature than myelocytes, and
    • Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase activity is high in benign conditions but low in CML patients.
    • Large blue cytoplasmic inclusions known as "Dohle bodies" or toxic granulation are common in benign neutrophils.

The above image shows Dohle's bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Acute myelogenous leukemia

  • More than 20% of blast cells on bone marrow or peripheral blood smear suggest AML.

  • The scenario is suggestive of leukemoid reaction 

Option B: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

  • CLL is a slowly progressive malignancy of blood cells in which there is an increased number of leukocytes in the lymphoid tissue.
  • In CLL, abnormal leukocytes, also called leukemic cells, are produced instead of healthy white blood cells and accumulate over time.
  • CBC showing more than 10,000 lymphocytes/mm3 is highly suggestive of CLL, but definitive are needed for confirmatory diagnosis.

Option C: Chronic myelogenous leukaemia

  • LAP score is low in patients with CML.
  • More immature cells are present in CML.
  • Hypogranular leukocytes are present in CML.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented to medical OPD with low-grade fever, fatigue and unexplained weight loss for the last six months. On examination, an enlarged supraclavicular lymph node was palpated. The image depicts the histology of her lymph node biopsy. The tumour cells express B cell antigens and are Epstein-Barr virus-positive (EBV). The patient is HIV positive and is on antiviral medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Large B-Cell Lymphoma

  • The patient presented with an enlarged supraclavicular lymph node and unexplained weight loss. She is also HIV and EBV positive, and histology shows large neoplastic cells with round nuclei and prominent nucleoli, including giant tumour cells. All of these factors favour the diagnosis of diffuse large-cell B-cell lymphoma.
  • Most lymphomas in patients with AIDS are high-grade B-cell lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma and diffuse large-cell B-cell lymphoma.
  • Diffuse Large B- Cell Lymphomas are commonly EBV-positive and associated with immunodeficiency.
  • The median age of presentation is 60 years, but it can occur in any age group.
  • It is also seen in AIDS with HHV-8.
  • Its histology depicts large B cells (3 to 4 times the normal size) with Round nuclei with prominent nucleoli and dispersed chromatin, a relatively small amount of pale cytoplasm, a multilobular vesicular nucleus in some cases and occasionally tumour giant cells similar to Reed Sternberg cells.
  • It is Positive for CD20, CD79a, and CD15 negative, and background cells are predominantly T cells.
  • 30% of cases have BCL2 protein overproduction resulting from (14;18) translocation.
  • It is fatal if not treated in time.

Option A: Follicular Lymphoma

  • It is usually present in the adult population as painless generalised lymphadenopathy.
  • Its histology shows distinct nodular proliferation with numerous large centrocytes having angular 'cleaved' nuclei with rare mitosis and apoptosis.

Option B: Hodgkin Lymphoma

  • It is characterised by the presence of Reed Sternberg cell, classically having two mirror-image nuclei giving owl eyes appearance.
  • It is not associated with AIDs and EBV.

Option D: Mantle Cell Lymphoma

  • Its cell resembles the naïve B cells found in the mantle zone.
  • It involves lymph nodes in a diffuse/ vague manner.
  • Tumour cells are only slightly larger than normal cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with no known co-morbid presented to the hospital with complaints of spontaneous vaginal bleeding. She gets symptomatic treatment. She suffers from a tonic-clonic seizure in the next 24 hours. She is febrile, jaundiced, and has extensive purpura on physical examination. A haemoglobin of 5.3 g/dL with 8% reticulocytes, a platelet count of 10,000/mL, and a BUN of 48 mg/dL were found in the lab. A peripheral blood smear is also advised. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) occurs in acute or chronic form.
  • This disease has a pentad that includes fever, Microangiopathic hemolytic Anemia, Thrombocytopenia, Neurologic symptoms and Renal impairment.
  • All these things are positive in this patient.
  • The deposition of PAS-positive hyaline microthrombi in arterioles and capillaries throughout the body, particularly in the heart, brain, and kidneys, is a morphologic hallmark of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Platelet aggregates, fibrin, a few erythrocytes and leukocytes make up the microthrombi.
  • The peripheral blood smear displays microangiopathic hemolytic Anemia and numerous schistocytes.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura resembles hemolytic uremic syndrome, which occurs more often in children than adults.
  • The other choices are not associated with microangiopathic changes (e.g., schistocytes).

 

Option A: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia

  • Drugs can cause thrombocytopenia by several mechanisms, including direct bone marrow or other organ toxicity.
  • Clinically, these patients present with moderate to severe thrombocytopenia (defined as a platelet count of less than 50 × 109/L) and spontaneous bleeding varying from simple ecchymosis, petechiae, and mucosal bleeding to life-threatening spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage.
  • Excluding other causes of thrombocytopenia (such as congenital disorders and inflammatory processes) is important.
  • Many drugs can cause thrombocytopenia. Some of them are Heparin, furosemide, Gold, Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory disease, Antibiotics, and Statins.
  • In this case, no such drug has been used

Option B: Henoch-Schönlein purpura

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is the most common vasculitis in childhood.
  • It most commonly affects children 2-8 years of age 
  • The features include rash and one or more of the following:
    • Arthritis/arthralgia (50-75%)
    • Abdominal pain (50%)
    • Nephritis (25-50%)

Option C: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • It is a quantitative disorder of platelets caused by antibodies directed against platelet or megakaryocytic antigens.
  • Related to antibody-mediated immune destruction of platelets or their precursors.
  • The peripheral blood smear in Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura exhibits numerous large platelets, and the bone marrow shows a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes.
  • Clinical Features include:
    • Petechia
    • Purpura
    • Hemorrhagic bullae
    • Gum bleeding
    • Hematuria
    • Melena

questions.text: A 10-day-old infant presents with a complaint of projectile vomiting. His mother states that the infant will actively drink his milk, but he forcefully vomits after each feeding. The infant shows signs of failure to thrive, with weight loss, dehydration, and lethargy. Physical examination reveals a firm, nontender, mobile, "olive-shaped" epigastric mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Congenital pyloric stenosis

  • This patient with projectile vomiting after feedings, failure to thrive, weight loss, dehydration, lethargy, and a firm, nontender, mobile, "olive-shaped" epigastric mass most likely has Congenital pyloric stenosis.
  • It is caused by hypertrophy of the circular muscle layer of the pylorus.
  • Hypertrophy of pyloric musculature → Obstruction, non-bilious projectile vomiting.
  • It typically presents in male infants within the first several days to weeks of life and is generally not seen at the time of birth.

Option A: Candida esophagitis

  • It is characterized by whitish plaques in the oesophagus and associated discomfort while eating.
  • It is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, for example, those having a very low CD4 count secondary to HIV infection.

Option C: Esophageal cancer

  • A 10-day-old infant is the least likely candidate to have oesophagal cancer, as it is generally a disorder in older adults.
  • Projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped epigastric mass are also typically absent in oesophagal cancer cases.

Option D: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

  • It can present with a burning sensation or discomfort, particularly after meals.
  • It is also an adult disease and is generally seen in obese individuals.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and painful, stiff joints for one month. She has no significant medical or surgical history. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor and jaundice. Her vitals are within normal limits. Investigation findings include anaemia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with increased reticulocyte count. Direct Coombs test is positive for C3d. The peripheral blood film is shown below. What is the most likely cause of this pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cold AIHA

  • This is the case of cold agglutinin haemolytic anaemia (cold AIHA), in which the patient presents with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and arthralgia for one month.
  • Examination findings of pallor and jaundice, along with the presenting complaints, indicate an ongoing haemolytic disorder mediated by cold temperature.
  • This is further confirmed by anaemia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased reticulocyte count on laboratory findings.
  • Positive direct Coombs test for C3d and marked agglutination of RBCs seen in the above picture on peripheral blood smear confirms the diagnosis.
  • Cold AIHA is an autoantibody-mediated disorder characterised by the destruction of RBCs by cold-mediated autoantibodies at cold ambient temperatures of 0–4°C resulting in abnormal complement activation leading to acute intravascular and extravascular Haemolysis.
  • Clinical symptoms result from binding IgM to red cells in vascular beds where the temperature may fall below 30°C, such as in exposed fingers, toes, and ears.

Option B: Warm AIHA

  • It is also an autoantibody-mediated disease characterised by the binding of heat-sensitive autoantibodies, instead of cold-mediated antibodies, to RBCs, leading to increased red cell destruction by phagocytes and reticuloendothelial systems.
  • This autoantibody reaction is usually triggered by body temperatures of ≥ 37°C/98.6°F, with peripheral blood smear showing abundant spherocytes.

Option C: Hemoglobinopathy

  • It is usually characterised by the abnormal structure of haemoglobin, which can be seen on peripheral blood smears in the form of sickle-shaped or rod-shaped RBCs, target cells with microspherocytes.
  • It includes haemoglobin C disease, haemoglobin Zurich, sickle cell anaemia, and thalassemia.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It is an inherited disease resulting in impaired glutathione regeneration, leading to increased susceptibility of RBCs to oxidative stress like infection, various drugs, and consumption of fava beans. This results in episodic hyperproliferative haemolytic anaemia.
  • Heinz bodies (small inclusions in RBCS containing precipitates of denatured haemoglobin) and bite cells are usually seen on peripheral blood smears.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with swelling of his left parotid gland and pain, especially during chewing. He had experienced ten such episodes lasting 10–15 days each in the previous 2 years. Physical examination revealed a swollen left parotid gland with local tenderness and erythema of the overlying skin. The immunological evaluation revealed an IgA level of less than 7 mg/dl. The remaining immunoglobulin IgE, IgM, and IgG were within normal limits. Which of the following is the most important risk about the given condition?

choices.text: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease
Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea
Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Option D: Anaphylactic reaction on blood transfusion

  • The given clinical features and laboratory investigations point towards Isolated IgA deficiency.
  • The normal range for IgA is 36–268 mg/dl.
  • Common immunodeficiency is caused by impaired differentiation of naïve B lymphocytes to IgA-producing plasma cells.
  • Affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA.
  • Most individuals with IgA deficiency disease are asymptomatic. Because IgA is the major antibody in external secretions, mucosal defences are weakened, and infections occur in the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts.
  • The symptomatic patient commonly presents with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea.
  • When IgA-deficient patients are transfused with blood containing normal IgA, some of these patients develop severe, even fatal, anaphylactic reactions because the IgA behaves like a foreign antigen (since the patients do not produce it and are not tolerant to it).

Option A: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease

  • IgA deficiency is the most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease.

Option B: Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea

  • IgA deficiency increases the risk of sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections.

Option C: Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

  • IgA-deficient patients have a high frequency of respiratory tract allergy and a variety of autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of low-grade fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and myalgias for the past 3 months.  On physical examination, she had oral ulcers and facial rash, as shown in the picture below.  Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosing this disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Leukocytosis

SLE

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs and is characterized by a vast array of auto-antibodies which cause injury mainly by deposition of immune complexes.
  • Leukocytosis is defined as an elevation in the leukocyte levels in the blood.  It is a feature of inflammatory reactions, especially in response to bacterial infections.
  • However, in SLE, instead of leukocytosis, leukopenia or lymphopenia is observed.  Therefore, leukocytosis is not a diagnostic criterion for SLE.
  • The diagnosis of SLE is made by the following clinical and immunological criteria:

Criteria (2012) for diagnosis of SLE:

Clinical manifestations

  • Skin
    • Acute, subacute cutaneous lupus (photosensitive, malar, maculopapular, bullous rash)
    • Chronic cutaneous lupus (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like, hypertrophic verrucous, chilblains)
  • Oral or nasal ulcers
  • Nonscarring Alopecia
  • Synovitis involving ≥ 2 joints characterized by tenderness, swelling and effusion
  • Serositis (pleurisy characterized by pleural rub or pain, pericarditis characterized by pericardial friction rub)
  • Renal
    • Persistent proteinuria ≥ 0.5 g/ 24 hours or RBC casts
  • Neurologic
