    • Seizures, psychosis, mononeuritis, myelitis, peripheral or cranial neuropathies, acute confusional state
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Leukopenia (< 4.0 x 109 cells/L) or Lymphopenia (< 1.5 x 109cells/L) on two or more occasions
  • Thrombocytopenia (< 100 x  109 cells/L)

Immunological manifestations

  • ANA > reference negative value
  • Anti-dsDNA antibody >reference, if by ELISA 2x reference
  • Anti-Sm antibody
  • Antiphospholipid (any of lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, anti-β glycoprotein I)
  • Low serum complement (C3, C4 or CH50)
  • Positive direct Coombs test in the absence of hemolytic anaemia

Option A: Oral ulcers

  • Oral ulcers and nasopharyngeal ulcers are common clinical findings seen in SLE patients and are part of the diagnostic criteria of SLE.

Option B: Psychosis

  • Psychosis is an important neurological complication of SLE and is a diagnostic criterion of SLE.

Option C: Discoid rash

  • Chronic lupus demonstrates discoid rash, panniculitis and other types of rashes which are important diagnostic criteria of SLE.

questions.text: A 42Yr old chronic smoker with a known case of COPD now has complaints of easy fatigability, and shortness of breath has worsened further. On examination, Spo2 is 89%, Dyspneic and tachycardiac. Bronchial Biopsy taken shows stratified squamous cells with underlying glands. Which of the following change is this?
questions.solution:
Option A: Metaplasia

Metaplasia

  • Normally in bronchi →pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is present.
  • In a chronic smoker, replaced by →stratified squamous epithelium.
  • This type of change in the epithelium is called Metaplasia.
  • The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous, as seen in smokers
  • *Metaplasia is a benign, reversible condition.

Option B: Anaplasia

  • The loss of the mature or specialized features of a cell or tissue, for example, a malignant tumor.
  • Grading is done depending on the degree of anaplasia.
  • A lack of differentiation is called Anaplasia (a hallmark of malignancy).

  • Features of Anaplasia: Pleomorphism, Tumor giant cells, Atypical mitoses, Loss of polarity

Option C: Dysplasia

  • The abnormal types of cells are present in a tissue in the pre-cancerous stage.
  • This means “disordered growth.”
  • Dysplastic cells may exhibit considerable pleomorphism and often contain large hyperchromatic nuclei with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.

Option D: Neoplasia

  • Neoplasia is a new uncontrolled growth of cells that is not physiological but pathological.
  •  When dysplastic changes are marked and involve the full thickness of the epithelium but the lesion does not penetrate the basement membrane; it is considered a preinvasive neoplasm.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 4 hours after the sudden onset of excruciating pain in his right calf. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The right foot is cold and pale, and palpation of the right posterior tibial artery shows no pulse. Muscle strength is 1/5, and the sensation to touch significantly decreases in the right lower extremity. His serum creatinine kinase concentration is elevated. Arterial duplex sonography shows absent blood flow distal to the right popliteal artery. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following sets of intracellular electrolyte concentrations are most likely to be found in this patient's right distal gastrocnemius muscle?


	
		
			 
			Na+
			K+
			Ca2+
		
		
			A
			↑
			↓
			Normal
		
		
			B
			↑
			↑
			↑
		
		
			C
			↓
			↑
			Normal
		
		
			D
			↓
			↓
			Normal
		
		
			E
			↑
			↓
			↑
questions.solution:
Option E: E

  • This constellation of changes is consistent with late limb ischemia a stage at which the muscle cells have been irreversibly damaged, and necrosis has begun.
  • Once the cells' supply of ATP is depleted, energy-dependent cellular functions decrease, including Na+/K+ ATPase activity and calcium efflux through the cell membrane, resulting in an increase in intracellular sodium and calcium with a decrease in potassium.
  • The release of cellular enzymes, as evidenced by this patient's elevated serum creatinine kinase, indicates cell lysis, which is a sign of irreversible cell injury. This patient's elevated serum creatinine kinase suggests the release of cellular enzymes, indicating cell lysis, which is a sign of late ischemia.
  • A similar pattern of electrolyte changes occurs in ischemic myocardial cells (e.g., due to myocardial infarction).

Option A: A

  • The constellation of increased sodium, decreased potassium, and normal calcium is consistent with acute cellular ischemia. Because ischemic muscle cells rely on anaerobic metabolism, they quickly deplete their supply of ATP, leading to lactic acidosis and early symptoms of limb ischemia.
  • The affected cells counteract this acidosis by activating sodium-hydrogen exchangers, causing intracellular sodium levels to rise.
  • Intracellular potassium levels also increase, but the mechanism is unknown. Mild muscle weakness, minimal sensory loss, and no paresthesia are expected in patients with acute limb ischemia, as neurons remain intact.
  • This patient, however, has pain, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis. Moreover, elevated serum creatine kinase levels are not expected because muscle cells are not yet irreversibly damaged in the acute phase of an ischemic event.

Option B: B

  • The constellation of increased sodium, potassium, and calcium is seen in reperfusion injury, of irreversibly damaged muscle. 
  • Reperfusion injury typically occurs hours to days after the blood supply is restored to an ischemic muscle and is mostly due to the generation of free radicals and intracellular calcium overload.
  • This patient, however, is at a prolonged stage of limb ischemia, and perfusion to the muscle has not yet been restored. Therefore, another set of findings is expected.

Option C: C

  • The constellation of decreased sodium, elevated potassium, and unaltered calcium is not consistent with any stage of ischemia.

Option D: D

  • The constellation of unaltered calcium and decreased sodium and potassium is not consistent with any stage of ischemia.

questions.text: A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cytochrome C

  • This patient has squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
  • Cytochrome C is a critical regulator of apoptosis present in the mitochondrial membrane.
  • It seeps out of mitochondrial pores and activates apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (APAF-1).
  • APAF-1 converts procaspase-9 to caspase-9, causing downstream caspases to be activated (cysteine proteases).
  • These effector caspases break various target proteins, such as endonucleases, nuclear proteins, and cytoskeletal proteins, to orchestrate the morphological and biochemical changes that occur during apoptosis.

Option A: Catalase

  • Catalases through reactive oxygen species can cause cell death but do not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: Cytokeratin

  • Cytokeratin is a protein found in epithelial cells.
  • It is not associated with apoptosis.

Option D: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase, through reactive oxygen species, can cause cell death but does not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents with a 6-day history of a painful sore on his left hand. Physical examination reveals a 0.6-cm abscess on the extensor surface of the left hand that drains a thick, purulent material. Diapedesis of leukocytes into and around this patient's infected wound occurs primarily at which of the following given anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
Option B: Post-capillary venules

  • The leukocyte migration through the vessel wall occurs through the post-capillary venules.

Leukocyte migration:

  • The process of leukocyte recruitment is the migration of the leukocytes through intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis.
  • Transmigration of leukocytes occurs mainly in post-capillary venules.
  • Chemokines act on the adherent leukocytes and stimulate the cells to migrate through interendothelial gaps toward the chemical concentration gradient, that is, toward the site of injury or infection where the chemokines are being produced.
  • Several adhesion molecules in the intercellular junctions between endothelial cells are involved in the migration of leukocytes.
  • These molecules include a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily called CD31 or PECAM-1 (platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule).
  • After traversing the endothelium, leukocytes pierce the basement membrane, probably by secreting collagenases and enter the extravascular space.
  • After leukocytes pass through, the basement membranes become continuous again.
  • The cells that have exited the vessel then migrate toward the chemotactic gradient created by chemokines and other chemoattractants and accumulate in the extravascular site.
  • The most telling proof of the importance of leukocyte adhesion molecules in the host inflammatory response is genetic deficiencies in these molecules, which result in increased susceptibility to bacterial infections

Option A: Lymphatic capillaries

  • The lymphatic capillaries return the excessive fluid leak out of vessels.
  • This prevents oedema formation.

Option C: Precapillary arterioles

  • The precapillary arterioles are intact during the inflammation.
  • There is no leukocyte diapedesis through this area.

Option D: Small dermal arteries

  • The arteries are not involved during the diapedesis.
  • Venules contain significant gaps that aid in migrating leukocytes out of vessels.

questions.text: An 82-year-old female presents with a 4-hour history of high fever, chills, and disorientation. Her blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals diffuse purpura on her upper arms and chest. Blood cultures are positive for Gram-negative organisms. Which of the following cytokines are involved in the pathogenesis of direct vascular injury with septic shock?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tumor necrosis factor

  • Septicemia (bacteremia) is the clinical condition in which bacteria are found in the circulation of the patient.

  • It can be suspected clinically, but the final diagnosis is made by culturing the organisms from the blood. In patients with endotoxic shock, lipopolysaccharide released from Gram-negative bacteria stimulates monocytes/macrophages to secrete large quantities of TNF (tumour necrosis factor).

Option A: Interferon-γ

  • Interferon-γ is the only member of type II interferon.

  • It induces and modulates an array of immune responses.

Option B: Transforming Growth Factor-β (TGFβ)

  • Transforming Growth Factor-β (TGFβ) is a secreted cytokine.

  • Transforming Growth Factor-β (TGFβ) plays an important role in angiogenesis, wound healing, and cancer.

Option C: Platelet-derived growth factor

  • Platelet-derived growth factor regulates cell growth and cell division.

  • It plays an important role in wound healing and in repairing damage to blood vessel walls.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents with persistent complaints of a dry cough for four weeks, which in turn was associated with intermittent fever and easy fatigue. Following a further medical history, he added that he experienced chest discomfort and difficulty breathing during exertion. The vitals examination of the patient reveals SpO2 = 92% in ambient air, heart rate = 110 beats/ min, and respiratory rate = 18 breaths/min. Radiological studies revealed symmetrical hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and a black bead cluster sign was observed. On the biopsy, there is a granuloma without a necrotic centre. It is typically seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sarcoidosis

  • This is a case of sarcoidosis in which the patient presents with complaints of persistent dry cough for weeks, which is associated with intermittent fever and easy fatigue. 
  • The patient also experienced chest discomfort and difficulty breathing during exertion.
  • Radiological studies revealed symmetrical hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and a black bead cluster sign was observed. On the biopsy, there is a granuloma without a necrotic centre which is suggestive of sarcoidosis.
  • In the granulomas of certain infectious organisms (more classically, mycobacterium tuberculosis), a combination of hypoxia and damage induced by free radicals leads to a central area of necrosis. Basically, it looks grainy and cheesy and is therefore called caseous necrosis.
  • Under the microscope, this necrotic material appears as amorphous, eosinophilic granular debris with a complete loss of cellular structure.
  • Granulomas in Crohn's disease, sarcoidosis and foreign body reactions tend not to have necrotic centres and are said to be non-caseous.
  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disorder known to involve the lungs and lymph nodes. The presentation with dry cough, intermittent fever, easy fatigue, chest discomfort, and symmetrical hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. The black bead cluster sign on imaging is a characteristic radiological finding in sarcoidosis.

Option A: Syphilis

  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease.
  • It is caused by a bacteria known as treponema pallidum.
  • It is transmitted via sexual intercourse.
  • Normal sexual intercourse is not the cause, but unprotected sexual intercourse done multiple times with different sex partners is usually the cause.
  • It is treated successfully with antibiotics.

Option C: Tuberculosis

  • Tuberculosis is the prototype of the granuloma­tous diseases
  • Granulomatous inflammation is a distinctive pattern of chronic inflammatory reaction characterized by focal accumulations of activated macrophages, which often develop an epithelial-like (epithelioid) appearance in tuberculosis.
  • Tuberculosis (TB) can also present with hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, but TB granulomas typically have a necrotic center (caseous necrosis), which distinguishes them from the non-necrotizing granulomas commonly seen in sarcoidosis.

Option D: Cat-scratch disease

  • The cat-scratch disease is a benign condition which is usually transmitted via cat bite, scratching or licking.
  • The lesions formed as a result of this infection usually have necrotizing granuloma formation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a high-grade fever and dizziness. Her blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. On examination, she does not have any significant physical findings. She has been using vaginal tampoons for more than 1 month. A diagnosis of toxic shock syndrome is made secondary to the superantigen component of the causative organism. Which of the following is most likely associated with superantigen bacterial product?

choices.text: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules
Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation
Binds to the CD4 + molecule causing T-cell activation
Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4 + lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Option B: Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation

Superantigens:

  • Superantigens (SAgs) are the most powerful T-cell mitogens ever discovered.
  • By simultaneously binding to the major histocompatibility class II molecule on the surface of antigen-presenting cells and the T cell receptor (TCR) on T cells, SAgs trigger a strong oligoclonal expansion of T cells and the release of massive amounts of proinflammatory cytokines.
  • Thus far, bacterial SAgs have been found in Streptococcus pyogenes (Group Streptococcus), Group C Streptococcus, Group G Streptococcus, several species of Staphylococcus, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, and Mycoplasma arthritidis.
  • Option A: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules
  • Bacterial superantigens have been implicated as a causative agent in several acute pathological conditions, including food poisoning, toxic shock associated with staphylococcal sepsis, shock syndrome, scalded skin syndrome, and scarlet fever.
  • A common feature of these diseases is massive systemic immune activation, as reflected by high serum levels of TNFα, IL-1, IL-6, and IFNγ.
  • Associated toxic shock is likely, at least partly, to be due to the excessive release of cytokines.

Option A: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules

  • Co-stimulatory molecules are a heterogenous group of cell surface molecules that act to amplify or counteract the initial activating signals provided to T cells from the T cell receptor (TCR) following its interaction with an antigen/major histocompatibility complex (MHC), thereby influencing T cell differentiation and fate.
  • The superantigens are not co-stimulatory molecules.

Option C: Binds to the CD4 + molecule causing T cell activation

  • Activation of CD4+ T cells occurs through the simultaneous engagement of the T-cell receptor and a co-stimulatory molecule (like CD28, or ICOS) on the T cell by the major histocompatibility complex (MHCII) peptide and co-stimulatory molecules on the APC.
  • Superantigens do not bind CD molecules.

Option D: Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4 + lymphocytes

  • Superantigens are not processed and hence not presented to the lymphocytes.
  • Rather, they bind TCR and MHC II and lead to massive activation of T cells.

questions.text: A few Doctors Without Borders physicians on a 6-month African village posting encounter a pale foreigner complaining of extreme fatigue since arrival. He's a diabetic on insulin with controlled bronchial asthma. Despite malaria prophylaxis, he struggles with food adjustment and erratic blood glucose. If suspecting a pharmacogenetic condition, what might explain his current state?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primaquine-induced hemolytic anaemia

Pharmacogenetics:

  • Pharmacogenetics deals with genetic variation in the expression of enzymes that metabolize drugs.
  • These genetic differences can cause a drug response to deviate from the expected response and increase the risk of side effects.
  • If the enzyme in question is responsible for the breakdown of a drug, the following effects are possible:
    • A hyperactive variant of the enzyme decreases the drug response.
    • A hypoactive variant of the enzyme can cause cumulative drug effects and thus increase the risk of side effects.
  • The reverse is true if the enzyme is responsible for the activation of a drug. E.g. CYP2D6 polymorphism 
    • There are hyperactive and hypoactive variants.
    • CYP2D6 is involved in the metabolism of many drugs (e.g., the breakdown of antiarrhythmics and tricyclic antidepressants; the activation of codeine).
    • Gender-specific differences in CYP2D6 have been observed (e.g., CYP2D6-mediated breakdown of beta-blockers (such as metoprolol) is greater among women).
  • Primaquine is an oxidant drug. It can cause hemolytic anaemia in subjects having a deficiency of the G6PD enzyme.
  • This condition is genetically determined.

Option A: Hypoglycemia by insulin

  • Hypoglycemia due to insulin can occur due to the following conditions:
  • Insulin excess
    • Accidental overdose of insulin or noninsulin drugs (e.g., sulfonylureas, meglitinides)
    • Wrongly timed medication
    • Drug interactions
    • Factitious disorder
  • Increased sensitivity to insulin
    • Weight loss
    • Increase in activity/exercise
  • Decreased insulin clearance
    • Renal failure

Option B: Tachycardia by albuterol

  • Tachycardia by albuterol is the dose-dependent adverse effect of Albuterol and can happen in any individual.

Option C: Metoclopramide-induced muscle dystonia

  • Metoclopramide is a D2 receptor antagonist and increases the resting tone, contractility, lower oesophageal sphincter tone, and motility and promotes gastric emptying.
  • It is used in diabetic and postoperative gastroparesis as an antiemetic and persistent GERD.
  • Metoclopramide disrupts central dopaminergic signalling. Thus it may produce rare movement disorders, such as acute dystonic reactions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. For further examination of the eyes, the doctor had to pick cycloplegic drops to ensure that the patient did not develop posterior synechiae; which of the following difference between hyoscine and atropine must the doctor remember well?

choices.text: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses
Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye
Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyoscine exerts depressant effects on the CNS at relatively low doses

  • This is a case of reactive arthritis in which the patient presents with complaints of redness of the eyes, frequent urinary tract infections and mild joint pain for two weeks. The patient further gives a history of dysuria and pelvic pain. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The above-mentioned clinical feature suggests reactive arthritis.
  • The diagnosis of reactive arthritis is usually made clinically.
  • For further examination of the eye, the doctor had to use cycloplegic drops.
  • To ensure the patient doesn't develop posterior synechia, the doctor must know that hyoscine exerts a depressant effect on the CNS at relatively low doses.

Option B: Hyoscine exerts more potent effects on the heart than on the eye

  • Hyoscine doesn’t exert more potent effects on the heart than on the eye.
  • It has a more potent effect on the eye and the secretory glands.

Option C: Hyoscine is longer acting

  • Hyoscine is a very short-acting drug.
  • Atropine is a long-acting drug.

Option D: Hyoscine has weaker anti-motion sickness activity

  • Hyoscine has a strong anti-motion sickness activity.
  • It is most commonly used to prevent motion sickness.
  • It can also be used for the reduction of saliva in the mouth.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the physician with muscle aches, irritability, and difficulty concentrating for 15 days. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. On probing, the patient says that due to a change in deadline at work, she has had less sleep and began worrying about completing work on time. Which of the following medicine will the doctor prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Option A: Propranolol

  • This scenario indicates that the patient has a short-term anxiety disorder.
  • Anxiety disorder is a mental health condition that hinders a person’s daily life. Short-term anxiety usually lasts from days to a few weeks.
  •  

  • Mechanism of action: Propranolol works by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors in the body, particularly beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. By doing so, it reduces the effects of adrenaline (epinephrine) and other stress hormones, which can contribute to anxiety symptoms.

  • Performance anxiety: Propranolol is often prescribed for performance anxiety, such as stage fright or public speaking anxiety. By blocking the physical symptoms of anxiety, such as trembling, rapid heartbeat, and sweating, propranolol can help individuals feel more calm and in control during stressful situations.

  • Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): Propranolol may be used off-label in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder, although it is less commonly prescribed for this condition compared to other medications specifically approved for anxiety disorders, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or benzodiazepines

  • Propranolol suppresses anxiety in short-term stressful situations, but this is due to peripheral rather than a specific central action.

Option B: Imipramine

  • It is a tricyclic anti-depressant that blocks norepinephrine and serotonin in the neuron.
  • Imipramine is used to elevate mood, improve mental alertness, and increase physical activity. Its abuse can cause blurred vision, urinary retention, constipation, and orthostatic hypotension. It isn't used very often for anxiety.

Option C: Fluoxetine

  • It is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that is used as an anti-depressant. It is also used in longer anxiety disorders, panic attacks, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and bulimia.
  • Fluoxetine can be addictive, depending upon the dosage. Abuse of fluoxetine can cause decreased sex drive, drowsiness, nausea, nervousness, and excessive sweating.

Option D: Tamsulosin

  • Tamsulosin is non-quinazoline 1 receptor antagonist. It is also used in the treatment of BPH.
  • Tamsulosin relaxes the muscle in the prostate and bladder, helping the urine to flow out easily. But it does not produce apoptosis. Its side effects include disturbance in cognitive functions.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden shortness of breath for one hour. He gives no history of any other abnormalities or any chronic illness. After further investigation and examinations, the patient is diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure. He is given intravenous digoxin in the emergency. A few minutes later, the patient developed an irregular pulse consistent with ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following monovalent cation would reverse the effects of toxicity of the drug involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Potassium

  • The patient in the case presented with acute onset of dyspnea and was diagnosed with acute compensated heart failure. He was given digoxin but soon developed toxicity and had ventricular arrhythmia. 
  • Digitalis is a cardiac glycoside that causes positive inotropic effects by acting on Na/K ATPase.
  • A monovalent cation (K+), potassium can undo a digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • Potassium and digitalis compete to bind on the same receptor present on Na+/K+ ATPase on the cell membrane.
  • Digitalis toxicity is exacerbated by hypokalemia and hypercalcemia.
  • Hyperkalemia decreases digitalis toxicity.
  • Acceleration of the storage of intracellular calcium appears to be responsible for abnormal automaticity induced by digitalis.
  • Hypercalcemia thus increases the chances of digitalis-induced arrhythmia.

Option A: Digibind antibodies

  • They are used in severe digitalis toxicity, which is characterized by neurological symptoms, nausea and anorexia.

Option B: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine can be used for digitalis-induced arrhythmia.
  • But this drug has a risk of causing heart block in such cases.

Option C: Magnesium

  • Mg2+ has the opposite effect as Ca2+. Therefore, hypomagnesemia increases the risk of arrhythmias, whereas increased magnesium levels reduce the risk.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male has come into your clinic complaining of an occipital headache. After examination, BP is elevated at about 170/90 mmHg, and the importance of starting medication immediately is explained. He mentions that he is a known diabetic but is not compliant with medication. Which of the following diuretics, if given, can cause metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acetazolamide

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, they enzyme which catalysis the formation of carbonic acid (H2CO3) from CO2 and H20 from H+ and HCO3-
  • Acetazolamide causes metabolic acidosis by reducing the absorption of bicarbonate ions from proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Thus, it increases the bicarbonate excretion by preventing its absorption and ultimately decreases the blood pH.

Option A: Indapamide

  • Indapamide is a type of thiazide diuretic; it causes contraction alkalosis by increasing the secretion of aldosterone in response to volume depletion caused by the diuresis effect of indapamide.
  • Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions by increasing H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, thus causing metabolic alkalosis.

Option B: Furosemide

  • Furosemide causes contraction alkalosis by increasing the secretion of aldosterone in response to volume depletion caused by the diuresis effect of furosemide.
  • Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions by increasing H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, thus causing metabolic alkalosis.

​​​​​​​

Option C: Hydrochlorthiazide

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic; it causes contraction alkalosis by increasing the secretion of aldosterone in response to volume depletion caused by the diuresis effect of hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Aldosterone increases the excretion of H+ ions by increasing H+ATPase activity on α-intercalated cells, thus causing metabolic alkalosis. ​​​​​​​

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female presents to the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing. She reports no associated cough or fever. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), her pulse is 120/min, her respiration rate is 28/min, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. A chest x-ray is shown below:



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Short-acting beta 2 agonists

  • This patient is most likely suffering from acute exacerbation of asthma. The management of acute exacerbation of asthma involves the use of short-acting beta 2 agonists like salbutamol.
  • Short-acting beta 2 agonist drugs are the drugs of choice for treating acute exacerbation of severe asthma. The management of asthma is summarised as follows:

Option B: Long-acting beta 2 agonist

  • Long-acting beta-agonists are a class of bronchodilator drugs with a long duration of action (≥ 12 hours).
  • Their onset of action is variable, which is quick for formoterol and longer for salmeterol.
  • These drugs are used for the long-term control of asthma and COPD symptoms. Usually administered via a nebuliser or metered-dosed inhaler.

Option C: Oral theophylline

  • Oral theophylline is used in the management of asthma. However, it has no role in the treatment of acute exacerbation of asthma.

Option D: Inhaled ipratropium bromide

  • These drugs are used in the treatment of COPD. However, these are not preferred for the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male, presenting with fatigue, pale appearance, yellow conjunctiva, black stools, history of hepatitis, and alcoholism, was diagnosed with bleeding esophageal varices via upper GI endoscopy. What's the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
Option B: Octreotide

  • This is a case of upper GI bleeding. The tube that connects the throat to the stomach is the oesophagus, and varices are large or swollen veins.
  • When a clot or scar tissue in the liver blocks normal blood flow to the liver, oesophageal varices can form. Blood enters smaller arteries, which are not intended to carry high amounts of blood, to circumvent the blockages. The blood vessels have the potential to burst, causing life-threatening bleeding.
  • The goal of treatment is to avoid liver injury, stop bleeding from varices, and stop bleeding if it has already started.

  • Octreotide considerably lowers intravesical pressure and inhibits blood flow to the portal system by restricting the splanchnic arterioles. So, it is the drug of choice.
  • Variceal ligation conducted with an endoscope and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) performed by a radiologist is two alternative non-surgical methods for stopping variceal haemorrhage.
  • Side effects of this drug are either local or gastrointestinal, including anorexia, vomiting, nausea and diarrhoea.

Option A: Terlipressin

  • Terlipressin is an endogenous vasoconstrictor neurohormone that is a synthetic counterpart of vasopressin.
  • The indication is that terlipressin is a vasopressin receptor agonist indicated to improve kidney function in adults with hepatorenal syndrome with a rapid reduction in kidney function.
  • Terlipressin copies the effects of endogenous vasopressin, but it displays an increase in selectivity for the V1 receptor and a longer half-life than vasopressin.
  • Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as endogenous vasopressin, controls vital physiological processes such as osmotic balance, blood pressure control, sodium homeostasis, and kidney function.

Option C: Propranolol

  • Beta-blockers are a class of medications that includes propranolol. It helps with anxiety, treats cardiac issues, and shields against migraines.
  • Propranolol is generally safe to take by adults and most kids 12 and older. However, treating high blood pressure in children under 12 has not received formal approval.

Option D: Clonidine

  • Clonidine pills (Catapres) can be taken alone or with other drugs for treating high blood pressure.
  • Clonidine belongs to the group known as centrally-acting alpha-agonist hypotensive agents.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient with heart failure currently on digoxin therapy presents to the emergency department with blurred vision and yellow-green distortion. The plasma digoxin level is 4 ng/ml(normal 0.8- 2.0). Renal function is normal; this patient's plasma t1/2 for digoxin is 1.6 days. How long should digoxin be withheld to reach a safer yet probably therapeutic level of 1 ng/ml?
questions.solution:
• The patient has digitalis toxicity as the digoxin serum levels are high, and he's experiencing visual disturbances.
  • Elimination of digoxin follows first-order kinetics, i.e. the constant fraction of drugs is eliminated per unit of time, and the half-life remains constant.
  •  The time required to decrease the plasma concentration of digoxin from 4 ng/ml to 1 ng/ml will take approximately two half-lives (From 4 ng/ml to 2 ng/ml in one half-life and from 2 ng/ml to 1 ng/ml in second half-life). Thus, the time required will be two × t½, i.e., two × 1.6 = 3.2 days.
  • Half-life is the time required to change the drug in the body by half during elimination. For drugs following first-order kinetics, the clearance and plasma half-life remains constant.
  • In such drugs, nearly complete drug elimination occurs in 4-5 half-lives.
Number of half-lives 1 2 3 4
Percentage of drug remaining 50% 25% 12.5% 6.25%

questions.text: A 29-year-old female is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fever, palpitations, abdominal pain and diarrhoea for the past few hours. On examination, the patient had tremors and profuse sweating since she arrived. ECG revealed Atrial fibrillation. A diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. Which of the following anti-thyroid medications should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Propylthiouracil

  • A thyroid storm is also known as a thyrotoxic crisis.
  • It is a life-threatening condition caused by the excessive release of thyroid hormones in individuals with thyrotoxicosis.
  • The cause of thyroid storm is inadequate treatment for hyperthyroidism, untreated overactive thyroid gland and infection associated with hyperthyroidism.
  • Surgery, trauma, acute illness, burns, medication side effects etc., are precipitating factors that can also result in this condition.
  • The symptoms of thyroid storm are similar to hyperthyroidism.
  • It includes tachycardia, fever, profuse sweating, poor feeding and weight loss, agitation, restlessness, anxiety, diarrhoea etc.
  • The treatment of thyroid storm consists of supportive therapy, which includes intravenous (IV) fluids for dehydration, oxygen, cooling blankets to return body temperature to normal and acetaminophen.
  • Treat the underlying precipitating factor.
  • Antithyroid medication like Propylthiouracil is given to lower the hormone levels in the blood. It is the drug of choice for thyroid storms because it has an early onset of action and the capacity to inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

Option A: Thiocyanates

  • Thiocyanates are not used in the treatment of thyroid storm.

Option C: Propranolol

  • Propranolol is used to minimize sympathomimetic symptoms.
  • It is a life-saving drug used for cases of thyroid storm.

Option D: Radioactive iodine

  • Radioiodine therapy can be a definitive therapy for thyroid storm once symptoms improve.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes into the outdoor patient department with the presenting complaints of increased hunger and thirst. On testing, it is noted that he has elevated blood sugar levels. Owing to the patient’s financial condition, it is decided to prescribe him sulfonylurea. Glibenclamide is preferred over Chlorpropamide in the treatment because the latter is more likely to cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Alcohol intolerance

  • A sulfonylurea of the first generation is known as chlorpropamide. It accomplishes this by blocking K+ channels in the membrane of pancreatic beta cells, which results in the depolarization of the cell and, ultimately, the release of insulin due to an increase in the inflow of calcium.
  • Hangover-like symptoms, as well as nausea, vomiting, flushing, dizziness, and headaches, are hallmarks of alcohol intolerance and reactions similar to those caused by disulfiram.
  • The accumulation of acetaldehyde in the blood as a result of the inhibition of hepatic aldehyde dehydrogenases is the root cause of this condition.
  • Metronidazole (an antibiotic), Abacavir (an anti-viral), cefoperazone (an antibiotic), and chlorpropamide are the primary medicines that are responsible for this side effect (anti-diabetic).
  • .Another potential adverse reaction to this treatment is cholestatic jaundice, which manifests clinically as an unusually elevated level of hepatic Alkaline Phosphatase in comparison to AST and ALT levels.
  • Additionally, it creates increased ADH, which stands for severe inappropriate antidiuretic hormone, and this condition manifests as euvolemic hyponatremia (average amount of body fluids with low sodium).

Increase Insulin

Sulfonylureas

Meglitinides

1st Generation :

  • Chlorpropamide
  • Tolbutamide
  • Nateglinide
  • Repaglinide

2nd generation:

  • Glipizide
  • Glicanide
  • Glibenclamide
  

Option A: Lactic Acidosis

  • Lactic acidosis is the high amount of lactic acid accumulation in the body. The main drug that can cause it among anti-diabetics is Metformin.

Option C: Pancreatitis

  • Pancreatitis is defined as inflammation of the pancreas. It usually presents itself as epigastric pain that radiates to the back. The main drugs that cause it among anti-diabetes are GLP-1 analogues.

Option D: Urinary Tract Infection 

  • Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are infections of the urinary tract. The main drugs that cause it among the anti-diabetics include Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors.

questions.text: What would you warn the patient about before starting carbamazepine in the case of trigeminal neuralgia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hyponatremia

  • Carbamazepine causes an increase in antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which leads to abnormal sensitivity of the renal tubules to ADH activity.
  • This causes increased expression of aquaporin 2 channels in the renal tubules.
  • Therefore, carbamazepine can cause hyponatremia.
  • Carbamazepine is the DOC for focal seizures and trigeminal neuralgia
  • Carbamazepine is used for
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Bipolar disorder
  • Carbamazepine's adverse effects are:-
    • Release of ADH (leading to dilutional hyponatremia), especially in the elderly.
    • Agranulocytosis
    • Aplastic anaemia

 

Option B:  Hypokalemia

  • Carbamazepine causes the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which leads to low sodium, not low potassium.

 

Option C: Hyperkalemia

  • Beta-blocker overdose can cause hyperkalemia by inhibiting potassium entry into cells.
  • Carbamazepine does not cause hyperkalemia

Option D: Hypernatremia

  • Carbamazepine causes the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), which leads to hyponatremia, not hypernatremia.

questions.text: A 36-year old female patient is evaluated for gram negative septicemia. The patient’s medical records reveals that she has earlier experienced an episode of anaphylaxis leading to shock after the administration of penicillin V. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aztreonam

  • In a patient with severe sensitivity to Penicillin, all beta-lactams are contraindicated as they can cause a life-threatening reaction
  • Monobactams can be used instead of beta-lactams in this case as they lack the thiazole ring of Beta lactams and are safe to use if there is a contraindication to beta-lactams.
  • Aztreonam and imipenem are effective for gram-negative infections. However, as the patient is allergic to beta-lactams, carbapenems show cross allergy and are contraindicated in people with beta-lactam allergy. So Aztreonam is preferred in such a patient.​​​​​​​

Option A: Ampicillin plus sulbactam

  • Ampicillin is a beta-lactam which can cause a life-threatening infection again in this patient, so it is contraindicated

Option C: Cefazolin

  • Cefazolin is a cephalosporin and is a beta-lactam, so it cannot be administered to this patient with evidence of beta-lactam allergic reaction

Option D: Imipenem plus cilastatin

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem, and carbapenems have shown cross-allergy in patients with a beta-lactam allergy, so it is also contraindicated in this case

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presented with complaints of fever and headache that had lasted for 2 days, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The condition was diagnosed as meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis and treated. 4months later the patient again acquired a Neisserial infection. The increased susceptibility of this patient to meningococcal disease is probably due to?
questions.solution:
Neisserial infection are associated with Deficiency of late complements.
1

C1-C4 (early complements) deficiencies - SLE, glomerulonephritis ,pyogenic infections
2

Deficiency of C5- C9 (Membrane attack complex)( late components) of the complement — show increased susceptibility to meningococcal disease.

questions.text: A patient is having thick, gray coating on the throat and tonsils, followed with fever, chills and swollen glands in the neck. Microscopic examination of nasopharyngeal or pharyngeal swab showed gram positive organism with a special stain. What are the constitutes of the stain?

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid
Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.solution:
• The constitutes of the stain are Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid.
  • The clinical scenario given in the question is suggestive of diphtheria.
  • Gram positive organism causing gray colored coating (pseudomembrane) is Corynebacterium diphtheriae .
  • So, the specific stain is Albert stain: To demonstrate metachromatic granules (Volutin, Babes Ernst, polar bodies) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Contents of Albert stain:-

  • Albert stain is made up of two staining solutions:
  • Stain A- glacial acetic acid, malachite green, toluidine blue
    Stain B- Iodine and Potassium iodide in water

1: Crystal violet, Gram's iodine: used in Gram staining.

3, 4: Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue: Used in ZN staining (Refer to the image below).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of abdominal cramps along with diarrhoea associated with mucus for 4 days. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The treating physician wants to process the stool culture for the isolation of Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the following is a correct growth requirement for the organism involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Incubate at 42ºC, microaerophilic

  • This is a case of acute gastroenteritis in which the patient presents with abdominal cramps along with diarrhoea associated with mucus for 4 days.
  • It is caused by Campylobacter jejuni.
  • Campylobacter jejuni is a microaerophile, i.e. it needs only 5% O2. It grows at 42ºC.

Causative agents of predominantly dysentery:

  • Shigella species
  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Enteroinvasive E. coli
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Causative agents of predominantly inflammatory diarrhoea:

  • Salmonella species
  • Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Aeromonas hydrophila
  • Plesiomonas shigelloides

Characteristics of Campylobacter jejuni:

  • Motile gram-negative bacteria.
  • It is associated with poultry bird product contamination.
  • Gull wing-shaped bacteria.
  • Motile
  • Causes inflammatory diarrhoea - Fecal leucocytes are present
  • In children, C. jejuni leads to Guillain Barre syndrome.
  • Cultures did on Charcoal based media:
  • Campy bap
  • Bitzler
  • Skirrow→ incubate at 42oC

Option A: Incubate at 37ºC, microaerophilic

  • Campylobacter jejuni is microaerophilic.
  • But it doesn't incubate at 37ºC.
  • It incubates at 42ºC.

Option C: 5% CO2 is required

  • It doesn't require 5% carbon dioxide.
  • It only requires 5% oxygen.

Option D: Incubate at 37ºC and 10% capnophilic

  • Campylobacter jejuni is not capnophilic.
  • It is a microaerophile.
  • It incubates at 42ºC, not at 37ºC.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the paediatrician with complaints of fever and a sharp cough for 1 week. He gives no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals mild conjunctivitis with some pus. An x-ray chest of the patient was done, which confirmed pneumonia. No organisms are seen on the Gram stain of the pus. What is the most likely causative agent in this case?

choices.text: An obligate intracellular organism unable to make its own ATP
A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness as well as the pneumonia
An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer
An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium

questions.solution:
Option A: An obligate intracellular organism unable to make its own ATP

  • This is a case of pneumonia along with mild conjunctivitis, most likely due to chlamydia trachomatis, in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and a sharp cough for 1 week.
  • This obligate intracellular organism is unable to make its own ATP.

Predisposing factors for pneumonia:

  • Extremes of age
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Chronic bronchitis
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Congestive heart failure
  • IV drugs users, alcoholics, seizure disorder:

Clinical Manifestations Symptoms:

    • Cough with sputum
    • Fever with chills
    • Chest pain
    • Shortness of Breath
    • Rusty sputum
    • Currant Jelly sputum

Option B: A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness as well as the pneumonia

  • A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness, as well as pneumonia, is most like Gonococcus.
  • It should have been eliminated on Gram stain, and most would have been intracellular but not in phagosomes.

Option C: An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer

  •  An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer is most likely mycoplasma, which is not intracellular and rarely causes pneumonia in neonates.

Option D: An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium

  • An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium would be Rickettsia, which is both unlikely and not a good fit for the disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who has had HIV for 2 years and has a CD4 count of 150 cells//µL presents with the complaint of fatigue, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is also complaining of chest tightness on breathing. The patient says that the symptoms are getting worse every day. The doctor ordered sputum microscopy. The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain of his sample showed black-coloured cysts, as shown in the image below. Select the true statement about the pathogen causing the above-mentioned disease as shown in the image.

choices.text: Ampicillin is the drug of choice
Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A: Stain : - Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS)

The given image shows Pneumocystis jirovecii

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii) causes PCP (Pneumocystis pneumonia)
  • It most commonly infects HIV patients (with CD4+ cell count below 200/µL) and patients on long-term immunosuppressive regimens.
  • It mostly affects only immunocompromised individuals.
  • Patients with hematologic and non-hematologic malignancies.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiographs show perihilar haziness with diffuse mottling.
  • Sputum induced by inhalation of a hypertonic saline solution is a useful specimen for microscopic demonstration of the organism.
  • Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black-coloured crushed ping-pong balls against the green background.
  • Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for Pneumocystis pneumonia.

Image: The spore cases (cysts) of pneumocystis stained with the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain.

Other Options

Option B: Ampicillin is the drug of choice

  • The drug of choice for pneumocystis jirovecii is amphotericin B.
  • Ampicillin is the drug of choice in infections caused by a beta-lactamase-negative type of H. influenza, enterococci, and L. monocytogenes.

Option C: Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

  • It usually occurs in patients with a CD4+ count below 200/µL.
  • Recurrent bacterial pneumonia occurs when CD 4 count is 200-500/ µL.

Option D: Diagnosed on X-Ray imaging

  • This disease is most commonly diagnosed through sputum microscopy.
  • The X-ray can show consolidation, but diagnosis is confirmed by sputum culture,

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of eye pain for 5 days. She gave a history of using contact lenses which she usually stores in tap water. After a complete evaluation, a diagnosis of severe retinitis was made. If we culture the water she was using for contact lens storage and the vitreous, the probable pathogen that can be isolated would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option D: Acanthamoeba

  • This is a case of retinitis in which the patient presents with complaints of severe eye pain.

  • It is caused by acanthamoeba.

  • Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba.

  • Acanthamoeba is commonly isolated from contact lens fluid and patients with retinitis who do not store their lenses under sterile conditions.

  • Causes of contact lens keratitis·:

    • Aerosol route → Lungs → Hematogenous spread → Brain → Granulomatous Encephalitis

    • Spread can occur even though the Optic route

Lab diagnosis:

CSF Examination:

  • Cysts & Trophozoites are seen

  • lymphocytes are present

  • Acanthamoeba can be grown on non-nutrient agar plates using Escherichia coli as a food source.

Other Options

Option A: Naegleria

  • Naegleria fowleri is a parasite that lives in the soil.

  • It can cause primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.

Option B: Pneumocystis

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii can cause pnemocystic pneumonia.

  • Its symptoms include productive cough, shortness of breath, and fever.

Option C: Babesia

  • Babesia is a tiny parasite that causes babesiosis.

  • Babesiosis is a life-threatening infection of red blood cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female from a rural area presents to OPD for a follow-up visit after she had a recent history of compound leg fracture. She now has signs of acute appendicitis and is taken to surgery. When her appendix is removed, it contains light-coloured, 20.5-cm long roundworm and bile-stained eggs. Her features are consistent with Ascaris. How does she probably acquire this infection?

choices.text: Ingestion of water containing filariform larvae
Ingestion of food contaminated with the eggs

questions.solution:
Option D: Ingestion of food contaminated with the eggs

  • Human infection is acquired through ingesting food contaminated with embryonated eggs.

  • The clinical scenario and microscopic features of the egg are indicative of Ascaris.

  • Embryonated Ascaris eggs released in faeces may contaminate food or water, which is then consumed. Ascaris do not attach to the intestine but maintains their position by mobility.

  • The worm may become hypermotile (e.g., during febrile periods, anaesthetic use, or antibiotic use) and migrate into the appendix or bile duct.

  • Habitat of ascaris adult worm: Jejunum / upper ileum

Ascaris causes:

  • Intussusception → Intestinal obstruction

  • Strongly associated with Loeffler's syndrome → Massive eosinophilia

Egg of Ascaris:

  • Bile stained

  • Unsegmented ovum

  • Eggs with rugosity

  • The image below: Fertilised egg of Ascaris

  • Image below: Unfertilised egg of Ascaris

Option A: Ingestion of water containing filariform larvae

  • Infection of Ascaris in humans is not acquired through ingestion of water contaminated with filariform larvae.

  • The ingested larvae cannot mature into free-living adults and must find a new host to continue the life cycle.

  • In contrast, embryonic eggs are swallowed and hatched in the small intestine. They subsequently develop into filariform larvae, which go into the lungs and result in eosinophilia.

Option B: Skin penetration by filariform larvae.

  • The filariform larvae can penetrate through the skin but don't cause infectivity.

  • From there, they travel through the bloodstream and lymphatic to the lungs, which are eventually coughed up and ingested.

  • They mature into adult female larvae, incapable of infectivity without male larvae.

Option C: Skin penetration by rhabditiform larvae

  • Rhabditiform larvae cannot penetrate through the skin.

  • They develop into filariform larvae which are capable of penetrating through the skin.

  • Infection of Ascaris in humans is acquired through ingestion of food contaminated with embryonated eggs.

questions.text: A 52-year-old African-American woman presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and icterus for 3 weeks. On history taking, she was found to be an IV drug user. On molecular examination of the sample, a single-stranded enveloped RNA virus was found to be the causative agent. Which of the following statements is associated with the given condition?

choices.text: Hepatitis B is the causative agent
The most common indication for liver transplant
Does not cause co-infection with Hepatitis B

questions.solution:
Option B: The most common indication for liver transplant

Hepatitis C Virus

  • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) is a single-stranded enveloped RNA virus, and it’s the most likely causative agent in this scenario.
  • HCV belongs to the family Flaviviridae.
  • HCV infection is seen only in humans.
  • Incubation Period: 15-160 days, with a mean of 50 days.

Clinical Presentation

  • It may present with fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera, dark coloured urine.
  • About 20% of people develop acute hepatitis. Acute illness is mild and anicteric.
  • About 75-80% directly develop the chronic disease; out of which:
    • 60-70% develop Chronic hepatitis.
    • 5-20% develop Cirrhosis.
    • 1-5% develop Hepatocellular Carcinoma. (HCV accounts for 25% of total liver cancer patients.)

Transmission

  • Infection is mainly by blood transfusion and other modes of contact with blood and blood products.
  • IV Drug abusers, transplant recipients, and immunocompromised patients are at high risk.
  • It can also spread via sexual contact.
  • Infection may spread from mother to baby. (Vertical transmission)

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • The standard method of identification is Antibody Detection via ELISA
  • PCR for HCV RNA is the most specific and sensitive.

Prophylaxis

  • There’s no vaccine available.
  • It can be prevented generally by avoiding the usage of used IV needles and direct contact with blood or blood products.

Treatment

  • Interferon alpha, alone or in combination with antiviral like Ribavirin.

Indications for Liver Transplant

  • Any metabolic diseases or infection that leads to acute or chronic liver failure and hepatic malignancies are the indications for a liver transplant.
  • The most common indication for liver transplantation is Cirrhosis due to chronic Hepatitis C infection.

Option A: Hepatitis B is the causative agent

  • Hepatitis B is the only DNA virus among Hepatitis viruses.
  • Hence it cannot be the causative agent.
  • Hepatitis C is an RNA-enveloped virus.

Option C: Does not cause liver cancer

  • 1-5% of patients infected with HCV develop Hepatocellular Carcinoma. (HCV accounts for 25% of total liver cancer patients).
  • HCV is one of the most important causative factors for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D: Does not cause co-infection with Hepatitis B

  • HCV may cause co-infection with HBV and co-infection with HCV.
  • HBV increases the rate of development of Cirrhosis and the risk of HCC compared with infection with either virus alone.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy living in rural India had a history of cowpox infection. His sister's rash on the skin turned into a fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center. On history taking, the patient says it was just nausea, vomiting, and fever in the beginning. Later, she started having ulcers in the mouth and a rash that turned into blisters. The doctor suspected it was a contagious viral infection. The strange thing, in this case, is that the boy who is her brother, despite coming in contact with his sister multiple times, was not infected. The boy's protection from this disease by the previous infection is due to the?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antigenic cross-reactivity

The protection against smallpox by previous infection with cowpox represents antigenic cross-reactivity.

  • The above given is a case of smallpox. The fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center is characteristic of smallpox.
  • The initial mouth ulcer followed rash; eventually, blisters are a classical pattern for smallpox.
  • Antigenic cross-reactivity- Sometimes single antigen stimulates the production of various antibodies that more or less resemble the correct fit for the antigen.
  • Each of these antibodies may attack different antigens that more or less resemble one another.
  • Cross Reactivity: The ability of an individual antibody combining site to react with more than one antigenic determinant.
  • The ability of a population of antibody molecules to react with more than one Ag.

Option B: Activation Of B cell

  • Lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system.
  • Both T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes come under the same banner of the adaptive immune system.
  • Activation of B lymphocytes by T-lymphocytes leads to maturation of B-cell into plasma cells and antibodies formation from plasma.

Option C: Passive immunity

  • This immunity is conferred by the transfer of serum or lymphocytes from a specifically immunized individual.

Option D:Innate immunity

  •  It is the resistance that an individual possesses by birth.
  • It is not specific and is the first line of defense against pathogens.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the outpatient department physician because of a sore throat, dry cough, headache, and runny nose for the past three days. During this period, His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), his pulse is 80/min, and his blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination of the throat shows erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. A swab was taken and inoculated into a suitable liquid culture medium, and the bacterium's growth was plotted. In a bacterial growth curve, in which phase is the maximum cell size obtained?
questions.solution:
Option B: End of lag phase

  • Maximum cell size is obtained at the end of the lag phase.

Option A, C, and D:

Phases of bacteria growth curve:

 

Lag phase

Log phase

Stationary phase 

Decline phase

Bacteria divide

No

Yes

Yes

No

Bacterial death

No

No

Yes

Yes

Total count

Flat

Raises

Raises

Flat

Viable count

Flat

Raises

Flat

Falls

Special features

1. Preparatory phase

2. Accumulation of enzymes and metabolites

3. Attains maximum size at the end of the lag phase

1. Uniformly stained,

2. Metabolically active

3. Small size

1. Gram variable

2. Produce: Granules, spores, an exotoxin, antibiotics, bacteriocin

1. Produce involution forms

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has been brought in for admission in a semiconscious state. She was found by her roommate in her hostel room with some bottles of alcohol and some drugs by her side. On observation, the patient's hands were seen moving in a pill-rolling pattern. Occasionally she was also threading imaginary needles.This is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Datura poisoning:

  • Carphologia is seen in Datura poisoning.
  • Typical pill-rolling movements, Pull imaginary threads from fingertips, Threads imaginary needles can be seen.
  • Other signs and symptoms: Dry mouth, irrelevant slurred speech, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils.
  • Treatment: Physostigmine is the drug of choice.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Digitalis poisoning:

  • Toxic symptoms are due to overdose or by a cumulative action.
  • In Digitalis poisoning: Nausea, vomiting, pain in the abdomen, burning sensation, diarrhea, Bradycardia, CNS Headache, fatigue, confusion, anxiety, depression, disorientation, drowsiness, hallucinations, delirium, Transient amblyopia, blurring, photophobia, Urticaria can be seen.
  • The patient becomes drowsy and the condition may deepen into coma. Convulsions may precede death. Death occurs from cardiovascular collapse

Option C - LSD overdose:

  • Signs and symptoms (Acute intoxication) of LSD:
    • Somatic or physical: Dizziness, dilated pupils, nausea, flushing, hyperthermia, paresthesia, hyperactive reflexes and tremors.
    • Perceptual: Altered changes in vision and hearing, like floating feeling, illusions, sensation of synesthesia, i.e., 'seeing' smells and 'hearing' colors.
    • Psychic or changes in sensorium: Delusional ideation, body distortion, suspiciousness to the point of toxic psychosis, depersonalization, and loss of sense of time.

Option D - Alcohol withdrawal:

  • Tremulousness or shakes or jitters (most common sign), weakness, pain in the muscle, cold sweat, insomnia, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, restlessness, exaggerated reflexes, raised temperature, fluctuating BP, hallucinations, loss of memory, and delirium tremens.

questions.text: The case that is being followed by the entire community is that of a young man who has claimed his rightful property. He alleges that he is the posthumous child of the late owner of a bungalow in that town. The court has begun an investigation into the matter. While claiming to be a posthumous child, he is claiming to be?

choices.text: Child delivered after death of his mother.
Child delivered after death of biological father
Born after death of both parents

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Child delivered after death of biological father:

  • Posthumous child is one who is born after the death of his/her father.

Incorrect options:

Option A,C,D are incorrect due to the above given reason

questions.text: A 52-year-old man who had been diagnosed with Young Onset Parkinson's disease reported back for a follow-up visit. He informed the doctor that he had taken the medication regularly and has experienced an improvement in his symptoms. His tremors and rigidity had noticeably decreased but one complaint he had was that his sexual desire had increased. What is an excessive sexual desire in men termed as?
questions.solution:
Option B: Satyriasis

  • Morbid, insatiable sexual need or desire in a man.

Option A: Nymphomania

  • Nymphomania: Abnormal, excessive, insatiable desire in a woman for sexual intercourse.

Option C:Frigidity

  • Frigidity: It is the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females (absence of desire for sexual intercourse or incapacity to achieve orgasm).

Option D: Fetishism

  • Transvestic/ Fetishism/ Eonism
  • It is a disorder characterized by recurrent, intense, sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges or behaviors involving cross-dressing.

questions.text: Iran has returned the body of the 35-year-old man who was executed on charges of drug trafficking. The body has been embalmed prior to repatriation. Although it is usually still possible to identify the presence of drugs, the constituent chemicals in embalming fluids affect not only the detection but also the rate of decay of the majority of both pharmaceutical and illicit drugs in blood and many other bodily tissues, making forensic evidence unsafe and, therefore, usually inadmissible in courts of law. Which tissue sample will the forensic team prefer in this case for toxicological analysis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Skeletal muscle

  • In the embalmed body the best specimen may be skeletal muscle from the buttock.

Option A: Bile

  • It is best removed by puncturing the gall bladder in situ. Narcotic drugs, cocaine, methadone, glutathione, barbiturates and some tranquilisers.

Option B: Vitreous

  • Alcohol, chloroform, cocaine, morphine, tricyclic antidepressants.

Option-C : Spinal cord

  • Spinal cord entire length: strychnine and gelsemium.

questions.text: A 26 yrs. old patient presented to ER after five days of alleged ingestion of rodenticide used for pest control at farms. Clinical manifestations seen were abdominal pain and Luminous vomiting followed by a depressed sensorium. Features of acute liver failure including coagulopathy were present. ER doctor confirmed it is a case of Smoky stool syndrome. Smoky stool syndrome is characteristically seen in poisoning with?
questions.solution:
Phosphorus

  • Smoky stool syndrome is characteristically seen in poisoning with Phosphorus. Clinical manifestations include abdominal pain and Luminous vomiting followed by a depressed sensorium. Features of acute liver failure including coagulopathy were present.

Iodine

  • Inhalation produces glottic and pulmonary edema. Swallowed in the solid form, it acts as an acid corrosive poison. There is burning pain extending from the mouth to the stomach, intense thirst, salivation, vomiting, purging, giddiness, cramps or convulsive movements of the limbs, and fainting.
  • The urine is scanty or suppressed, red-brown in color, and contains albumen; metabolic acidosis, nephritis, and renal failure occur. Pulse is slow and weak, skin cold and clammy and there may be skin rashes.
  • Chronic Poisoning (Iodism): The symptoms are pain over the frontal sinus, running of the nose, conjunctivitis, bronchial catarrh, salivation, nausea, vomiting, purging, emaciation, lymphadenopathy, parotid swelling (iodide mumps), wasting of breasts, testes, etc. and acne or erythematous patches on the skin, urticaria, etc.
  • Iodine rarely causes poisoning, but cases may occur from overdose and idiosyncrasy. Iodine is converted to an iodide ion in the body. The normal iodide content of the blood is 2 to 5mg./100 ml.

Bromine

  • Bromine: Non-metallic, inorganic irritants. Bromine causes necrosis of the skin and tissues.
  • Certain people are sensitive to certain drugs and even articles of diet. Iodine, bromine, opium, belladonna, cocaine, aspirin, penicillin, and mercury are common examples of drugs to which many people are allergic.
  • Chronic Bromide poisoning (Bromism): Skin rashes in the form of red papules (Bromine rash), similar to acne vulgaris, which may transform into a pustular lesion/ ulcerate at the hair roots (Bromoderma), on the face, neck, and upper part of the chest.

Learning Objective

Signs and Symptoms of acute phosphorus poisoning

  • Garlicky odour.
  • Luminous vomit and stool because of the presence of phosphorus.
  • Fumes emanate from the stools (smoking or smoky stool syndrome).
  • Acute poisoning causes liver cell necrosis, fatty liver and acute yellow atrophy.

Chronic Phosphorus Poisoning (Phossy Jaw/Glass Jaw/Lucifer’s Jaw):

  • Due to inhalation of fumes over years.
  • Toothache (earliest symptom) & swelling of the jaw.
  • Loosening of the teeth &Necrosis of the lower jaw.
  • Sequestration of bone in the mandible & multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

questions.text: First, add a few crystals of ferrous sulfate to 5 ml of gastric aspirate. Then, add 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. Boil the mixture and then allow it to cool. Afterward, add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid. If the solution turns a 'greenish-blue color,' this indicates the presence of cyanide in the aspirate. What is the name of this bedside test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lee Jones Test:

  • The Lee Jones Test is a bedside test used to detect the presence of cyanide in gastric aspirate.

  • Proceedure:

    • Add a few crystals of ferrous sulfate to 5 ml of gastric aspirate.
    • Add 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide.
    • Boil the mixture and then allow it to cool.
    • Finally, add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid.

  • If the solution turns a "greenish-blue color," it indicates the presence of cyanide in the gastric aspirate. This test is a rapid and simple way to assess whether cyanide poisoning may be a factor in a patient's condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Marquis Test:

  • The Marquis Test is a different chemical test used to identify the presence of various drugs, including opiates and amphetamines, by using specific reagents. It is not related to the detection of cyanide.

Option C - Marsh Test:

  • The Marsh Test is a method used to detect and quantify arsenic in a substance or solution. It is not used for cyanide detection.

Option D - Mydriatic Test:

  • It is used for testing for the presence of toxic alkaloids found in datura plants

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented to the gynecology department with an unwanted pregnancy that she wants to terminate. The physician is giving her Mifepristone. Which of the following is the correct action of this drug for inducing abortion?
questions.solution:
Progesterone receptors

  • Mifepristone, also known as RU-486, is a medication typically used in combination with misoprostol to bring about abortion during pregnancy.
  • This combination is 97% effective during the first 63 days of pregnancy. It is also effective in the second trimester of pregnancy.
  • Mifepristone blocks the natural substance progesterone that is needed for pregnancy to continue (i.e., antiprogestogen).
  • Mifepristone is a derivative of norethindrone with antiprogestin action.
  • It binds to progesterone receptors in the endometrium and decidua, resulting in necrosis and detachment of POCs.

Learning Objective

  • Mifepristone (RU 486) in combination with misoprostol is 95% successful in terminating pregnancies of up to 9 week's duration with minimum complications. The commonly used regimen is mifepristone 200 mg orally on day 1, followed by misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally either immediately or within 6- 8 hours.
  • Commercially it comes as an MTP kit having combi pack tablets of mifepristone 200 mg one tablet and misoprostol 200 mcg 4 tablets (800 mcg). The other regimen is a dose of mifepristone 600 mg on day one, followed by 400 mcg orally of misoprostol on day three.
  • The patient should return for a follow-up visit approximately 14 days after the administration of mifepristone to confirm by clinical examination or ultrasonography scan that a complete termination of pregnancy has occurred. Patients who have an ongoing pregnancy at this visit have a risk of fetal malformation resulting from the treatment. Surgical termination is recommended to manage medical abortion treatment failures.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, itchy blisters all over the body, loss of appetite, and headache. Which of the following is the period of infectivity for the given condition?

choices.text: 5 days prior to appearance of rash till 4 days afterwards
4 days prior to appearance of rash till 5 days afterwards
4 days prior to appearance of rash till 1 day afterwards
1 day prior to appearance of rash till 4 days afterwards

questions.solution:
Option D: 1 day prior to appearance of rash till 4 days afterward

  • The symptoms mentioned above point toward the diagnosis of Chickenpox. The period of communicability/infectivity of chicken pox is 1-2 days before the appearance of the rash till 4 days afterward.
  • Therefore, all other options (A, B, and C) are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of cold, cough, fever, shortness of breath, and muscle aches visited the OPD. The doctor sent him for sample testing to identify the strain of influenza. What is common to H5N1 and H7N7 strains of influenza?

choices.text: Have same frequency of antigenic variation

questions.solution:
Option C: Strains of Avian influenza

  • H5N1 and H7N7 both are strains of Avian Influenza.
  • H7N7 virus infection in humans is uncommon but has been documented in persons who have direct contact with infected birds, especially during outbreaks among poultry.
  • H7N7: More common in horses.
  • In humans: H7N7 virus infections cause mild to moderate illness.
  • All other options (A, B & D) are incorrect.

Option A: Frequently endemic infection in man

  • H7N7 is more common in horses.
  • H7N7 is not frequently an endemic infection in men.

Option B: Have same frequency of antigenic variation

  • They both don't have the same frequency of antigenic variation.

Option D: All are correct

  • This is not the appropriate answer to the above-given question.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male from Rajasthan presented to the hospital with diarrhea, painful blisters on his legs, fever, swelling, and locking of joints. The patient also complains of worms coming out of the skin blister. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dracunculiasis

  • The causative agent of the Guinea Worm is Dracunculus medinensis.
  • Mode of transmission: Consumption of water containing Cyclops harboring infective stage of the parasite. Hence Dracunculiasis is the answer.
  • Type of Disease: Water-based disease.
  • Type of biological transmission: Cyclo development transmission.
  • India certified for the elimination of guinea worm: Feb 2000.

Option A: Typhoid

  • Typhoid fever is the result of systemic infection mainly by S. typhi found only in men.
  • The disease is clinically characterized by a typical continuous fever for 3 to 4 weeks, relative bradycardia with involvement of lymphoid tissues, and considerable constitutional symptoms.
  • The term "enteric fever" includes both typhoid and paratyphoid fevers. The disease may occur sporadically, epidemically, or endemic.

Option B: Yellow fever

  • Yellow fever is a zoonotic disease caused by an arbovirus. It affects principally monkeys and other vertebrates in tropical America and Africa and is transmitted to man by certain culicine mosquitoes.
  • It shares clinical features with other viral hemorrhagic fevers and albuminuria or anuria, shock, agitation, stupor, and coma. In general, death occurs between the fifth and tenth day of illness. The case fatality rate may reach 80 percent in severe cases.

Option D: Ancylostomiasis

  • Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are the main nematodes causing hookworm infection in man.
  • Almost eradicated from Europe and the USA, hookworm infection is still seen in warm, moist climates in tropical and subtropical regions between 45°N and 30°S of the equator.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, divorced, living alone was admitted to the hospital in a near comatose condition because of an overdose of approximately thirty tablets of Valium 5 mg, combined with alcoholic intoxication. The case was an attempt to suicide. According to NCRB report 2018, Suicide rate in India is?
questions.solution:
10.2 per 100,000 population

  • Suicide rate in India: 10.2 per lac population

Learning Objective

Suicides in India

  • Suicide rate in India: 10.2 per lac population
  • Highest number of suicides: Maharashtra
  • Highest suicide rate: Andaman And Nicobar islands > Puducherry > Sikkim
  • Lowest suicide rate: Bihar
  • MC age group in suicides: 18-30 years

questions.text: The national poliomyelitis elimination program is carried out by vaccinating all children under the age of five years against the polio virus. Under National Poliomyelitis Elimination Programme, Poliomyelitis is diagnosed by which of the following method?
questions.solution:
Option B: Viral isolation in stool

  • The greatest yield for poliovirus is from the viral culture of stool specimens; it is less likely to be recovered from the pharynx, and only rarely recovered from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or blood. If poliovirus is isolated, reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and genomic sequencing are used to determine the serotype (i.e., 1, 2, or 3), and whether the virus is a wild, vaccine (Sabin), or VDPV strain.

Option A: Antibodies titre rise in blood

  • Antibodies titre rise in the blood is previously used for diagnosis purposes.

Option C: Viral microscopy in stool

  • Virologues start the process of isolating poliovirus from the faeces samples in a lab. Determining the difference between wild (naturally occurring) and vaccine-related poliovirus is the next step if poliovirus is isolated.
  • Viral isolation in the stool is the method of diagnosis.

Option D: Clinical examination

  • Inapparent (subclinical) infection: In between 91% and 96% of cases of poliovirus infection, this is an inapparent (subclinical) infection ( 19). There are no visible signs of disease. Only virus isolation or increasing antibody titres can indicate recognition.
  • Abortive polio or Minor illness: Occurs in roughly 4–8% of infections. Viraemia only causes a little or self-limiting disease. The patient achieves a quick recovery. Clinical testing cannot determine the diagnosis.
  • Non-paralytic polio: Makes up about 1% of all infections. Neck and back pain as well as stiffness are the presenting symptoms. The illness lasts for two to ten days. Rapid recovery is seen in most cases.
