  • Paralytic polio: Less than 1% of infections result in Paralytic polio. The virus attacks the CNS and paralyses people to variable degrees. Flaccid paralysis with asymmetries is the main symptom.
  • Viral isolation in the stool is the confirmatory method of diagnosis.

questions.text: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Deafness (NPPCD) was launched by Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Govt. of India. Which of the following is the long term objective of national programme for prevention and control of deafness?

choices.text: To reduce disease burden by 25% by end of XII five year plan
To reduce disease burden by 50% by end of XII five year plan
To reduce disease burden by 75% by end of XII five year plan
To reduce disease burden by 100% by end of XII five year plan

questions.solution:
To reduce disease burden by 25% by end of XII five year plan

  • Long term objective is to reduce disease burden by 25% by end of XI five-year plan.

National programme for prevention and control of deafness:

  • OBJECTIVES:
    1. To prevent avoidable hearing loss on account of disease or injury.
    2. Early identification, diagnosis and treatment of ear problems responsible for hearing loss and deafness.
    3. To medically rehabilitate persons of all age groups, suffering with deafness.
    4. To strengthen the existing inter-sectoral linkages for continuity of the rehabilitation programme, for persons with deafness.
    5. To develop institutional capacity for ear care services by providing support for equipment, material and training personnel.
  • Long term objective: To prevent and control major causes of hearing impairment and deafness, so as to reduce the total disease burden by 25% of the existing burden by the end of 12th Five Year Plan.

questions.text: A healthcare delivery system is an organization of people, institutions, and resources to deliver healthcare services to meet the health needs of a target population. Three – Tier system of Health care delivery in rural areas in India is based on the recommendations of which of the following committee?
questions.solution:
Option C: Balwant Rai Mehta committee

  • Balwant Rai Mehta Committee: Recommended 3-tier rural Health infrastructure "Panchayat - Panchayat samiti - Zilla Parishad".

Option A: Bhore committee

  • Bhore Committee (1946Q): Also known as ‘Health Survey and Development Committee.
  • Prepare Social Physicians: (3 months of training in preventive and social medicine in medical education).

Option B: Chadha Committee

  • Constituted to study arrangements necessary for the ‘Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Programmme (NMEP).
  • 1 Basic Health Worker per 10,000 population (for malaria vigilance, collection of vital statistics, and family planning).
  • Family Planning Health Assistants to supervise 3-4 basic health workers.

Option D: Mudalair committee

  • It is also known as ‘Health Survey and Planning Committee.
  • 1 PHC per 40,000 population maximum.
  • Constitution of ‘All India Health Service’.
  • Strengthen district hospitals with specialist services.
  • Regional organizations in each state.

questions.text: In a population of 1000, there are 200 eligible couples. Among the eligible couples, 30 use condoms, 20 use IUCD, 20 use OC pills and 70 have undergone female sterilization. The rest of the couples do not use any method. Calculate the Couple protection rate.
questions.solution:
Option D: 70%

  • Values given are:
    • Total eligible couples = 200
    • Eligible couples protected by any of the approved methods = 30+20+20+70 =140
  • Couple protection rate (CPR) = Total number of eligible couples protected by any of the approved methods / Total number of eligible couples in the community × 100
  • CPR =140/200 X 100= 70%

Therefore, other options (A, B, and D) can be ruled out.

questions.text: International health regulations define their purpose and scope to prevent, protect against, control and provide a public health response to the international spread of disease. Which of the following disease is not covered by International health regulations?
questions.solution:
Option B: HIV/AIDS

  • The International Health Regulations (WHO IHR) do not cover HIV/AIDS.
  • It covers:
  • Immediately Notifiable Diseases
    • Smallpox
    • Human Influenza
    • Wild Polio
    • SARS
  • Potentially Notifiable Diseases:
    • Public health importance:
      • Cholera
      • Plague
      • Yellow fever
      • Viral hemorrhagic fever
      • West Nile fever
      • Dengue
      • Rift valley fever
      • Meningococcal disease.
  • Biological / Chemical / Radiological events
  • Serious illnesses of Unknown origin

 

Option A: Cholera

  • Cholera is a potentially notifiable disease under the Internation health regulation.
  • Extremely contagious cholera can result in severe acute watery diarrhoea. After consuming infected food or drink, symptoms usually appear between 12 hours and 5 days.

Option C: Plague

  • Plague is a potentially notifiable disease under the Internation health regulation.
  • Yersinia pestis is the bacterium that causes Plague. The most common ways for humans to contract the plague are through handling a plague-infected animal or by getting bitten by a rodent flea that is carrying the disease.

Option D: Yellow fever

  • Yellow fever is a potentially notifiable disease under the Internation health regulation.
  • Acute viral hemorrhagic disease called yellow fever is spread by infected mosquitoes. A safe and economical vaccine that is incredibly successful at preventing yellow fever is available. Yellow fever vaccination only needs to be administered once to provide lifelong immunity and protection from the disease.

questions.text: A community medicine intern in his viva session with his senior incharge was asked to define saturation index. Which of the following is the correct definition of Saturation index?

choices.text: Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants.
Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity and pH.
Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops.
Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it.

questions.solution:
B: Used to assess the Water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity and pH

  • Langelier saturation index is used for assessment of water quality, therefore option B is correct answer.

Langelier Saturation index:

  • Langelier saturation index indicates degree of saturation of CaCO3 in water.
  • Used in industry to stabilize water.
  • LSI is based on
    • pH of water
    • Total dissolved solids
    • Alkalinity
    • Calcium concentration
    • Water temperature
  • LI positive: It leads to deposition & scaling.
  • LI negative: It leads to corrosion.
  • LI should be kept zero: To avoid corrosion & scaling.

A/ C/ D: Used to assess the Air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants/ Used to assess the Soil quality that whether it is good for growing crops/ Used to assess the Milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it.

  • These all choices do not correctly describe the saturation index

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with dry skin and dry eyes. On serological examination Vitamin. A deficiency was reported. What is the daily requirement of Vitamin A by an adult man?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option B: 900 mcg

  • 900 mcg or 3000IU The recommended daily amount of vitamin A is 900 micrograms (mcg) for adult men and 700 mcg for adult women.

Other options

Option C: 600 mcg

  • Incorrect answer.

Option A: 350 mcg

  • Incorrect answer.

Option D: 2000 mcg

  • This amount is significantly higher than the recommended daily requirement for Vitamin A in an adult man. Consuming such a high dose of Vitamin A regularly can lead to toxicity and potential health problems.

questions.text: School health refers to a state of complete physical, mental, social and spiritual well- being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity among pupils, teachers and otherschool personnel. Which of the following committee gave the concept of school health first?
questions.solution:
BHORE committee

School Health ·

  • Concept first laid by BHORE committee (Recommendation 1946)
  • Guidelines were laid down in detail by RENUKA ROY committee (Recommendation 1961)

BHORE Committee

Contribution of BHORE committee as follows:

  • School health
  • Primary health care
  • Health survey and development
  • Social Health
  • Comprehensive Health care
  • Social physician

RENUKA ROY committee

  • Renuka roy committee gave the first comprehensive school health.

Kartar Singh committee

  • Kartar Singh committee is the committee on multipurpose workers under health and family planning.

Mukherjee committee

  • Mukherjee committee suggested that Basic health should be provided at block level

questions.text: A microbiologist is teaching his intern to prepare the DPT vaccine in the laboratory. After vaccine preparation, he added an adjuvant to the DPT vaccine. What is the role of adjuvant in the DPT vaccine?

choices.text: Increase the shelf life of a vaccine

questions.solution:
Option C: Increase antigenicity

  • Aluminum hydroxide/phosphate is used as an adjuvant/adsorbent in the DPT vaccine.
  • It binds the three components (D, P, and T) together.

  • The commonly used adjuvant are alumnium salts (aluminium phosphate, aluminium hydroxide, or potassium aluminium sulfate).

  • Adjuvants are primarily included in vaccines to increase antigenicity, which means they enhance the body's immune response to the antigens in the vaccine.

  • Adjuvants help stimulate a stronger and longer-lasting immune response by activating immune cells, such as dendritic cells, and promoting the production of antibodies and memory cells. This ensures that the vaccine is more effective in providing immunity against the targeted diseases.

Option A: Decrease hypersensitivity

  • Adding an adjuvant does not decrease the hypersensitivity reactions. 
  • Adjuvants can rarely lead to injection site reactions and contact hypersensitivity.

Option B: Decrease absorption of vaccine

  • The adjuvant does not decrease the absorption of vaccine.
  • The adjuvant is added to a vaccine to enhance the immune response, making it possible to the total number of doses needed to achieve immunity.

Option D: Increase the shelf life of a vaccine

  • The adjuvants have no role in increasing the shelf life of the vaccine.

questions.text: In a town of 20,000 population, a total of 456 births were there in a year out of which 56 were dead born. There were 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and another 34 had died after 28 days and before completing the first birthday. What is the Infant mortality rate in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: 225

  • The infant mortality rate (IMR) is calculated as the number of infant deaths (under one year of age) per 1,000 live births.
  • Total live births = 456 - 56 (dead born) = 400
  • Total infant deaths = 56 (within 28 days) + 34 (between 28 days and first birthday) = 90
  • IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) x 1000
    • IMR = (90 / 400) x 1000
    • IMR = 225
  • So, the infant mortality rate in this area is 225 per 1,000 live births.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: In a study carried out prospectively, out of 1000 truck drivers who were using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. During the same period, out of 5000 truck drivers who were not using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. What is the Relative Risk?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 5

  • Exposure is mobile usage while driving, the incidence of accidents under consideration is that of:
  • Incidence of exposure (IE)= 300/1000
  • Incidence of non-exposed (INE) = 300/5000
  • RR (Relative Risk) = = 5 (thus mobile usage is associated with 5 times increased incidence of accident).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria. A renal biopsy demonstrates focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis with crescent formation. The patient gives a history of intermittent hemoptysis and intermittent chest pain of moderate intensity. A previous chest X-ray had demonstrated 90 multiple opacities, some of which were capitated. The patient also has chronic cold-like nasal symptoms, joint pain, fatigue, weight loss, skin sores, and blood in the urine. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wegner's granulomatosis

  • The patient has the involvement in the following:
  • Upper respiratory tract: chronic cold symptoms suggestive of sinusitis
  • Lower respiratory tract: intermittent hemoptysis due to bilateral lung cavitation.
  • Kidney involvement: Hematuria with necrotizing vasculitis.
  • Therefore, the diagnosis favors granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's Granulomatosis).
  • It is a vascular necrotizing vasculitis and is granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
  • It involves:
    • A: upper respiratory tract (sinusitis, crusting rhinitis, saddle nose deformity),
    • B lower respiratory tract (lung nodules, alveolar hemorrhage) and
    • C kidney involvement (glomerulonephritis).
  • Diagnosis
    • For diagnosis, c-ANCA will be helpful, along with biopsy findings of vasculitis.
    • The cytoplasmic immunofluorescence pattern (c-ANCOPTION A: is caused by PR3-ANCA and has a high specificity of>90% for granulomatosis with angiitis.

Option A: Aspergillosis

  • It is an infection caused by a type of mould (fungus)
  • It usually affects the Respiratory system and leads to shortness of breath, fatigue and coughing up blood
  • Involve lungs in invasive aspergilloma, but multiple cavity formation is not seen, and neither is glomerulonephritis, as in this case.
  • Symptoms include chills and a fever
      • Hemoptysis
      • breathing difficulty
      • joint or chest ache
      • Eye issues or headaches
      • Skin lesions

Option B: Polyarteritis Nodosa

  • It is a disorder that causes damage to small and medium-sized arteries.
  • Such as those supplying the skeletal muscles, neurological system, heart, kidneys, and gut.
  • This may result in hypertension, aneurysm of an arterial wall, thrombosis, and necrosis in certain affected areas.
  • They were ruled out as lung and pulmonary artery involvement is not seen in this option.
  • It is unknown what specifically causes polyarteritis nodosa.
  • The majority of patients have no known predisposing factors. Unknown viral or bacterial infections could be the reason. Drug abusers, particularly those who use amphetamines, and hepatitis B patients have been shown to have polyarteritis nodosa.
  • An allergic response to certain medications and immunizations has also been connected to this condition.

Option C: Renal cell carcinoma metastatic to the lung

  • RCC metastasizes most frequently to the lungs.
  • In such cases, the most common manifestation is solitary or multiple lung nodules.
  • Ruled out since it is mentioned that renal biopsy shows segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis and no presence of lung nodules is indicated.
  • Pleural effusions are a symptom of advanced renal cell carcinomas.
  • Pulmonary emboli are a symptom of RCC because of a hypercoagulable condition.
  • RCC's highly vascularized nature in metastatic foci may result in arteriovenous fistulas.
  • Additionally, paraneoplastic symptoms, including cough and diaphragm paralysis, might be a symptom of RCC.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib, and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes. What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allogeneic bone marrow transplantation

  • The above features are suggestive of the Accelerated phase of CML.
  • Among patients who present with or evolve to the blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • The same applies to patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase. Patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response). The most effective is stem cell transplantation.
  • Among patients who relapse in the chronic phase, the treatment sequence depends on several factors, such as the patient's age and risk factors for stem cell transplantation.

Option B: Autologous bone marrow transplantation

  • Autologous bone marrow transplantation is not the treatment of choice; because the patient's bone marrow is already infiltrated with cancer.

Option C: Chemotherapy

  • The patient's peripheral blood shows >30% blasts with promyelocytes after treatment with imatinib and nilotinib. It shows chemotherapy is ineffective in this case.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Hydroxyurea & interferon

  • Hydroxyurea, a ribonucleotide reductase inhibitor, is used for controlling cell counts.
  • Interferons are given when allogeneic stem cell transplantation is not feasible.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to OPD complaining of painless bloody diarrhoea with a frequency of 10 episodes/ day, generalized weakness, puffy eyes, and swelling over both ankles. A colonoscopy reveals lesions in the rectum. A biopsy is taken, and a microscopic examination of tissue shows inflammation limited to mucosa and submucosa only. Which of the following is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation in this disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Faecal lactoferrin

  • The above case scenario is indicative of Ulcerative colitis.
  • Faecal lactoferrin, a glycoprotein in activated neutrophils, is a sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation in ulcerative colitis.
  • Faecal calprotectin levels can also be elevated in cases of acute diarrhoea.

Option A: CRP

  • It is used to monitor disease activity in autoimmune diseases.

Option C: Faecal calprotectin

  • Faecal calprotectin levels correlate well with histologic inflammation, predict relapses, and detect pouchitis

Option D: Leukocytosis

  • The degree of white blood cell elevation does not correlate with the number of white blood cells in the intestine.

questions.text: A 38-year female presents to emergency with complaints of Headache, confusion, decreased urinary output, swelling on both ankles, nausea, fatigue and shortness of breath. Urine investigations revealed: Urine osmolality: 800 mOsm/kg. Urinary sodium 10 mmol/L.BUN: creatinine=20:1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pre-renal acute renal failure

  • Urine osmolality should be greater than 500 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium less than 20mmol/dl
  • Fractional excretion of sodium should be less than 1
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be greater than 20:1
  • All these criteria are fulfilled above
  Pre renal Renal (ATN) Post renal
Urine osmolality > 500 mOsm

 

 ~ 300 mOsm

 

 <400 mOsm
Urine sodium <20 mmol/dl >20 mmol/dl

 

 Variable
FeNa <1 >1 Variable
Urine microscopic findings Hyaline casts Muddy brown casts

 

 Normal or RBC/WBC
BUN: creatinine ratio >20:1 (normal 10:1)

 

 <20:1

 

 >20:1

 

 

Option B: Acute tubular necrosis

  • This constitutes renal injury for which the following criterion is followed
  • Urine osmolality almost equal to 300 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium of more than 20mmol/dl
  • Fractional excretion of sodium of more than 1
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be less than 20:1

Option C: Acute Cortical Necrosis

  • This constitutes renal injury for which the following criterion is followed
  • Urine osmolality almost equal to 300 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium of more than 20mmol/dl
  • Fractional excretion of sodium of more than 1
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be less than 20:1

Option D: Urinary Tract Obstruction

  • This constitutes post-renal injury for which the following criterion is followed
  • Urine osmolality less than 400 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium is variable
  • Fractional excretion of sodium is also variable
  • BUN and creatinine ratio should be more than 20:1

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, CEO of a multinational company, suffered from palpitations, breathlessness and sweating while attending a conference. He was rushed to a nearby hospital. On physical examination, the patient was pulseless, and his blood pressure was unrecordable. The ECG was done with findings as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia

  • Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MVT) is a broad, complicated heartbeat that originates in the ventricles from a single focus.
  • It consists of continual, widespread complicated tachycardia with the uniform broad QRS complex.
  • The heart rate is 250 bpm, and broad complex QRS is seen in all leads.
  • In a patient with pulseless VT, the heart rate increases, causing a decrease in diastolic duration; as a result, the end-diastolic volume decreases leading to a decreased stroke volume, causing the patient to collapse.
  • Therefore, a hemodynamically unstable patient needs a DC shock of 200 J biphasic.
  • However, stable monomorphic VT treatment is done with IV procainamide/Amiodarone.

Option B: Bidirectional tachycardia

  • It is a regular ventricular tachyarrhythmia having 2 different morphologies of QRS, which alternate at a rate between 140 and 180 bpm.
  • Most commonly associated with digoxin toxicity.

Option C: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

  • Multiple ventricular foci are present in polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PVT), a kind of ventricular tachycardia in which the QRS complex results has varied amplitude, axis, and duration.
  • PVT is typically brought on by myocardial ischaemia or infarction, and other causes which prolong the QT interval include:
    • Metabolic abnormalities (Hypokalemia, Hypomagnesemia and Hypocalcemia)
    • Erythromycin + HCQ also cause QT interval prolongation and lead to Torsades de Pointes. Other banned drugs, such as Cisapride, Astemizole, and Ketoconazole, cause QT interval prolongation and can make the ventricular myocardium unstable.
  • ECG:
    • QTc prolongation (c= corrected)
    • Broad QRS complex tachycardia: the amplitude, axis and duration of QRS are variable, so it is called Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

Option D: Ventricular fibrillation

  • ECG findings include
    • It has chaotic irregular deflection having a varying amplitude
    • P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves cannot be identified
    • Ventricular rate of 150 to 500 per minute and decreasing amplitude with duration

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 2 weeks. He reports mild substernal chest pain. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 74 beats/min, and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. On chest auscultation, fine basal crackles are heard bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Lower limbs are edematous bilaterally up to mid-thigh, and oedema is more pronounced at the ankles. An echocardiogram is done, which reveals an ejection fraction of 25% with anterior, septal, and lateral wall motion defects. He is admitted to the ward and stabilized on furosemide, spironolactone, bisoprolol, and ramipril. What would be the best next investigation in course of his management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Angiogram

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with heart failure secondary to ischemic heart disease.
  • An echocardiogram is a screening tool used for looking at wall motion abnormalities.
  • Angiography:
    • Angiography or arteriography is an imaging technique in which a contrast dye is used to visualize the inside of blood vessels and the heart chambers.
    • It is a gold standard investigation to assess the anatomy, and physiology of the heart.
    • Angiography is used to assess vasculature abnormalities and to evaluate the extent of severity of cardiac disease in symptomatic individuals.
    • The indications of angiography are as follows:
Indications of Angiography:
Asymptomatic or Symptomatic Ventricular tachycardia
Symptomatic Acute Coronary Syndrome
Chest pain syndromes
STEMI
Congestive Heart failure
Pericardial disease
Cardiac Transplantation

Option A: Endomyocardial biopsy

  • Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) is a procedure that obtains small amounts of myocardial tissue percutaneously for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) is used for surveillance of cardiac allograft rejection and the diagnosis of unexplained ventricular dysfunction.
  • It is not an investigation to look at vessels.

Option C: Viral titers

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with heart failure. Heart failure can occur secondary to viral infections such as hepatitis B and C, COVID-19, and parvovirus etc.
  • However, this patient does not have any prodromal viral symptoms and his history is more consistent with heart failure in the setting of ischemic heart disease.

Option D: Exercise tolerance test(ETT)

  • ETT is contraindicated in the setting of ongoing chest pain.
  • As this patient has ongoing pain, it should not be done.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to dysuria and passing foamy urine for 2 weeks. He has had a history of type II diabetes mellitus for 20 years, for which he takes insulin irregularly. The recent laboratory investigations reveal:


	
		
			
			Glucose
			
			
			200mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Urea
			
			
			52mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			1.2mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Uric acid
			
			
			5.3mg/dl
			
		
	



	
		
			Blood pressure
			160/92mmHg
		
		
			Urine Albumin
			35mg
		
	


The physician suspects a complication of long-standing diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria
24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine
Microalbuminuria correlates with nocturnal spike in Systolic blood pressure
It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.solution:
Option C: Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in systolic blood pressure

  • The patient presents with clinical features of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is initially manifested as microalbuminuria.
  • Microalbuminuria is the urinary albumin excretion of 30-300mg/day.
  • Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in systolic blood pressure.
  • There is a positive link between high blood pressure and microalbuminuria.
  • High blood pressure may cause microalbuminuria by increasing glomerular filtration pressure and subsequently causing kidney damage.
  • Antihypertensive activity decreases microalbuminuria by decreasing intraglomerular pressure and lowering systemic hypertension.
  • Hence, normotensive diabetic patients with microalbuminuria have slightly elevated blood pressure during sleep, which is lowered by antihypertensive therapy.

Option A: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria

  • Sensitive radioimmunoassay methods measure small amounts of urinary albumin in contrast to less sensitive dipstick strips, whose minimal detection is 0.3-0.5%

Option B: 24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine

  • 24-hour urine albumin values are affected by the following:
    • Exercise
    • Dietary protein
    • Sustained erect posture
  • ​​​​​​​This problem is circumvented with spot sample urine albumin to urine creatinine values.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus

  • Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.
  • Heart disease in a patient with diabetes is due to coronary atherosclerosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents to his primary health care physician for further evaluation of hypercalcemia detected incidentally during a routine medical check-up. She is asymptomatic and denies constipation, palpitation, or bone pains. Her laboratory investigations are as follows: 


	
		
			
			Haemoglobin
			
			
			12.2 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Serum
			
			 
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			0.7 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Proteins
			
			 
		
		
			
			Total
			
			
			7.0 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Albumin
			
			
			4.1 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			13.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Phosphorus
			
			
			2.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Alkaline phosphatase

			PTH
			
			
			130 U/L

			72
			
		
	


After administration of normal saline, her serum calcium is 12 mg/dl. The rest of the laboratory investigations, including the cancer screen, are normal. What is the most likely indication for surgery in this patient?

choices.text: Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

questions.solution:
Option D:  Serum calcium >11 mg/dL above the normal value

  • This clinical vignette is about a patient suffering from primary hyperparathyroidism, the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (as also seen in this patient).
  • The patient is asymptomatic, but her serum calcium level is more than 11 mg/dL, higher than the normal upper limit. Therefore, this patient needs surgery for the treatment of her condition.
  • Normal calcium levels: 9-11 mg %

Role of surgery in the management of hyperparathyroidism:

  • A more aggressive surgical approach should be considered in most patients due to concerns of subtle neuropsychiatric symptoms, long-term skeletal effects, and potential for cardiovascular deterioration.

Option A: Age >50 years

  • Age of less than 50 years is an indication for surgery of primary hyperparathyroidism

Option B: 24-hour urine for calcium >100 mg/day

  • Urinary excretion of > 400 mg/day of calcium is an indication of surgery

Option C: Osteopenia on bone density testing

  • T score in bone density test between -1 to -2.5 indicates osteopenia

questions.text: An alcoholic develops intractable vomiting for 2 days with loose motions. Since he had decreased food intake and altered sensorium, he has been brought to the hospital, where the fluid loss and dyselectrolytemia are aggressively corrected with the fluid infusion. Post-treatment, the patient starts having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Osmotic demyelination syndrome

  • Chronic hyponatremia management is significantly complicated by the asymmetry of the cellular response to the correction of plasma Na+ concentration.
  • Specifically, brain cells' reaccumulation of organic osmolytes is attenuated and delayed as osmolality increases after correcting hyponatremia, sometimes resulting in degenerative loss of oligodendrocytes and an osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS).
  • Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) is also associated with a disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.
  • The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons.
  • Patients with central pontine myelinolysis can present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, a "locked-in syndrome," and/or loss of consciousness.
  • Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in association with lesions of the pons but occasionally in isolation; in order of frequency, the lesions of extrapontine myelinolysis can occur in the cerebellum, lateral geniculate body, thalamus, putamen, and cerebral cortex or subcortex.
  • Therefore, the clinical presentation of ODS can vary as a function of the extent and localization of extrapontine myelinolysis, with the reported development of ataxia, mutism, parkinsonism, dystonia, and catatonia.
  • Relowering of plasma Na+ concentration after overly rapid correction can prevent or attenuate ODS.
  • However, even appropriately slow correction can be associated with ODS, particularly in patients with additional risk factors; these include alcoholism, malnutrition, hypokalemia, and liver transplantation.

Option B: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH production

  • SIADH is caused by various drugs, such as SSRIs and disorders of the pulmonary system and CNS.
  • It causes euvolemic hyponatremia.
  • However, it is not associated with mutism or quadriparesis.

Option C: Brainstem infarct

  • Brainstem infarcts may present with quadriplegia.
  • Coma can occur.
  • However, the risk factors are hypertension, diabetes and chronic atherosclerotic diseases.

Option D: Meningitis

  • Meningitis presents with headache, fever and signs of meningeal irritation.
  • Meningitis complicated by brain abscess can cause a focal neurologic deficit.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in a rural PHC. A 26-year-old male presented with complaints of a burning sensation over the chest, usually after eating, associated with regurgitation of food or sore liquid. You prescribed him PPI & advised the patient for follow-up. All of the following statements are true regarding the above condition, except?

choices.text: Occurs during transient relaxation of LES
Bicarbonate secreted by oesophageal mucosa neutralizes the acid
Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the hallmark of GERD

questions.solution:
Option C: Bicarbonate secreted by oesophagal mucosa neutralizes the acid

  • The primary function of the mucosal bicarbonate secretion is to neutralize acid diffusing into the mucus gel layer and to be quantitatively sufficient to maintain a near-neutral pH at the mucus-mucosal surface interface.
  • Bicarbonates are secreted from pancreas not from esophagus.
  • The above clinical history leads to the diagnosis of GERD.
  • Mechanisms of GERD:
    • Transient LES relaxations
    • LES hypotension
    • Anatomic distortion of the esophagogastric junction inclusive of hiatus hernia ·
    • The acid can lead to chemical tracheitis → nocturnal cough, and bronchospasm.
    • Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the endoscopic hallmark of GERD.

Option A: Occurs during transient relaxation of LES

  • Transient lower oesophageal sphincter relaxation (TLESR) is defined as lower oesophagal sphincter relaxation that is induced spontaneously without swallowing.
  • TLESR is a physiological mechanism that enables the venting of gas from the stomach.
  • The lower oesophageal sphincter (LES) remains tonically contracted at rest.
  • It relaxes during various reflex activities, including swallowing, allowing antegrade flow and belching and gastroesophageal reflux allowing the retrograde flow of gastric contents.

 

Option B: Can present with nocturnal cough

  • Nocturnal cough can be due to a disease of the upper airway, lower airway, gastrointestinal system, or cardiovascular system.
  • A viral respiratory tract infection is the most common cause of acute/subacute cough—upper airway cough syndrome.
  • Causes of a nocturnal cough can be categorized as respiratory, non-respiratory, and systemic.
  • A chronic cough's most common respiratory causes include postnasal drip, postinfectious, and asthma.
  • Environmental factors include smoking, both active and passive; this is the most frequent environmental factor.

Option D: Erosive esophagitis at the esophagogastric junction is the hallmark of GERD

  • Esophagitis is inflammation that may damage tissues of the oesophagus, the muscular tube that delivers food from mouth to stomach. Esophagitis can cause painful, difficult swallowing and chest pain.
  • The abnormal reflux of gastric contents causes gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in the oesophagus.
  • GERD can be divided into two groups, erosive esophagitis and non-erosive reflux disease (NERD).
  • Erosive esophagitis is severe reflux esophagitis characterized by mucosal breaks, such as erosions or ulcerations on endoscopy. There is little correlation between endoscopic and histologic findings in patients with GERD.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with complaints of 2 episodes of hematemesis. Initial investigations revealed Hb of 7.2g/dl. She was advised to have a UGI endoscopy done. Which of the following finding on upper GI endoscopy indicates the most negligible chances of re-bleeding after hematemesis episodes?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clean-based ulcer

  • Most patients with hematemesis have a re-bleed within the next 3 days of an episode.
  • UGIE is diagnostic and prognostic as a clean-based ulcer has the slightest chance of re-bleeding, while the visible bleeding vessel has the highest chance.
  • Endoscopic intervention is indicated in active bleeding, non-bleeding visible vessel, and active bleeding or visible vessel exposed after adherent clot removal.
  • These are ulcers with a clean base or with flat blood spots.

 

Option A: Adherent clot on the ulcer

  • An adherent clot is called a red, maroon, or black protuberance greater than 3 mm in diameter that could not be dislodged by forceful irrigation with water.
  • It is typically seen as a barium-filled ulcer crater's smooth or irregular filling defect.
  • Granulation tissue or debris in the ulcer may produce similar findings.
  • Symptoms may include sudden, severe pain in the belly (abdomen), usually in the upper abdomen.

 

Option C: Gastric ulcer with AV malformation

  • An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal tangle of blood vessels connecting arteries and veins, which disrupts normal blood flow and oxygen circulation.
  •  Arteries are responsible for taking oxygen-rich blood from the heart to the brain. Veins carry the oxygen-depleted blood back to the lungs and heart.
  • An AVM occurs when arteries in the brain connect directly to nearby veins without having the usual small vessels (capillaries) between them.
  • The exact cause of cerebral AVM is unknown. However, evidence suggests a genetic cause.

 

Option D: Visible bleeding vessel

  • There are four commonly used endoscopic techniques in treating a bleeding ulcer: injection therapy, thermal coagulation, endoscopic clipping, and, most recently, hemostatic powders that are sprayed onto the bleeding ulcer.
  • An endoscopy procedure may help to see if and where GI is bleeding and the bleeding's cause.
  • In upper GI bleeding, an IV drug known as a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is given to suppress stomach acid production.
  • Severe internal bleeding is life-threatening. Perforation or serious bleeding may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presented with a long history of upper abdominal discomfort, anorexia and two episodes of recent gum bleeds without fever or other bleeding manifestations. Examination revealed moderate hepatosplenomegaly. On investigation, he was found to have extreme thrombocytosis and leucocytosis. He was investigated for CML and found to be positive for BCR-ABL by reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR). Vitamin B12 level in this patient would be?
questions.solution:
Option A: Elevated

  • Vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML
  • The increase in circulating Vitamin B12 levels is predominantly caused by enhanced production of haptocorrin.
  • The haptocorrin is also known as transcobalamin-1 (TC-1) or cobalophilin.
  • It is a unique glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the oral cavity in response to the ingestion of food.
  • The essential function of haptocorrin is the protection of the acid-sensitive vitamin B12 while it moves through the stomach.

Option B: Decreased (slightly)

  • The level of vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML.
  • The level of LAP (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase) is decreased in CML.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Normal

  • The level of vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Markedly decreased

  • The level of vitamin B12 is markedly increased in CML.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of the right-side face, arm weakness, and difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 76 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 3/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left. Non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intravenous reteplase

  • The patient is presenting with complaints of a stroke. Non-contrast CT of the head shows a hypodense area in the left middle cerebral artery indicating acute ischemic stroke.
  • Causes of ischemic stroke include:
  • Thrombotic (a thrombus forms at the site of the infarct)
  • Embolic (an embolus travels from other parts of the body)
  • Hypoxic (due to systemic hypotension or hypoxemia)
  • Management of ischemic stroke:
  • Thrombolytic therapy (e.g., reteplase, alteplase) if the ischemic stroke occurred within 4.5 hours with no risk of haemorrhage.
  • Mechanical thrombectomy is required if there is a large artery occlusion.
  • Treating the underlying cause of the ischemic stroke.
  • Lowering a patient's blood pressure will reduce cerebral perfusion and worsen the patient; hence antihypertensives are avoided.
  • Aspiration pneumonia and deep vein thrombosis should be prevented
  • Mannitol is given when features of raised intracranial pressure are present.

Option A: Intravenous nicardipine

  • IV nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker.
  • It is not required as blood pressure is not in the range of a hypertensive crisis.

Option B: Intravenous labetalol

  • Labetalol is a beta blocker drug used as an antihypertensive and antiarrhythmic.
  • IV labetalol is unsuitable as the patient's blood pressure is not in the hypertensive crisis range.

Option D: Intravenous mannitol

  • Mannitol is given when features of raised intracranial pressure are present. This patient shows no sign of raised intracranial pressure, i.e. nausea, vomiting, or headache. Hence, no need for mannitol in this patient

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the neurology outpatient department, who is a diagnosed case of low-grade astrocytoma, with complaints of recurrent headaches and frequent seizure episodes secondary to his brain tumour. Which of the following anticonvulsant drug is suitable for treating epilepsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Levetiracetam

  • In epilepsy caused by a brain tumour, the drug of choice is those drugs that do not induce the hepatic microsomal enzyme system.
  • Following are the drugs that can be used:
  • Levetiracetam
  • Topiramate
  • Lamotrigine
  • Valproic acid
  • Lacosamide.

Option B: Phenytoin

  • The most common cause of drug interactions with phenytoin is the induction of the cytochrome P-450 isoenzymes CYP2C, CYP2D, and CYP3A subfamilies and UDP-glucuronosyltransferase.

Option C: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is a powerful inducer of CYP3A, the most abundant family of cytochrome P450 enzymes.

Option D: Phenobarbitone

  • Phenobarbital is a potent cytochrome P450 enzyme inducer, leading to interactions with other drugs by increasing their clearance.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with weakness in both lower extremities, progressively worsening tingling and numbness, and difficulty getting up from the chair. He has had a history of having laxity in both ankles since his 20s. He also has a tendency for his feet to turn inwards, trip, and subsequently sprain his ankles. Family history also reports having hammertoes in immediate family members involving his mother, sibling, and daughter. On examination, palpable nerves are seen. A typical onion bulb appearance is noted on a biopsy of the nerve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Charcot Marie Tooth disease

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to the defective proteins involved in myelin sheath structure and function.
  • It results in foot abnormalities and motor/sensory deficits.
  • Concomitant sensory deficit leads to Gait ataxia.
  • Nerve biopsy: Classical onion bulb appearance seen in Charcot Marie Tooth disease.
  • Charcot Marie Tooth disease ( Hereditary sensorimotor neuropathy) manifests as:
  • Peroneal muscle atrophy leading to stork leg appearance as shown in the image provided in the question.
  • Thickened nerves
  • Nerve biopsy: Onion bulb appearance
  • Distal weakness
  • A summary of signs and symptoms is given below in the image:

Option B: Lambert Eaton Syndrome

  • Autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels characterize Lambert Eaton Syndrome.
  • Clinical manifestations are:
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction (constipation, dry mouth)
  • Absent deep tendon reflexes
  • Dysphagia and dysarthria also are seen.
  • Ocular symptoms are ptosis and diplopia due to cranial nerve (CN)involvement.
  • Repeated electrical stimulation enhances muscle power due to incremental response.
  • It is associated with small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option C: Neurosyphilis

  • Tabes dorsalis or Neurosyphilis is caused by tertiary syphilis.
  • It results from the degeneration/demyelination of dorsal columns and roots.
  • There is decreased sense of proprioception which leads to sensory ataxia (the patient cannot stand with closed eyes and falls to the ground).
  • There is also decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option D: Duchenne's Muscular dystrophy

  • It is a genetic mutation with dystrophin gene deletion from chromosome X, so it mainly affects boys.
  • Dystrophin is a structural protein present in muscle fibres, and its absence results in muscular abnormalities:
  • Clumsy and waddling gait.
  • Progressive proximal muscular weakness.
  • Thigh muscles atrophy
  • Hypertrophy of calf muscle (pseudo-hypertrophy to compensate for the thigh muscle weakness).
  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • It starts affecting in 3 to 4 years, and the child can become a wheelchair user by 12 years.
  • It can also cause pulmonary problems due to kyphoscoliosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with pre-existing seropositive rheumatoid arthritis presents in the emergency department with complaints of progressive difficulty in breathing. He works as a crane operator near a construction site. On examination, joint findings were consistent with chronic rheumatoid arthritis, and Rheumatoid nodules were appreciated. Hence, a chest X-ray was performed, which is shown below. What is your most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Caplan syndrome

  • There are many manifestations of respiratory illnesses in patients diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and a variety of respiratory problems may be seen. 
  • Pulmonary fibrosis, pleural effusion, pulmonary nodules, bronchiolitis obliterans, complications of drug therapy, infections (possibly atypical) secondary to immunosuppression.
  • Caplan's syndrome is diagnosed as massive fibrotic nodules with occupational coal dust exposure in RA patients. 
  • CXR of this patient is suggestive of – Pneumoconiosis, and on examination, Rheumatoid nodules are also present, which points to the diagnosis of Caplan syndrome.
  • Caplan syndrome: Coal worker pneumoconiosis + Rheumatoid nodules.

Other options

Option B: Felty’s syndrome

  • There are many systemic complications of RA, and Felty's syndrome is a rare complication comprising (RA + splenomegaly + low white cell count).

Option C: Bronchiolitis obliterans

  • Bronchiolitis obliterans is obliterative bronchiolitis that constricts the smallest airways of the lung (bronchioles) because of continuous inflammation. It is also known as popcorn lung disease because of the patchy involvement of the lung.
  • It can present with dry cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing.

Option D: Lung cancer

  • Lung Cancer presents with mass effects and different symptoms than in the scenario mentioned above.
  • The sign and symptoms in patients with lung cancer include: hemoptysis, dyspnoea, chest pain, weight loss and anorexia, hoarseness
    • It can be seen with Pancoast tumours pressing the recurrent laryngeal nerve
    • superior vena cava syndrome
    • On the radiograph, Lung cancer will be appreciated as a mass, excluding the small cell lung cancers, which are very small to be appreciated on the chest X-ray.

questions.text: An elderly female patient occupationally teacher presents to the medicine outpatient department. She was complaining of a severe right-sided throbbing headache. Upon history taking, the patient informed that she has a history of polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient also had a history of undocumented weight loss because she had difficulty eating and was constantly fatigued. On further examination, she also complained of aching of the jaw during chewing. The result of the prescribed lab investigation showed the results of elevated ESR. The symptoms mentioned earlier indicate a vascular disease. Which statement is correct regarding the disease?

choices.text: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years
Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis
50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss
It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults

questions.solution:
Option C: 50% of the patient present with ocular symptoms that vary from diplopia to complete vision loss

Giant cell arteritis:

  • Also known as "Temporal Arteritis."
  • GCA is a granulomatous large vessel vasculitis of the aorta and its branches, preferably the temporal artery.
  • GCA affecting cranial branches of the aortic arch :
    • Superficial temporal arteries (most common)
    • Ophthalmic arteries

 

  • Clinical features:
    • A disease of the elderly (age > 50)
    • Female predominance
  • Symptoms - constitutional:
    • fever,
    •  fatigue,
    • weight loss
  • Temporal artery:
    • Ipsilateral headache
    • Tender artery and scalp
    • Absent TA pulse
  • Ophthalmic artery : (optical symptoms)
    • Optic neuritis
    • Diplopia to complete vision loss in 50 % of patients
    • Amaurosis fugax
  • Facial artery:
    • Jaw claudication (pain on chewing due to ischemia of masseter muscles).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis is based on clinical features + elevated ESR + prompt response to steroid.
    • Elevated ESR.
    • Elevated CRP
    • Normocytic normochromic anemia
    • Temporal artery biopsy
  • Treatment:
  • Steroids (Prednisone at 40–60 mg daily for 1 month with gradual tapering).
  • Do not await biopsy and pathology reports to start steroids.
  • Monitor clinical status and ESR.

Option A: Large vessel vasculitis is commonly seen in patients aged <50 years.

  • In Asia, Takayasu's Arteritis is the most common vasculitis in young and middle-aged patients (age <50).
  • It is granulomatous large vessel  vasculitis affecting
  • Aortic arch vessels
  • Pulmonary arteries ( half of the cases)
  • Clinical features :
    • Fatigue, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia
    • Anaemia and elevated ESR
    • Visual field defects and retinal haemorrhages
    • Systolic BP <10mm Hg b/w arms
    • Loss of pulse in upper extremities
  • Female predominant
  • Angiography is the most accurate test.
  • It shows occlusions, stenosis and aneurysms.
  • Treatment:
    • Steroids (high dose)
    • Immunosuppressant

Option B: Steroids are contraindicated in this vasculitis

  • Steroids are contraindicated in Kawasaki disease (medium-sized vessel vasculitis) due to the danger of vessel rupture.
  • Kawasaki is treated with Aspirin (NSAID) and IV Immunoglobin.
  • GCA is treated with high and low-dose steroids.
  • Corticosteroids are used in GCA to improve the visual acuity of the patient.
  • There is a severe danger of blindness in untreated patients.

 

Option D: It is medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis in young adults.

  • Polyarteritis Nodusa is necrotizing vasculitis involving medium-sized vessels in young adults, predominately male.
  • It spares pulmonary arteries.
  • Clinical features:
    • Constitutional:  weight loss, fever, fatigue
    • Musculoskeletal: arthritis, myalgias, arthralgias
    • Renal: hypertension,  renal failure
    • CNS: peripheral neuropathies, mononeuritis multiplex, stroke
    • GI: abdominal pain, cholecystitis
    • Skin: palpable purpura, ulceration
    • Lab findings :
      • Elevated ESR
      • Hepatitis B surface antigen (in 30% of cases)
  • Treatment:
    • Corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide
    • Anti-viral therapy for hepatitis B-related PAN

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child was brought with complaints of abdominal distension with a history of intermittent fever, recurrent lung infections, difficulty in walking in the form of repeated falls, difficulty in coordinating movements, an inability to move the eyes vertically, poor muscle tone, severe liver disease, and interstitial lung disease and multiple episodes of tonic-clonic seizures since last 1 year. She also had a younger sibling having similar complaints of abdominal distension and developmental delay. On examination, the patient had hepatosplenomegaly, a global developmental delay with mild mental retardation. A bone marrow examination was done, which showed characteristic lipid-laden foam cells. Lysosomal enzyme studies confirmed the Deficiency of an enzyme. Identify which of the following is responsible for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acid Sphingomyelinase

The given clinical features and diagnostic tests confirm the diagnosis of Niemann pick disease.

Deficient enzyme

Disease

Acid Sphingomyelinase

Niemann pick disease

Hexosaminidase A

Tay-sachs disease

Ceramidase

Farber disease

Arylsulfatase B

Maroteaux – Lamy syndrome
  • Niemann-Pick disease is an inherited disease that affects lipid metabolism.
  • It is divided into four main types: type A, type B, type C1, and type C2
  • Types A and B occur when acid sphingomyelinase (ASM) isn’t properly produced in the white blood cells. ASM is an enzyme that helps remove fats in all the cells of your body.
  • Sphingomyelin, the fat that ASM removes, can build up in your cells when ASM isn't properly breaking it down. When sphingomyelin builds up, cells begin to die, and organs stop functioning correctly.
  • Individuals with Niemann-Pick disease types C1 and C2 have problems with speech and swallowing difficulties that worsen over time. Affected individuals often experience a progressive decline in intellectual function, and about one-third have seizures. People with these types may survive into adulthood.

Option B: Hexosaminidase

  • Tay–Sachs Disease is caused by a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to a build-up of GM2 ganglioside within cells. Notably, the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside leads to the destruction of nerve cells. Signs and symptoms include neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and the appearance of onion-skin lysosomes on EM biopsy.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Ceramidase

  • Acid ceramidase deficiency is a spectrum of disorders that includes a rare lysosomal storage disorder called Farber disease and a rare epileptic disorder called spinal muscular atrophy with progressive myoclonic epilepsy.

Option D: Arylsulfatase B

  • A deficiency of arylsulfatase B is associated with skeletal and growth malformations, termed the Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome. The characteristic skeletal dysplasia includes short stature, dysostosis multiplex and degenerative joint disease. Other clinical findings may include cardiac valve disease, reduced pulmonary function, hepatosplenomegaly, sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, sleep apnea, corneal clouding, carpal tunnel disease, and inguinal or umbilical hernia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old army man presented to our hospital with complaints of breathlessness, mostly on exertion, dry cough and episodes of hemoptysis for the past 18 months. A digital chest radiograph was labelled normal from the outside. Still, on careful observation, bilateral lower lobe infiltration was observed, and then HRCT was advised, which showed early bronchiectatic changes in both lungs. Pulmonary function testing demonstrated a decrease in lung capacity with mild airflow. These characteristic Bronchiectatic features with dry cough are most commonly seen with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tuberculosis

  • Bronchiectasis is defined as permanent abnormal dilation of bronchi and bronchioles.
  • The hallmark of this disease is a copious amount of productive cough and, i.e. the copious amount of sputum, which is yellowish-green in color.
  • The cause is persistent infection by opportunistic organisms in the dilated bronchial tree.
  • On the other hand, bronchiectasis sicca or dry bronchiectasis is a rare condition that comprises all bronchiectasis features but the absence of a copious amount of sputum.
  • The most important causes are airway obstruction, cigarette smoking, rheumatic and systemic diseases, pulmonary infections (e.g. tuberculosis), cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Other infectious organisms associated with bronchiectasis sicca are P. aeruginosa, H. influenza, S.pneumoniae, and S. aureus.
  • Common clinical manifestations include cough, hemoptysis, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and fatigue.

  • HRCT chest shows abnormal dilation of the tracheal and bronchial tree; it is present without infective sputum and occurs due to tuberculosis.
  • A dry cough with hemoptysis is the typical presentation.

Option B: Pertussis

  • Pertussis is an acute respiratory infection characterized by severe spasmodic coughing, not seen in this case.
  • The complications of pertussis are bacterial pneumonia, seizures, brain inflammation, and death.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis

  • Cystic fibrosis can result in bronchiectasis and bronchiectasis sicca, but it is more commonly found in younger adults or children.

Option D: Kartagener syndrome

  • Kartagener syndrome can result in bronchiectasis and bronchiectasis sicca.
  • It comprise of a triad of bronchiectasis, situs inversus and sinusitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient who complains of breathlessness on exertion associated with a productive cough has come up for a consult. On auscultation, bilateral basal inspiratory fine crackles. What is the next best step to confirm a diagnosis of ILD?
questions.solution:
Option B: HRCT

  • High-resolution computed tomography is superior to the plain chest x-ray for early detection and confirmation of suspected ILD.
  • In addition, HRCT allows better assessment of the extent and distribution of disease.
  • Ideally, a lung biopsy should be done, but in the appropriate clinical setting, HRCT may be sufficiently characteristic to preclude the need for a lung biopsy.

Option A: Chest X-ray

  • Chest X-ray is a good initial test to assess the lungs grossly for any other pathology, but it is not the best for studying fibrosis in detail.

Option C: Gallium – 67 DTPA scan

  • Gallium scans are nuclear medicine tests.
  • Gallium salts are absorbed by tumors, inflammation, and both acute and chronic infection, allowing imaging of these pathological processes.
  • Gallium is particularly useful in imaging osteomyelitis involving the spine and in imaging older and chronic infections that may cause a fever of unknown origin.

Option D: MRI

  • A magnetic resonance image could differentiate areas of reversible active inflammation from irreversible fibrosis, but the best imaging modality for visualizing fibrosis is HRCT.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female who had nacho cheese the night before presented to the emergency department with complaints of diplopia, followed by dyspnoea, chest tightness, congestion and dysphagia. The patient was resuscitated, and initial investigations were done. The edrophonium tensilon test and lumbar puncture came out to be negative. The botulinum toxin test was positive. The most potent toxin produced in the given condition is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Botulinum Toxin A

  • Eight antigenically distinct Clostridium botulinum toxins are known: A, B, C (alpha), C (beta), D, E, F, and G.
  • Types A, B, E and rarely F cause human disease.
  • Toxins A and B are the most potent, and consuming small amounts of food contaminated with these types has resulted in full-blown disease.
  • During the last 20 years, toxin A has been the most common cause of food-borne outbreaks; toxins B and E follow in frequency.

Option B: Botulinum Toxin C

  • Toxin C causes disease in various animals.

Option C: Botulinum Toxin D

  • Toxin D causes disease in various animals.

Option D: Botulinum Toxin F

  • Toxin F can rarely cause human disease

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman visited our hospital with her son because she had developed feelings of anxiety and sleep disturbance. She had become unable to cook, make telephone calls, and shop without assistance for two years. She had no history of psychiatric disorders. She was given donepezil 5 mg/day and returned for follow-up visits with her husband around once a month. Feelings of anxiety and sleep disturbance showed improvement at the two-month follow-up visit. Which of the following statements are true in her condition ?

choices.text: Onset before 45 years of age is rare
Long-term memory is affected before short term memory
Staining shows Tau protein in senile plaques
MRI shows atrophy in frontal and parietal lobes

questions.solution:
• The first statement is correct. Onset is usually after 65 years of age.
  • Second statement is incorrect, long-term memory gets affected in advanced stages only.
  • Third statement is also incorrect as senile plaques contain amyloid bet (Aβ) and not tau proteins.

The last statement can be argued upon. Alzheimer’s disease is usually described as disease of temporal and parietal lobe and MRI usually shows atrophy in temporal and parietal lobe. Although we must remember that frontal cortex does get involved in the advanced phases

HOW TO REMEMBER: Tau is at Top=extra-cellular and in old age(senile plaques). Long term memory lasts Longer.

questions.text: Sleep disturbances can be caused by a patient's lifestyle. This is commonly referred to as poor sleep hygiene. Universal sleep hygiene focuses on modifiable environmental and lifestyle componentsthat can disrupt sleep, as well as actions that can disrupt sleep Which of the following is not correct advice in this case? which one is not the right advice aboutsleep hygiene?

choices.text: Wake up at the same time
30 mL and lesser amount of alcohol could be useful to induce sleep over long term
Use bed for sleep and sexual activity

questions.solution:
Some basic components of sleep hygiene are:

·Physical exercises should be done on a daily basis (preferably not in the evening)

·Avoid fluid intake and large meals right before bedtime to avoid midday naps.

·Before going to bed, avoid caffeine (e.g., tea, coffee, cola beverages).

·Avoid consuming alcohol on a regular basis (especially avoid use of alcohol as a hypnotic for promoting sleep)

·Sleep in a dark, quiet, and comfortable setting with regular bedtime and wake-up times. Experiment with relaxing techniques.

·When you're in bed, don't use your phone or other electronic gadgets.

·Avoid looking at the clock repeatedly to check the time of sleep onset..

HOW TO REMEMBER : Fact is alcohol cause stupor and coma in high quantities but it disturbs sleep in small quantities and regular use.

questions.text: An A-30-year old male is brought to the hospital with a history of makingobscene phone conversations withtheunknowncompanion on the telephoneand vocally discloses his preoccupations or entices her to discuss her sexual activities. Masturbation generally follows the talk, which is often finished after the contact is broken. He is diagnosed as having Scatology, which is an example of?
questions.solution:
• Scatology is a type of paraphilia and is defined by obscene phone calls with an unknownaccomplice.
  • Tension and excitement build up in anticipation of the phone conversation; the receiver listens while the caller (typically a man) vocally reveals his preoccupations or entices her to discuss her sexual activities.
  • Masturbation typically occurs after the discussion has been stopped.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male presents to the clinic by her mother with the complaint of poor speech development. On examination, the child has difficulty concentrating and communicating and has poor speech development. His mother also reports that he has no friends and spends most of the day looking at his own hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Autism

This child displays all three fundamental symptoms of autism, including:

  1. Social interaction impairment (difficulty forming friends)

  2. Communication impairment

  3. Repetitive behavior.

  • Stereotyped conduct is a term that refers to the way people act in certain situations (spend most time seeing their own hands).

Clinical features of Autism:

  1. Impairment in social interaction (Reciprocal social skills poor).

  2. Poor eye contact

  3. Lack of social smile and anticipatory posture absent.

  4. Poor attachment to parents and others

  5. Restricted, repeated & stereotype behaviors: Repetitive plays, Stereotyped movements like hand wringing, spinning, and head banging

  6. Impairment of communication and language: Delayed language milestones, motor milestones normal

  7. The higher threshold for pain and less/no sensations for spinning movements.

  8. Self-destructive behaviors (biting, scratching, head banging)

  9. Abnormal dermatoglyphics(fingerprints)

Option B: ADHD

  • In ADHD, there are inattentive spells and hyperkinetic symptoms.

  • This child meets the criteria for autism disorder.

Option C: Specific learning disability

  • Specific learning disorders are neurodevelopmental disorders typically diagnosed in early school-aged children, although they may not be recognized until adulthood.

  • They are characterized by persistent impairment in at least one of three major areas: reading, written expression, and/or math.

  • This child meets the criteria for autism disorder.

Option D: Tourette syndrome

  • Motor tics characterize Tourette syndrome.

  • Inattentive spells are not seen.

  • This child meets the criteria for autism disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant chemotherapy after mastectomy?

choices.text: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy
There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Option B: Size > 1cm & lymph node positive

  • Chemotherapy given after mastectomy is called adjuvant Chemotherapy.
  • Not all patients with breast cancer need Chemotherapy, but several factors play a role in deciding Chemotherapy.
  • Indications of Adjuvant therapy:
    • Size > 1cm
    • Lymph node positive
    • Size > 0.5cm and lymph node negative with adverse prognostic factor
  • Adverse prognostic factors are
    • High histological grade
    • Lymphovascular
    • HER-2-NEU positive.

Option A: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy

  • The presence of malignant cells in biopsy is indicative of neoplasm.
  • It gives no clue whether the patient will benefit from adjuvant Chemotherapy.

Option C: Family history of breast cancer

  • Multiple family members with a history of breast cancer indicate familial breast cancer.

Option D: Adjuvant Chemotherapy is not advisable for this patient

  • Adjuvant Chemotherapy is indicated in patients with positive lymph nodes post-surgery.
  • It is also indicated in patients who are at high risk for recurrence.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented to the casualty complaining of swelling in the right side of the neck region. After reading some information online, he is worried that he has anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. A small, solitary nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid was noted on physical examination, and FNAC reveals follicular adenoma. Which of the following is the best surgery for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Right hemithyroidectomy

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid:

  • Seen in Iodine deficient areas
  • Most common  malignancy in long-standing goiter
  • Common among the fifth to the sixth decade and in females
  • Involves the mutation of:
    • PAX – 8/ PPAR -1
    • PTEN
    • P-53
    • RAS
  • The patient presents with the following findings:
    • A sudden increase in the size of swelling
    • Minimal/no pain over the swelling unless a hemorrhage into the nodule has occurred
  • No evidence of compression of the trachea, esophagus or RLN
  • In <1% of cases, follicular cancers may be hyperfunctioning leading patients to present with signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Lymphatic spread is not seen (So lymph nodes need not be removed during surgery). It is most commonly spread hematogenously. The most common site of metastasis is the Bones (Thoracic vertebra > Ribs > Pelvis > skull) and lungs.
  • Follicular carcinoma thyroid leads to pulsatile secondary and Renal cell carcinoma (osteolytic and hypervascular)
  • FNAC cannot differentiate follicular adenoma from follicular carcinoma. Hence hemithyroidectomy is done initially for solitary nodule thyroid diagnosed as follicular adenoma, and the specimen is sent for histopathological examination. Complete thyroidectomy is done when there is evidence of vascular invasion / capsular invasion in a biopsy.

Option A: Enucleation

  • The removal of the nodule alone by enucleation is associated with a greater risk of bleeding and/or spillage and spread of the tumor. Therefore, the most effective removal is done by thyroidectomy (hemithyroidectomy to remove the specimen and diagnosis)

Option B: Sub-total thyroidectomy

  • Treatment of Follicular adenoma is hemithyroidectomy for taking specimens in order to differentiate between adenoma and carcinoma. This is followed by total thyroidectomy if follicular carcinoma is seen.

Option D: Near-total thyroidectomy

  • Hemithyroidectomy is the recommended course of treatment for Follicular Adenoma in order to get a specimen and distinguish between Adenoma and Carcinoma. If follicular cancer is discovered, a total thyroidectomy is performed after this.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not seen in a patient of Grave's disease?

choices.text: Subperiosteal new bone formation in metacarpals

questions.solution:
Option A: Enophthalmos

  • Enophthalmos is defined as the posterior displacement of the globe of the eye in an anterioposterior plane within the orbit.
  • This is caused by one of the following factors:
    • Enlargement of the orbit
    • Reduction of the orbital contents
    • Shrinkage or contracture of orbital contents
  • The patient presents facial asymmetry, double vision, dry eyes, droopy upper eyelid (ptosis), difficulty focusing, and deep superior sulcus.
  • However, the ophthalmopathy seen in Graves' disease is called exophthalmos.

Option B: Gynecomastia

  • Most commonly seen in young boys.
  • Gynecomastia occurs in hyperthyroidism due to increased thyroid hormone-mediated effects:
    • Increased aromatase activity in the peripheral tissue causes the conversion of androgens to estrogen.
    • Increased sex hormone binding globulin, which decreases the free testosterone levels causing gynecomastia.

Option C: Subperiosteal new bone formation in metacarpals

  •  Acropachy is defined as the thickening of extremities manifested by a triad of the following:
    • Subperiosteal new bone formation in metacarpals
    • Digital clubbing
    • Soft tissue swelling of hand and feet

Option D: Pretibial myxedema

  • Dermopathy is caused by the deposition of glycosaminoglycans leading to the thickness of the skin in the pretibial region and dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought in with complaints of abdominal mass, blueberry muffin spots on the skin, proptosis, and periorbital ecchymosis. Upon further evaluation, urinary catecholamines and their metabolites were elevated. Which of the following is incorrect about the described condition?

choices.text: Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood
It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option B: Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood

  • This is incorrect statement.
  • The above-described clinical condition is neuroblastoma

NEUROBLASTOMA

  • Most common extracranial solid tumor in infants and children, arises from neural crest cells
  • Malignant neoplasm of the sympathetic nervous system
  • Over 80% of cases are present before the age of 4, and the peak incidence is 2 years
  • It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain
  • Most common site: 65% occur in the abdomen, with 50% localized to the adrenal medulla, neck (5%), chest (20%), or pelvis (5%)
  • Exhibit spontaneous regression completely, especially in stage 4S with a spontaneous cure
  • Mostly occur sporadically, but 1% to 2% are familial
  • Homer Wright pseudorosettes are characteristic of neuroblastoma
  • Metastasizes to the liver, lungs, cortices of long bones, bone marrow, regional or distant lymph nodes, skull, eyes, and skin
  • Clinical features
    • Asymptomatic
    • Constitutional symptoms
    • Enlarging mass, Pain, Abdominal distension
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Respiratory distress
    • Bladder or bowel disturbance (diarrhea) - Tumor metabolites (VIP)
    • Horner syndrome - Stellate ganglion involvement
    • Periorbital swelling and proptosis (raccoon eyes) - ocular metastases
    • Long bone pain and tenderness- bony metastasis
    • Rubbery lymph nodes in the neck or axilla - Lymph node metastases
    • Limping, paralysis or weakness, and failure to thrive - bone marrow metastases
    • Palpable skull nodule - skull metastases
    • Blueberry muffin syndrome (blue subcutaneous nodules) - skin metastases
    • Paraneoplastic syndromes (intractable diarrhea)
    • Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • Diagnosis
    • Elevated levels of
      • Urinary catecholamines and their metabolites (vanillylmandelic acid or homovanillic acid)
      • Lactate dehydrogenase (>1500 U/ml)
      • Ferritin >142 ng/mL
      • Neuron specific enolase (>100 ng/mL)
    • Histology - Undifferentiated small round blue cells
    • Modified Shimda Classification - Helps to predict prognosis
  • Treatment
    • Localized neuroblastoma: Excision
    • Unresectable tumor: Biopsy, initially treated by chemotherapy and radiotherapy, followed by surgical resection of residual tumor
    • Disseminated disease: Chemotherapy (Cyclophosphamide, vincristine, dacarbazine, doxorubicin, Cisplatin)

Other Options

Option A: Homer Wright pseudorosettes are characteristic

  • Homer Wright’s pseudorosettes are classically seen on the histological examination of the tumor.

Option C: May undergo spontaneous regression

  • Some neuroblastoma variants also undergo spontaneous regression.

Option D: It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain

  • Neuroblastoma can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain from the cervical sympathetic ganglia to the thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic ganglia.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female was admitted with a complaint of escalating abdominal pain, increased abdominal circumference, and recurrent diarrhea for 2 months. He has a history of consumption of bush teas for 5 months to reduce weight. Physical examination revealed mild jaundice, distended abdomen, and tenderness on RUQ. Laboratory results showed WBC 6.82 × 109/L, Hb 122 g/L, HbsAg (-), ALT 66 U/L, AST 81 U/L, serum total bilirubin 39.7 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 10.6 μmol/L, and ALB 32.8 g/L. CT scan of the abdomen revealed moderate ascites, hepatomegaly, delayed enhancement of parenchyma, and obscure hepatic veins. Which of the following drugs is effective in improving survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Defibrotide

VENO OCCLUSIVE DISEASE:

  • In western countries, Bone marrow transplantation is the commonest risk factor.
  • Bush teas and cytosine arabinoside are risk factors, but mushroom poisoning is not a risk factor.
  • There is no difference between Veno occlusive disease and Budd-Chiari syndrome except for the site of occlusion.
  • The investigation of choice for diagnosis – Biopsy.
  • Treatment of choice: If hepatic failure is present – Liver transplantation.
  • If there is no hepatic failure – side-to-side portocaval shunt.
  • One drug is effective in improving survival – DEFIBROTIDE.

Option A: Feature

  • It is an antioxidant used for the diagnosis as well as treatment of males in fertility.
  • Common side effects are allergic reactions, asthma, and high blood pressure.

Option B: Tenofovir

  • Tenofovir is commonly used to treat hepatitis B.
  • It is also used in the treatment and prevention of AIDS.

Option D: Ibutilide

  • Ibutilide is a class 3 anti-arrhythmic drug.
  • It is used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted for appetite loss, nausea, and back pain. A physical examination revealed right hypochondriac tenderness and obvious jaundice.  MRCP revealed dilated intrahepatic and common hepatic bile ducts, distended gallbladder, and erosion of less than 1/3 of the circumference of common hepatic duct. What is the best next step in the management?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option A: Partial cholecystectomy + T- tube drainage

  • According to the Csendes classification, the best treatment for Mirizzi syndrome type II is partial cholecystectomy + T- tube drainage
  • Mirizzi’s syndrome
    • Obstruction of the bile ducts due to a severe pericholecystic inflammation secondary to the impaction of a stone in the infundibulum of the gallbladder is known as Mirizzi’s syndrome.
    • The prerequisite for this syndrome, characterized by gallbladder disease causing obstructive jaundice, include:
      • A cystic duct that courses parallel to the common hepatic duct
      • An impacted stone in the gallbladder neck or cystic duct
