      • Obstruction of the common hepatic duct is caused by the stone or inflammatory response. The resultant inflammation can cause a cholecystocholedochal fistula.
      • It usually presents as jaundice or recurrent cholangitis. The presence of Mirizzi syndrome obliterates the triangle of Calot.

Other Options

Option B: Conservative management

  • The most common complication of Mirizzi syndrome is cholecystobiliary or cholecysto-enteric fistula formation due to prolonged inflammation.
  • Therefore, surgical management is required.

Option C: Partial cholecystectomy alone

  • Partial cholecystectomy alone is the treatment of choice for type I choledochal cysts.

Option D: Partial cholecystectomy + Bilioenteric anastomosis

  • The treatment of choice for type IV and V Partial cholecystectomy + Bilioenteric anastomosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?

choices.text: Fair skin(skin type I and II)

questions.solution:
Option C: Viral hepatitis B

  • Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma (order of frequency from greatest to smallest):
    • Viral hepatitis B
    • Viral hepatitis C
    • Alcoholic cirrhosis
    • Smoking
    • Aflatoxin produced by Aspergillus species
    • Vinyl chloride
    • Oral contraceptive pill use
    • Sugar
    • NASH (Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis)
    • Hemochromatosis
    • α1 Antitrypsin deficiency disease
    • Copper deficiency disease

Option A: Fair skin(skin type I and II)

  • It is a risk factor for Basal cell carcinoma
  • Other factors include
    • Intermittent UV exposure
    • Personal history of BCC
    • Prior treatment with ionizing radiation

Option B: Barrett's Esophagus

  • It is a risk factor for Esophageal adenocarcinoma
  • Other factors include
    • Acid-peptic disorders
    • Motor disorders of the esophagus
    • Other malignancies
    • Medications, environmental exposures
    • Diet
    • Nutrition

Option D: Human papillomavirus(HPV)

  • It is a risk factor for Cervical cancer
  • Other factor includes
    • Smoking
    • Weak Immune system
    • Having Multiple Sexual partners
    • Long term Use of birth control pill

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented to us with c/o epigastric pain and weight loss. He also gave a history of dyspepsia and progressively increasing jaundice with clay-colored stools with no history of fever or pruritus. On physical examination, there was evidence for icterus without any palpable neck lymphadenopathy. Abdominal and chest CT scan confirmed the presence of a tumor measuring 50 mm in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) also indicated that the tumor was in contact with both the SMA and the SMV, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed adenocarcinoma. On the basis of these clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed with Unresectable Locally Advanced Pancreatic cancer. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to the patient to increase his survival rate?
questions.solution:
• Gemcitabine is currently the standard of care for patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer
  • Gemcitabine was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for use in pancreatic cancer in 1996.
  • In patients with unresectable pancreatic cancer, gemcitabine results in symptomatic improvement, improved pain control and performance status, and weight gain.
  • Prior to gemcitabine, 5-fluorouracil was used as the standard treatment for unresectable pancreatic cancer

questions.text: Where is Killian's dehiscence located?

choices.text: Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Option B: Between Inferior constrictor 

  • Killian’s dehiscence is a weakness located between the inferior constrictor muscle. 

  • The dehiscence area of muscular weakness is a triangle zone that is formed between the two pharyngeal and esophageal muscles, the inferior pharyngeal constrictor, and the cricopharyngeus. This zone is located in the middle of the pharynx. The surrounding muscles in this area are weak, which gives this region its distinctive appearance. In medical terminology, the term "dehiscence" refers to an opening that has gaped open, burst open, or split apart along natural or sutured lines. This type of hole can also be called a "burst open." 
  • Between the muscle fibres of the thyropharyngeus and the cricopharyngeus, there is a dehiscence that is known as Killian's dehiscence. This dehiscence may be found between the two muscles. The protrusion of mucosa and submucosa that arises as a result of Killian's dehiscence is referred to as Zenker's diverticulum. 
  • One can view the dehiscence of Laimer's in the region below the cricopharyngeus. 

Option A: Below Superior constrictor 

  • Killian's dehiscence is located between the inferior constrictor muscle. 

Option C: Above the cricopharyngeal muscle 

  • It is located below and lateral to the cricopharyngeal muscle. 

Option D: Below the upper 1/3rd of the smooth muscle of the esophagus 

  • Killian’s dehiscence is an area of muscular weakness in the neck.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical OPD with an epigastric mass, early satiety, and weight loss for the last 3 months. Abdominal examination revealed an irregular mass in the epigastric region 4×5cm, moving with respiration, and hard in consistency. Endoscopic Biopsy from an ulcer-proliferative lesion in the greater curvature revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is a manifestation of carcinoma stomach?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • Most patients have advanced stage III or IV at the time of diagnosis.
  • The most common symptom is weight loss, reduced food intake due to anorexia and early satiety.
  • Chronic occult blood loss occurs, leading to Iron deficiency anemia and heme-positive stools.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes such as Trousseau's syndrome (thrombophlebitis), acanthosis nigricans, and peripheral neuropathy may occur.
  • Cervical, Left supraclavicular ( referred to as Virchow's node called Troisier's sign), and axillary (Irish )lymph nodes may be enlarged.
  • Malignant ascites or pleural effusion or aspiration pneumonitis may be present.
  • The abdominal mass shows a large tumour (T4 tumour), liver metastasis, or carcinomatosis (including Krukenberg's tumour of the ovary).
  • Palpable umbilical nodes (Sister Mary Joseph's node) are pathognomic of advanced disease.
  • Rectal examination shows drop metastasis or rectal shelf of Blumer in the pouch of Douglas.

Option A: Troisier's sign

  • The Troisier sign shows an enlargement of a left-sided supraclavicular lymph node. The enlarged supraclavicular lymph node is known as a Virchow node. It is suggestive of gastric malignancy.

Option B: Trousseau's syndrome

  • Trousseau syndrome is an acquired blood clotting disorder that results in migratory thrombophlebitis (inflammation of a vein due to a blood clot)
  • It is often associated with gastric carcinoma.

Option C: Irish node

  • Gastric carcinoma may cause an enlargement of an axillary lymph node called the Irish node.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with colicky pain in the lower abdomen. He also complains of absolute constipation. After performing a physical examination, an X-ray is ordered. The abdominal X-ray findings are given below:



Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Colonoscopic detorsion followed by elective sigmoid colectomy

  • Given Abdominal X-ray: Coffee bean sign / Omega sign / Bent inner tube suggestive of Sigmoid volvulus.
  • Gastrograffin enema shows a narrowing at the site of volvulus and a pathognomonic bird's beak
  • Treatment of sigmoid volvulus:
    • Colonoscopic detorsion
    • After 3 days of sigmoid colectomy (as the risk of recurrence is high)

Option A: Colonoscopy detorsion

  • Colonoscopy detorsion is one of the steps in the management of the volvulus
  • However, the process should be followed by elective sigmoid colectomy

Option B: Elective sigmoid colectomy

  • Elective sigmoid colectomy is done only after the colonoscopy detorsion

Option C: Air enema

  • Air enema is helpful in intussusception cases but not in the case of volvulus

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of mucus-containing diarrhea and bleeding per rectum from the last 3 months. On presentation patient's vitals are blood pressure of 90/70 mmHg, pulse rate of 110 beats/min, and respiratory rate of 21/min. On further evaluation, colonoscopy findings are consistent with ulcerative colitis. The patient does not respond to medical therapy. What will be the treatment of choice in this case?

choices.text: Colectomy + manual proctectomy + ileoanal pouch anastomosis

questions.solution:
Option C: Proctocolectomy with ileoanal pouch anastomosis

  • Clinical signs: Mucus containing diarrhea and bleeding per rectum are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis- a procedure of choice for patients who wish to avoid a permanent ileostomy
  • Emergent operation
    • In patients with fulminant colitis or toxic megacolon.
    • Total abdominal colectomy with end ileostomy (with or without a mucus fistula) is recommended.
  • Elective operation
    • For patients with an increased risk of malignancy and those who are intractable to medical treatment.
      • Total proctocolectomy with end ileostomy - the gold standard for treating patients with chronic ulcerative colitis.
      • Total proctocolectomy with continent ileostomy (Koch's pouch).
      • Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis: The procedure of choice for patients who wish to avoid a permanent ileostomy.
      • Abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis: For patients with indeterminate colitis and rectal sparing.
  • The diagram below shows the proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis.

 

Option A: Colectomy with ileostomy

  • The colon and rectum are both removed during this treatment. Proctocolectomy is regarded as the standard of care.
  • The surgeon might make a stoma or abdominal wall opening if the entire colon is removed.
  • The stoma allows the lower small intestine's tip to pass through.

Option B: Colectomy + manual proctectomy + ileoanal pouch anastomosis

  • Although it's one of the treatment of chronic ulcerative colitis, it is not the treatment of choice.

Option D: Ileorectal anastomosis

  • Abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis is done for patients with indeterminate colitis and rectal sparing.

questions.text: A 7-year-old with a history of bed wetting and recurrent urinary tract infections is brought with complaints of left-sided abdominal pain that intensifies on urination. She has a fever of 101 F°. Left costovertebral angle tenderness is present. IV pyelogram is conducted, and urinary tract infection is suspected. How would this condition be treated?

choices.text: If the function of the upper pole ureter is normal, then no intervention is needed, and for the lower pole ureter, ureterovesicoplasty can be done
Both the poles should be excised and reimplanted into the bladder as the patient may become susceptible to UTI more frequently
For upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed.
The lower pole ureter is prone to develop Ureterocele, so it should be excised in any case

questions.solution:
Option C: For upper pole hydronephrosis with no function, an Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed

  • In the above-mentioned clinical scenario, the patient is a 7-year-old female child who has presented with left-sided abdominal pain, fever and bed wetting. She has had a recurrent UTI since childhood, and her examination and imaging results reveal duplication of her left ureter.
  • Duplication of the ureter (AD)
  • Most Common congenital anomaly of the upper urinary tract.
  • The mode of inheritance is autosomal dominant.
  • More common in females.
  • Unilateral duplication is more common than bilateral.
  • The left side is more commonly involved.
  • Yo-Yo effect in the fused ureter (incomplete duplication) is seen.
  • Complete duplication occurs when there are two separate ureteric buds.
  • In complete duplication, the upper pole Ureteral orifice in the bladder is caudal and medial to the lower pole of the Ureteral orifice (Weigert Meyer rule).
  • Upper pole ureter is associated with Ureterocele, Lower pole ureter is associated with Short intravesical length of the ureter( risk of VUR).
  • Diagnosis:
  • IVP shows duplication In most cases.
  • Treatment:
  • If the function of the Upper pole ureter is normal- Excision and reimplantation into the bladder.
  • If the function of the Upper pole ureter is impaired- an upper pole nephrectomy is done.
  • Lower pole ureter- Ureterovesicoplasty.

 

Option A: If the function of the upper pole ureter is normal, then no intervention is needed, and for the lower pole ureter, ureterovesicoplasty can be done

  • In case the function of the entire duplicate ureter is intact, with no symptoms.
  • No intervention is required.

Option B: Both the poles should be Excised and reimplanted into the bladder as the patient may become susceptible to UTI more common

  • There is no need to excise both poles.
  • Only the dysfunctional part needs to be excised and treated.

Option D: The lower pole ureter is prone to develop Ureterocele, so it should be excised.

  • The lower pole should only be excised and treated if any pathology is present.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presented to the local hospital with complaints of urinary retention with severe pain and burning sensation in the lower urinary tract since yesterday. He also has a poor urinary stream, nocturia, and post-void dribbling. The vital signs and Laboratory tests were normal. On digital rectal examination, there is a palpable, hard, nodular prostate with an obliterated median sulcus. Ultrasound reports showed an enlarged prostate of weight 93 grams. His ratio of free: total PSA is estimated as 20%. The ultrasound of this patient is given below. What diagnosis does the doctor suspect in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Benign prostatic hyperplasia

  • It is the suspected case of benign prostatic hyperplasia due to urinary symptoms such as urinary retention, poor urinary stream, nocturia, and postvoid dribbling in the old-aged male.
  • Poor stream means decreased urine flow with less calibre of the stream.
  • Nocturia is being woken at night by the need to pass urine.
  • Post-void dribbling means falling off the drops after the end of urination.
  • On digital rectal examination, a palpable prostate with smooth muscle hypertrophy is the typical finding of benign prostatic hyperplasia.
  • The normal prostate weight at the age of 60 years is 30 g, but this patient has a 93 g weighted prostate, suggesting hyperplasia.
  • The free total prostate-specific antigen ratio discriminates between prostate carcinoma and benign prostate hyperplasia. If it is < 18%, it is suggestive of carcinoma; if it is > 18 %, it suggests benign prostate hyperplasia, as it is 20% in this patient, indicating benign prostate hyperplasia.       

Option A: Tuberculous prostate

  • As there is no history and symptoms of tuberculosis, this disease does not correlate with the patient's condition.
  • It is diagnosed by urine examination for ZN staining and culture of tubercle bacilli from the first-morning urine sample. 

Option C: Acute prostatitis

  • It is the inflammation of the prostate due to any lower abdominal trauma or secondary to urinary tract infection.
  • On palpation, there is warm and tender prostate. Leukocytosis is the typical lab finding.

Option D: Carcinoma of the prostate

  • The free total ratio of PSA is the differentiating point between carcinoma and benign prostate hyperplasia.
  • If it is > 18%, it is suggestive of benign prostate hyperplasia as this patient has a 20% ratio, so it excludes carcinoma of the prostate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has been experiencing lower abdominal pain and frequent urination for seven months. She has no other symptoms, and tests have been inconclusive. Cystoscopy revealed a finding, what is true about the management of this condition?

choices.text: Conservative management; Has a good prognosis
Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

questions.solution:
Option B: Application of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder

  • The patient disguised is suffering from interstitial cystitis, and the treatment is the instillation of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the distended bladder under anaesthesia. Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and pelvic pain.
  • The pain can be very uncomfortable or very mild.
  • The ailment is a member of the painful bladder syndrome group of illnesses.
  • Interstitial cystitis is also called Hunner’s ulcer.
  • Chronic Pancystitis characterize it.
  • There is Infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • It is more common in females.
  • Its aetiology is unknown.
  • There is the presence of a linear bleeding ulcer in the fundus (involving mucosa).
  • Clinical features:
    • Initial symptom - Increased frequency
    • The pain increased by distention of the bladder & relieved by micturition.
    • Bladder capacity is reduced to 30 – 50ml.
    • Diagnosis
      • On Cystoscopy – the presence of a linear bleeding ulcer in the fundus.
  • To rule out malignancy:
    • Urinary cytology
    • Biopsy
  • Treatment
    • Difficult and unsatisfactory.
    • Bladder distention under anaesthesia.
    • Installation of dimethyl-sulfoxide into the bladder.

Option A: Conservative management; has a good prognosis

  • Interstitial cystitis is not managed conservatively. Its treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory, involving the distention of the bladder and the instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide.

Option C: Surgery followed by chemotherapy

  • The treatment of hunger ulcers is the instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide into the bladder. The bladder is distended under anaesthesia.
  • No surgery followed by chemotherapy is needed.

Option D: Bladder resection under anaesthesia

  • The bladder is distinct under anaesthesia but not rejected; dimethyl sulfoxide is instilled into the blood, but the treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory.

questions.text: During Orchiopexy for undescended testes, accidental ligation of which artery compromises the blood supply to the testes?
questions.solution:
• The anatomy of the adult testis reflects its embryonic development. Testis arise from portions of the wolffian bodies on the genital ridge below the kidneys at around the 10th thoracic level; therefore, the major blood vessels for the testes arises high up in the retroperitoneum from the aorta just below the renal arteries and are termed the internal spermatic arteries or testicular arteries

  • Secondary blood supply to the testes comes from the artery of the vas deferens, and a small branch from the epigastric artery termed the external spermatic artery or cremasteric artery which forms during descent of the testes from the abdomen to the scrotum.

  • The surgical importance of this phenomenon is that operations involving the region of the renal arteries may sacrifice the internal spermatic artery
  • The vascular and genital ductal structures leave the testis from the mediastinum in the posterosuperior portion and travel through the scrotal neck into the inguinal canal
  • The venous drainage of the testicle initially begins as a pampiniform plexus coalescing into the gonadal or testicular veins. On the right, the vein drains directly into the venacava and on the left , the vein drains into the the left renal vein

questions.text: A 43-year-old male race-course farrier presents to his family doctor complaining of persistent pain and numbness, fatigue, and frequent cramps extending bilaterally throughout the upper limbs (especially on the right side). Colour flow Doppler USG is prescribed, which reveals bilateral functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein, which is more severe on the right side. A subsequent angiography-assisted CT scan shows the presence of right subclavian venous thrombosis. What is likely the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation
Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

questions.solution:
Correct options

Option C: Anticoagulation therapy followed by catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy

  • In this case, as the patient is farrier, he overuses his arm. History of overuse of the arm and functional stenosis of the axillary-subclavian vein suggests the diagnosis of Axillary-subclavian venous thrombosis (ASVT). 
  • Axillary-subclavian venous thrombosis (ASVT) is a condition in which the blood vessel of the upper arm is compressed by a nearby rib or muscle and results in blood clots.
  • ASVT may develop in the subclavian vein or axillary vein.
  • ASVT is a form of DVT that usually results from sudden injury or overuse.
  • Primary ASVT:
    • Less common.
    • History of performing repetitive and prolonged motion activities, leading to damage to the subclavian vein, usually where it passes between the first rib and head of the clavicle.
  • Secondary ASVT:
    • More common.
    • Associated with an easily identified cause such as an indwelling catheter or a hypercoagulable state.
  • Treatment:
    • Once ASVT is diagnosed, anticoagulation therapy should be initiated in order to prevent pulmonary embolism (PE) and decrease symptoms. 
    • Patients diagnosed with acute symptomatic primary ASVT are candidates for catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy.

Other Options

Option A: IV anticoagulants + Rest should be advised as the provocative factor is his occupation

  • Rest and elevation of the limb are the initial management for ASVT.
  • As in this case, the patient's symptoms are severe; only rest cannot cure the damage. 
  • So the patient must be given IV anticoagulants along with catheter-directed Thrombolytic therapy.

Option B: Treated with IV anticoagulants alone

  • Anticoagulants are blood thinners and prevent blot clot formation. But already present blood clots are treated by Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy.
  • Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy is used to treat acute ASVT. It dissolves the blood clot that can travel to the lungs and can cause shortness of breath and chest pain and lead to death. 

Option D: Ultrasound-guided embolectomy

  • Ultrasound-guided embolectomy is performed when the blood clot has reached to lungs and causes pulmonary embolism.
  • As the patient has not reached this stage, catheter-directed thrombolysis will be used for the treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with the complaint of progressively worsening ulcers in the fingertips of both hands and feet for 4 years, along with intermittent claudication of the feet whenever he is walking. After taking history, he told the doctor that he had "migratory superficial thrombophlebitis." He is a  20-pack-year smoker who is not a diabetic; his cholesterol levels are normal according to him, and his ECG findings were normal. What would be the best way for this patient to arrest the development of his disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Smoking cessation

  • This clinical feature is suggestive of Buerger’s disease, and the only measure that can stop disease progression is the cessation of smoking
  • Buerger’s disease also known as thromboangiitis obliterans, is characterized by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized arteries.
  • It is associated with superficial thrombophlebitis and Raynaud’s phenomenon in a smoker of usually less than 30 years of age.
  • The serious complication is amputation if the disease is not controlled.

Option A: Aspirin

  • It is a platelet aggregation inhibitor, usually beneficial in patients with atheromatous disease.
  • It has very little to no role in thromboangiitis obliterans.

Option B: Good glycaemic control

  • It is useful in patients with a disease due to increased blood sugar levels.
  • Because Buerger’s disease has no diabetic component, glycaemic control is useless in these patients.

Option C: Blood cholesterol control

  • It is useful in patients suffering from a disease due to the formation of atheromatous plaques in the vessel walls, resulting from increased cholesterol levels.
  • Cholesterol levels are normal in Buerger’s disease, so they don’t have a role in disease cessation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female smoker presented with non-small cell lung cancer from the lateral segmental right middle lobar orifice. Preoperative evaluation revealed excellent pulmonary reserve and no evidence of metastatic disease. Mediastinoscopy had negative results. A right vertical axillary thoracotomy revealed a central 3.0 cm adenocarcinoma invading the superior pulmonary vein and the descending pulmonary artery. Hence, the patient was prepared for pneumonectomy. What is the first step when doing a pneumonectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ligate pulmonary artery

  • Pneumonectomy is anatomically more straightforward than lobectomy (in carcinoma bronchus):
    • The pulmonary artery is first dissected, divided, and sutured.
    • The pulmonary veins are then isolated, divided, and sutured.
    • The main bronchus is divided so that no blind stump is usually stapled. 
    • Pneumonectomy indication:
      • Traumatic lung injury
      • Pulmonary tuberculosis
      • Fungal infections of the lung
      • Bronchiectasis
      • Congenital lung disease
      • Bronchial blockage with a destroyed lung
      •  Pulmonary metastases (cancer that has spread to the lungs from another site in the body)

Option A: Ligate the pulmonary vein

  • In carcinoma of bronchus, a pneumonectomy is anatomically simpler than a lobectomy: at first the pulmonary artery is dissected, divided, and sutured before the pulmonary veins are identified, divided, and sutured.

Option C: Divide the bronchus

  • In cases of carcinoma bronchus, a pneumonectomy is more straightforward anatomically than a lobectomy: first, the pulmonary artery is dissected, divided, and sutured; next, the pulmonary veins are isolated, divided, and sutured.
  • Finally, the main bronchus is divided so that no blind stump is left behind.

Option D: Perform lymph node clearance

  • A common medical operation is lobectomy (or pneumonectomy) with lymph node dissection.
  • In each of these procedures, surrounding lymph nodes are also removed to check for potential cancer spread.
  • However, the first step of pneumonectomy is the ligation of the pulmonary artery.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose. The lesion has gradually increased since it first appeared 11 months ago. He is a farmer and lives together with his wife. Examination of the skin shows a nontender lesion at the right medial canthus. An image of the lesion is shown.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Basal cell carcinoma

  • This patient is most likely suffering from basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma is characterized by a slow-growing, locally invasive malignant neoplasm of the skin that arises from basal epithelial cells.
  • It is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinoma develops in sun-exposed areas as a pearly, indurated, nodular, nontender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration, as illustrated in the image below:

  • The subtypes of basal cell carcinoma include nodular basal cell carcinoma and superficial basal cell carcinoma.
  • Nodular basal cell carcinoma mostly involves the face, especially the nose, as shown in the image below:

  • Whereas superficial basal cell carcinoma is characterized by the flat eczematous (scaly) plaque with a pearly border lesion.
  • The superficial basal cell carcinoma variant mostly involves the trunk. This variant is illustrated in the image below:

  • The patient with basal cell carcinoma (BCC) should undergo a full-thickness biopsy of the edge of the lesion for histopathological confirmation of BCC.
  • The standard treatment options include surgical excision with a safety margin and  Mohs micrographic surgery.

Option B: Squamous cell carcinoma

  • Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is the second most common type of skin cancer and is commonly located on the face or neck (the lower lip is a specific location). Sun exposure and smoking present in this patient are risk factors for SCC. Although this patient also has a lesion involving his face, SCC has a different appearance: it is typically a hyperkeratotic nodule or ulcer with crusting that does not heal and bleeds easily. A pearly induration with a rolled border suggests another diagnosis.

Option C: Actinic keratosis

  • While actinic keratosis typically affects patients over 50 and is also associated with sun exposure, it does not manifest as pearly nodules surrounding a central ulcerative depression.
  • Instead, actinic keratosis presents with dry and scaly patches of skin.

Option D: Keratoacanthoma

  • While keratoacanthomas may appear as an erythematous nodule with a central crater, which would be consistent with this patient's lesion, they do not have a pearly appearance or a rolled border. In contrast to this patient's lesion, keratoacanthomas typically grow rapidly over 2–3 months and usually heal without treatment.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with squamous cell carcinoma of her lower lip. The lesion involved the full lower lip and partly skin of the chin. Under general anesthesia, an extended peripheral resection is done. Then, modified extended Karapandzic flaps were used to rebuild the lower lip and tongue mucosa flap to rebuild the vermilion. Which of the following is the most likely advantageous point of the Karapandzic flap?

choices.text: It is a neuromuscular preserving flap

questions.solution:
Option C: Neuromuscular preserving flap

  • This patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip needs reconstructive surgery using tissue flaps to fill the gap by excision of the tumor.
  • This wound can be repaired using a Karapandzic flap, a sensate axial musculocutaneous flap.
  • The Karapandzic flap is based on the superior and inferior labial arteries. It provides good aesthetic effects and is useful for closing one-half to two-thirds of defects of the upper lip  and defects up to three-quarters of the lower lip. The main advantageous point of the Karapandzic flap is that it is a neuromuscular preserving flap.
  • The modalities for the reconstruction of the lip are summarized in the following table:
Cross-lip Flaps Circumoral Advancement Flaps
Lip-Switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap used to repair defects of either the upper or lower lip, based on the superior labial artery
  • Karapandzic flap: Uses a sensate, neuromuscular flap Uses a sensate, neuromuscular flap based on the labial artery.
  • Webster-Bernard repair: Use lateral nasolabial flap with buccal advancement
   

Option A: 2-stage procedure

  • This is not the advantageous point of the Karapandzic flap.

Option B: It can cause Macrostomia

  • This is not the advantageous point of the Karapandzic flap.

Option D: All of the above

  • This is an incorrect option.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the clinic with insidious onset of deep, dull aching pain in the left hand involving distal interphalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and 1st carpometacarpal joints are worsened by activity and improved by rest. The patient also complains of joint stiffness in the morning, lasting less than 30 minutes. There is a sparing of meta-Carpo-phalangeal and wrist joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Osteoarthritis

  • The given clinical scenario has classical features of Osteoarthritis
  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves the distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden's node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard's node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb) of the hand with sparing of metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.
  • It can affect any joint, but weight-bearing joints are most involved (hips, knees, cervical and lumbar spine)

Clinical Presentation:

  • Insidious onset of joint pain
  • A deep dull ache, worsened by activity and improved by rest
  • Stiffness in the morning or after inactivity which lasts for less than 30 minutes
  • Restricted joint motion

Risk Factors:

  • Advanced age (>55 years old)
  • Obesity
  • Trauma

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray findings involve joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, subchondral cysts, and bone spurs
  • Low WBCs in synovial fluid (non-inflammatory arthritis)
  • All blood tests normal

Treatment:

  • Weight loss
  • Exercise and physical therapy
  • Topical or oral NSAIDs

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Involvement of PIP, MCP, Wrist
  • Spared: DIP joint usually
  • Anti-CCP antibodies are positive
  • DMARDs can slow the disease progression

Option C: Ankylosing spondylitis

  • The joint involved in Ankylosing spondylitis is the Sacroiliac joint
  • Hands are spared
  • Associated with HLB27
  • Managed with NSAIDs

Option D: Psoriatic arthritis

  • According to the Caspar criterion, PA involves a distal interphalangeal joint,  Proximal interphalangeal joint, and any joint
  • Associated with psoriasis
  • Pitting of nails is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a crush injury of the lower limb 30 minutes ago. The patient is in severe pain. Limbs appear mottled on the examination. You're an Orthopaedic postgraduate attending the case. What can help you decide between amputation and limb salvage?
questions.solution:
Option C: MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score)

  • Mangled Extremity severity score (MESS) - Tells about the survival of a limb after a crush injury
  • Includes 4 parameters:
  • S –Shock
  • I - Ischemia
  • V -Velocity Of Trauma
  • A -Age of the patient
  • Total score = 11 ≥ 7 limbs cannot survive and requires amputation.

MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score):

Component Points
Skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Low energy(stab, simple fracture)
  • Medium energy(open or multiplex fractures, dislocation)
  • High energy( Crush injury, gunshot wound)
  • Very high energy (same as above plus gross contamination, soft tissue avulsion)

 
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
  • 4
Limb Ischemia (score doubled for ischemia more than 6 hours)
  • Pulse reduced or absent, but perfusion normal
  • Pulseless paresthesia diminished capillary refill
  • Cool, paralyzed, insensate(numb)
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
Shock
  • Systolic blood pressure is always >90mm
  • Transient hypotension
  • Persistent hypotension
  • 0
  • 1
  • 2
AGE (yr)

<30

30-50

>50
  • 0
  • 1
  • 2

Option A: Gustilo Anderson classification

Gustilo Anderson Classification is used to classify open fractures

  • Grade 1: Clean wound of < 1 cm length
  • Grade 2: Wound > 1cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap, or avulsion
  • Grade 3: Wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, comminution, contamination, segmental fractures, Gunshot injuries, or farmhouse injuries

Option B: GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) Score

  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the initial assessment of consciousness in an emergent patient.

Option D: ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support)

  • Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines are used in the assessment and resuscitation of injured patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female comes to the hospital to evaluate a finger deformity. She started experiencing pain and difficulty using her fingers a few weeks ago. She has a long history of rheumatoid arthritis but does not take medicines regularly. Which of the following is correct about the given deformity?
questions.solution:
Option D: Swan neck deformity

  • The deformity given in the radiograph is Swan's neck deformity.

  • This deformity is seen in Rheumatoid arthritis.

  • Swan neck deformity is characterized by proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint flexion.

  • There is also reciprocal flexion noted of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.

  • This is a result of an imbalance of the extensor mechanism of the digit.

  • The imbalance could be due to a significant laceration or stretching of the extrinsic tendon forces on the distal phalanx or from tightness and pulling of the extensor mechanism, both intrinsic and extrinsic, at the PIP joint

     

Option A: Boutonniere deformity

  • This deformity is called Boutonniere deformity / Buttonhole deformity

  • Extensor deficiency at PIP joint

  • Hyperextension at DIP, Flexion of PIP

Option B: Pencil in cup deformity

  • It is seen in psoriatic arthritis

  • Patients usually have a history of psoriasis

  • It is driven by bone destruction and pathologic new bone formation, often in the same digit.

Option C:  Osler nodes.

  • Osler's nodes are painful on the tip of the finger or toes.

  • They are thought to be caused by the localized immunological-mediated response.

  • Seen in infective endocarditis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to the orthopedic emergency department after a fall from a height while working on a high roof. The patient is in severe pain. There is tenderness on the greater trochanter, and the patient cannot walk. The lateral border of the foot touches the bed. The senior resident is expecting some fracture of a bone on the lower leg. He orders an X-ray to confirm. What is the most common complication in the affected area in the given clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Option C: Malunion

Femur fracture:

  • The given clinical scenario depicts the fracture of the femur's neck (intertrochanteric).
  • Extra-capsular (inter-trochanteric) fracture is more common than intra-capsular.
  • A most common complication of extracapsular fracture of the neck of the femur is malunion.
  • In inter-trochanteric fractures, there is usually gross deformity and pronounced lateral rotation.
  • The complication of inter-trochanteric fractures is avascular necrosis and non-union.

Femur fracture:

Fractured neck of femur presents with the following clinical features:

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb

A plain radiograph of the fracture neck of the femur may show the following features:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line
  • Intracapsular fracture of the femoral neck is treated by anatomical reduction (preferably closed) and cannulated cancellous lag screw fixation.
  • Malunion of these fractures has been described in the coronal plane (coxa valga or coxa vara).

Option A: Non-union

  • In Intra-capsular (neck of femur fracture)
    • Most common complication is avascular necrosis > non-union.

Option B: Avascular necrosis

  • In Intra-capsular (neck of femur fracture)
    • Most common complication is avascular necrosis > non-union.

Option D: Pulmonary complications

  • Pulmonary complications like ARDS may occur in a fracture of the femur shaft.
  • Pulmonary embolism can also occur.

questions.text: The rationale for adding dextrose in spinal anaesthesia is to:

choices.text: Reduce plasma levels of local anesthetic to prevent toxicity

questions.solution:
Option C: Increase specific gravity

  • In the above case, the pain and bulging in the groin with a hernia sac that protrudes through the external inguinal ring, bypassing the inguinal canal, is suggestive of Direct inguinal hernia for which hernioplasty is performed under spinal anaesthesia. The rationale for adding dextrose to Bupivacaine is to increase specific gravity.
  • Baricity is defined as the ratio of the density of the local anaesthetic to the density of CSF.
  • The significance of baricity is actually the ability to influence the distribution of local anaesthetic spread based on gravity.
  • Adding dextrose makes local anaesthetic hyperbaric and prevents uncontrolled ascending of local anaesthetics because of the more predictable spread and less interpatient variability.
  • The local anaesthetic solutions are made hyperbaric by the addition of glucose or hypobaric by the addition of sterile water.
  • A hyperbaric solution of local anaesthetic is denser (heavier) than CSF, whereas a hypobaric solution is less dense (lighter) than CSF.
  • Hyperbaric solutions tend to move to the most dependent area of the spine. With the patient in a head-down position, a hyperbaric solution spreads cephalad, and a hypobaric anaesthetic solution moves caudally.
  • A head-up position causes a hyperbaric solution to settle caudally and a hypobaric solution to ascend cephalad.
  • An isobaric solution tends to remain at the level of injection.

Option A: Increase the duration of action

  • By adding dextrose, make local anaesthetic hyperbaric and prevent uncontrolled ascending of local anaesthetics.
  • It will not increase the duration of action.

Option B: Reduce plasma levels of a local anaesthetic to prevent toxicity

  • Adding 8% dextrose in Bupivacaine 0.5% will increase the specific gravity of the solution and make it hyperbaric.
  • It will not reduce the plasma level of the local anaesthetic.

Option D: Increase the hypobaric

  • The local anaesthetic solutions are made hyperbaric by the addition of glucose or hypobaric by the addition of sterile water.
  • Adding 8% dextrose in Bupivacaine 0.5% will decrease the hypobaric.

questions.text: A 45-year-old perimenopausal woman was admitted with a history of abnormal uterine bleeding for the past 6 months. She was posted for a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salphingo oophorectomy. The anaesthesia plan was spinal anaesthesia with an epidural catheter for postoperative analgesia. Postoperative pain scores were low, and the patient was comfortable postoperatively. The epidural catheter was removed after 48 hours. What is the most appropriate indication for this type of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • Epidural anaesthesia is an excellent choice for independent anaesthesia and analgesia with general anaesthesia.
  • Thoracic epidural injection for thoracic surgery, and rib fracture.
  • Upper and lower abdomen procedures require a lumbar epidural.
  • It may also be used for urogenital or gynecologic procedures such as;
    • Cystectomy
    • Nephrectomy
    • Ureteral repair
    • Radical abdominal prostatectomy
    • Ovarian tumour debulking
    • Pelvic exenteration
    • Total abdominal hysterectomy

Option A: Rib fracture

  • Thoracic epidural injection for thoracic surgery, rib fracture
  • Other indications for thoracic epidural
    • Thoracotomy
    • Rib fractures
    • Pectus repair
    • Thoracic aneurysm repair
    • Thymectomy
    • Video-assisted thoracic surgery

Option B: Lower abdominal surgery

  • Lower abdomen procedures require a lumbar epidural.
  • Lower abdominal procedures may include:
    • Abdominal aortic aneurysm repair
    • Colectomy
    • Bowel resection
    • Abdominal perineal resection

Option C: Upper abdominal surgery

  • Upper abdomen procedures require a lumbar epidural.
  • Upper abdominal procedures may include:
    • Esophagectomy
    • Gastrectomy
    • Pancreatectomy
    • Cholecystectomy
    • Hepatic resection

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is being posted for a right-modified radical mastectomy under general anaesthesia. Induction of anaesthesia is done with Inj. Propofol and endotracheal intubation is facilitated with Inj. Atracurium. While doing mask ventilation after administering muscle relaxant, the monitor showed a blood pressure reading of 75/40 mmHg, a pulse rate to be 130/minute, and flushing of the face, which was treated with intravenous fluid bolus and Inj. Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV. Which of the following is the underlying mechanism of these observed findings?

choices.text: Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors
Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol

questions.solution:
Option A: Histamine release

  • Histamine release by benzylisoquinolinium compounds such as mivacurium, atracurium and tubocurarine can cause skin flushing, decreases in blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance and tachycardia.
  • Histamine has positive ionotropic and chronotropic effects on the myocardial H2 receptors. The clinical effects of histamine are seen when the drug administration is rapid.
  • Cisatracurium, vecuronium or rocuronium may be appropriate for patients with hemodynamic instability due to less or no histamine release.
  • Slow administration of benzylisoquinolinium compounds over 60 seconds and prophylaxis with combined H1 and H2 blockers maintain cardiovascular stability.

​​​​​​​Option B: Effects mediated by autonomic nicotinic cholinergic receptors

  • Neuromuscular blocking agents interact with nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors within the autonomic nervous system and at the nicotinic receptors of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Tubocurarine causes marked ganglionic blockade resulting in hypotension due to peripheral venous and arteriolar dilatation via stimulation of the vascular H1 and H2 receptors.
  • Pancuronium produced a profound vagolytic response by blocking the sympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals. It is characterised by tachycardia, reduction in heart rate variability and baroreflex sensitivity. It may also stimulate the catecholamine release from adrenergic nerve terminals.

Option C: Reduced peripheral vascular resistance by propofol

  • It may result in hypotension, but the observed findings of flushing do not particularly occur secondary to propofol administration.

Option D: Preoperative use of antihypertensives

  • Antihypertensives are used preoperatively in some patients with elevated blood pressure readings to keep their blood pressure within a suitable range for the induction of anaesthesia.
  • Flushing is particularly not expected secondary to this intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intestinal obstruction has been admitted to the surgical ward. The conservative treatment does not relieve his symptoms. He has been taken for immediate surgery. The anaesthesia with inhaled anaesthetic has been started. Which of the following factor decreases the MAC of the inhaled anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lithium

  • The lithium decreases the value of MAC
  • Increases in MAC
    • Hyperthermia
    • Hypernatremia
    • Excess pheomelanin production
    • Drug-induced increases in central nervous system catecholamine levels
    • Cyclosporine
  • Decreases in MAC
    • Hypothermia
    • Increase in age
    • Preoperative medication
    • Drug-induced decreases in central nervous system catecholamine levels
    • Alpha 2 agonists
    • Acute alcohol ingestion
    • Pregnancy
    • Postpartum(returns to normal in 24-72 hours)
    • Lithium
    • Lidocaine
    • Neuraxial opioids(?)
    • Ketanserin
    • PaO2 < 38mm Hg
    • Mean blood pressure < 40mm Hg
    • Cardiopulmonary bypass
    • Hyponatremia
  • No change in MAC
    • Anaesthetic metabolism
    • Chronic alcohol abuse
    • Gender
    • Duration of anaesthesia(?)
    • PaCO2 15-95 mm Hg
    • PaO2 > 38 mm Hg
    • Blood pressure > 40 mm Hg
    • Hyperkalemia or Hypokalemia
    • Thyroid gland dysfunction

Option B: Hyperthermia

  • Hyperthermia increases the value of MAC.

Option C: Gender

  • Gender does not affect the MAC value

Option D: Thyroid dysfunction

  • Thyroid dysfunction does not affect the MAC value

questions.text: A 22-year-old boxer was brought to the Emergency department by an ambulance. He had a boxing match prior to his arrival. The attending physician did a thorough physical checkup and suspected an orbital floor fracture. He immediately ordered an X-ray of the orbital floor. What is the most appropriate view of X-ray for this patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Water’s view

  • An angled posteroanterior radiograph of the skull with the patient looking slightly upwards is known as the occipitomental (OM) or Waters view.

  • In addition to acute sinusitis, it can be used to check for facial fractures.

  • It is the view of choice for visualizing fractures of the orbital floor.

Option B: Caldwell’s view


  • Caldwell's view is a caudally angled radiograph, and its posteroanterior projection exposes the orbits to the least amount of radiation possible.

  • The paranasal sinuses, particularly the frontal sinus, are easier to visualize at this angle.

  • Assessing four inflammatory disorders, including sinusitis, secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts might be helpful.

  • This view also enables the identification of superior orbital fissure fractures.

Option C: Rhese view

  • The optic canal can be visualized by using the Rhese view of the X-ray.

  • In this view, the patient is positioned with the orbit to be studied such that the cassette should be touched by the zygoma, nose, and chin.

Option D: Towne view

  • The Towne view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull that shows the posterior clinoid processes, the dorsum sellae, and the petrous section of the pyramids, which are all visible in the foramen magnum's shadow.

  • This projection is utilized to assess for Paget disease, neoplastic alterations, and medial and lateral displacements of skull fractures.

  • The inferior orbital fissure of the orbit can also be visualized via this view.

questions.text: Which is not a finding of endometriosis:
questions.solution:
Option D: Median prosencephalic vein

Vein of Galen malformations: 

Galen Malformation (VOGM) | Boston Children's Hospital" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" height="209" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://www.childrenshospital.org/sites/default/files/media_migration/e85d24ab-257b-4e0b-8c97-67fd84d426d1.jpg" style="margin: 0px;" width="257" />

  • This is a case of vein of Galen malformation.

  • The vein of Galen malformations (VOGMs) is characterized by fistulous connections between the choroidal arteries and the residual dilated median prosencephalic vein of Markowski.

  • CT cerebral angiogram shows an aneurysmal structure that drains to the vein of Galen, the posterior part of the superior sagittal sinus, and the transverse and sigmoid sinuses are also enlarged.

  • Feeding arteries are multiple, dilated, and tortuous, attaching directly to the aneurysm area.

 

 

  • Figure showing different veins draining into the Vein of Galen.

 

 

  • Figure showing illustration of the median prosencephalic vein.

Option A: Great cerebral vein of Galen

  • The fistula of only the great cerebral vein of Galen doesn't cause the condition mentioned in this case.

  • The great cerebral vein, also known as the vein of Galen or the great vein of Galen, is a short valveless midline venous trunk that drains the deep parts of the cerebrum, brainstem, and parts of the posterior cranial fossa.

Option B: Median and lateral prosencephalic veins

  • The condition mentioned in this case is caused only by the medial prosencephalic vein. and Lateral prosencephalic vein is not involved.

Option C: Internal cerebral veins

  • The internal cerebral veins are a pair of midline veins that arise at the foramen of Munro.

  • It is located after the vein of galen.

questions.text: A patient with suspected case of tuberculoma was sent to radiological department for brain imaging . The radiologist decided to take MR spectroscopy . Which peak on MR spectroscopy is seen in tuberculoma?
questions.solution:
• MR-spectroscopy usually reveals a large lipid lactate peak at 0.9 to 1.33 ppm and reduced NAA.
  • The lipid peak in tuberculoma is primarily due to the predominant lipid content in the cell wall of tubercle bacillus.
  • Presence of lactate indicates anaerobic glycolysis and necrosis within the Tuberculoma.
  • However, lipid lactate peak can also be seen in other conditions having necrosis like high grade gliomas [GBM].

questions.text: A 37 yr old man was referred to NIMHANS Neurology opd with a history of 2 episodes of GTCS, Headache, weakness on the right side of the body, behavior, and personality changes. NCCT is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis that can be made?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oligodendroglioma

  • Oligodendroglioma has chicken wire calcifications.
  • The above-given NCCT image shows an ill-defined hypodense lesion in the left frontal lobe with dense foci of calcification in the center.
  • Both low- and high-grade oligodendroglial tumors express proangiogenic mitogens and may contain regions of increased vascular density with finely branching capillaries with a 'chicken wire' appearance.
  • Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT, which can be central, peripheral, or ribbon-like.
  • Meningioma is dural-based and appears hyperdense on NCCT.

Option A: Meningioma

  • Meningioma is dural-based and appears hyperdense on NCCT.
  • Typical unenhanced images feature a well-circumscribed, smoothly marginated extra-axial mass abutting the dura.
  • Calcification is seen in approximately 20-25% of cases.
  • The CT nature of the calcification may be nodular, fine and punctate, or dense.
  • Surrounding parenchymal vasogenic edema is common, identified as hypodense brain tissue.
  • Occasionally, the edema is extensive and, as it predominantly affects white matter, can resemble fingers of low attenuation.

Option C: Glioblastoma

  • GBM usually does not show calcification.
  • With gliomatosis cerebri, CT scan findings may be normal, or images can show widespread low-attenuating regions with no focal mass and enhancement.
  • Non-enhanced CT scan findings may include a heterogeneous poorly marginated mass; internal areas of low or fluid attenuation that are the foci of necrosis (present in as many as 95% of GBMs).
  • Internal areas of high attenuation are the foci of hemorrhage or, rarely, calcifications (more common if GBM is the result of the transformation of a low-grade astrocytoma or after therapy); and a significant mass effect and edema (vasogenic distribution of edema).

Option D: Craniopharyngioma

  • On CT, the cystic component of the tumor extends anteriorly or laterally and typically wraps around the solid component. Conversely, the solid component characteristically extends posteriorly and laterally.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of failure to conceive. She has been married for 10 years and has a baby of 8 years. She is undergoing infertility evaluation for secondary infertility. Her past pregnancy was spontaneously conceived 8 years back. A few blood tests evaluate ovarian reserve, including inhibin B, considering her age. Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at which stage of the menstrual cycle.
questions.solution:
Option B: Preantral follicle stage

  • Inhibins are heterodimeric protein hormones released by granulosa cells of the ovary in females and Sertoli cells of the testis in males.
  • Inhibin selectively decreases the secretion of pituitary follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • They have local paracrine actions in the gonads.
  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage and therefore reflects the size of the growing follicular cohort.
  • It is thus used as a measure of ovarian reserve in women with infertility, especially in those of advanced age, as the ovarian reserve is known to decline with age.
  • In normal fertile women, reduced inhibin B levels are seen with aging.
  • Inhibin B alone has poor predictive value for an ovarian response but improves the predictive value when added to the CCCT (clomiphene citrate challenge test).
  • Tests for ovarian reserve
    • FSH: the early follicular phase
    • Estradiol levels
    • Progesterone levels: mid-luteal
    • Inhibin B level
    • Anti-mullerian hormone
    • Ultrasound: antral follicle count, ovarian volume and ovarian blood flow
    • Clomiphene citrate challenge test
    • Ovarian biopsy

Stages of follicular development

  • Folliculogenesis is divided into various stages according to follicular characteristics regarding the number and appearance of granulosa cells, development of theca cells and formation of a fluid-filled structure called the antrum.
  • Preantral follicles: include primordial, primary and secondary follicles.
    • Primordial: 0.03-0.05 mm formed by a primary oocyte arrested in Prophase 1, surrounded by 1 layer of granulosa cells.
    • Primary: 0.1 mm, cuboidal granulosa cells develop FSH receptors.
    • Secondary: 0.2 mm, multilayered granulosa cell, theca cells develop from the stroma.
  • Antral follicles: tertiary and preovulatory follicles.
    • Tertiary: 0.2-5 mm and later 10-20 mm, formation of the antrum.
    • Preovulatory: > 20 mm

Option A: Tertiary follicle stage

  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage

Option C: Early antral stage

  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage, so it's a false statement.

Option D: Preovulatory stage​​​​​​​

  • Serum inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells starting at the preantral follicle stage, so it's not a true statement.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic, reporting that she is late for her period by one day. She has been married for 4 years and has 2 children. She has no significant gynecological history. She has had regular periods. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. She is advised to wait for another few days and gets her period the next day. Which mechanism is responsible for menstrual bleeding in the absence of pregnancy?

choices.text: The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.
Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon
Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

questions.solution:
Option A: The involution of corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically

  • The woman in question has had a normal period. The normal cycle length can vary from 21-35 days.

  • A corpus luteum is a mass of cells formed in an ovary. It leads to the production of progesterone during early pregnancy. The role of the corpus luteum varies whether or not fertilization occurs.
  • Without progesterone, the uterus lining does not undergo the changes supporting pregnancy. Instead, the lining would shed.
  • LH is the stimulus for the corpus luteum to continue its function of progesterone production. Apoptosis can occur by changes in hormone levels in the ovarian cycle. When there is no fertilization of the ovum, the endometrial cells die because LH production stops after the 10th day of its formation in the absence of pregnancy.
  • As the corpus luteum involutes, the levels of estrogen and progesterone fall and lead to a withdrawal bleed due to the absence of progesterone supporting the estrogen-primed endometrium.
  • Once pregnancy ensues, the hCG made from the syncytiotrophoblast is the stimulator for continuous corpus luteum function till around the 12th week of gestation, after which the placenta takes over the function of pregnancy maintenance.

Option B: LH levels rise after ovulation

  • LH levels fall after ovulation due to rising Progesterone which gives feedback inhibition to the production of LH from the pituitary.
  • So, it's a false statement.

Option C: Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon

  • The rising estrogen from the developing follicle continues to increase through the proliferative phase and causes the production of LH, which in turn is responsible for ovulation. So, it's not a true statement regarding the question asked above.

Option D: Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

  • Estrogen is responsible for the production of progesterone receptors in the endometrium. Progesterone is produced from the corpus luteum, acts on the endometrium, and causes secretory changes. So, it's not a true statement.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient who is being treated for infertility gets ovulation induction with clomiphene and Inj. hCG. After 5 days, she comes to OPD with complaints of abdominal distension, pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasonogram reveals subclinical ascites. The next step in management should be?

choices.text: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record and fluid balance
Hospitalise, input output charting and iv fluid administration
Hospitalise, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

questions.solution:
Option A: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record, and fluid balance

  • The patient has a history of infertility treatment with clomiphene and HCG and has symptoms after 5 days of Inj: hCG, which makes her a provisional diagnosis. A case of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment. Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Here outpatient management is appropriate, as she has mild OHSS and no symptoms of severity such as difficulty in breathing or coagulopathy, so the patient should be instructed to limit her activity, weigh herself daily, and monitor her fluid intake (at least 1 L/day of mostly electrolyte-balanced fluid) and urinary output.
  • Mild OHSS is a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Hospitalize, input-output charting and iv fluid administration

Indications for hospitalization include a more severe grade of OHSS with:

  • Inability to tolerate oral hydration
  • hemodynamic instability
  • respiratory compromise
  • tense ascites
  • hemoconcentration
  • leukocytosis
  • hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • abnormal renal or liver function
  • decreased oxygen saturation

 

Option C: Hospitalize, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

  • Hospitalization is done for more severe forms of OHSS with the abovementioned indications.
  • Albumin infusion is required in a patient with low serum protein values with excess extravascular fluid loss.

Option D: Paracentesis

  • Paracentesis is required in tense ascites causing excessive abdominal distension or causing respiratory distress.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman has been using tamoxifen for 2 years now for breast cancer prevention based on her strong family history, nulliparity, and early age at menarche. Her general physical and gynecological examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is this patient most likely to develop while on her current medication?
questions.solution:
Option C: Endometrial changes

  • Tamoxifen is SERM (Selective estrogen receptor modulator), which is an antagonist of the estrogen receptor in breast tissue via its active metabolite, hydroxy-tamoxifen. In contrast, it behaves as an estrogen agonist in other tissues, such as the endometrium.
  • It's a partial agonist on the endometrium and has been linked to endometrial cancer.
  • It may increase the risk of endometrial cancer by changing the lining of the uterus because it acts as an estrogen agonist in the endometrial cavity. Increased exposure to estrogen may lead to hyperplasia, polyps and even cancer.
  • Both tamoxifen and raloxifene reduce the risk of breast cancer in high-risk women by approximately 50% and are approved for this indication.
  • Additionally, it also decreases the risk of osteoporosis because it slows down bone loss by increasing bone density.
  • Other side effects of tamoxifen therapy are
    • menopausal symptoms like hot flashes
    • loss of libido
    • vaginal discharge, itching, dryness
    • rare: DVT, Pulmonary embolism, osteoporosis

Option A: Breast cancer

  • Tamoxifen is used for the prevention and treatment of breast cancer.

Option B: Elevated LDL cholesterol

  • Tamoxifen does not cause an elevation of LDL cholesterol.

Option D: Myocardial infarction

  • Tamoxifen does not increase the risk of myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a mass in the lower abdomen involving the umbilicus and the hypogastrium for 10 days. On examination, it is hard and mobile mass. The examiner cannot insinuate fingers between the mass and the pelvic bone. On radiological investigation, it is a cystic mass. What is the likely diagnosis with this given history?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovarian cyst

  • It is the correct option.
  • A mass involving the lower abdomen where the fingers cannot be implanted between the mass and pelvic bone implies a mass arising from one of the pelvic structures. The only pelvic mass in question is an ovarian cyst, which is fairly common. Mobile, but the examiner cannot insinuate fingers between the mass & the pelvic bone as it is a pelvic mass.

 

 

  • Features of Ovarian cyst:
  • Usually, ≤ 7 cm in diameter.
  • Usually, asymptomatic.
  • Spontaneous regression occurs.
  • Unilocular.
  • Usually contains clear fluid.
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which it arises.

 

 

Classification of ovarian masses

Non – neoplastic

Neoplastic
  • A follicular cyst (commonest functional cysts)
  • Corpus luteum cyst
  • Theca lutein & granulosa
  • Lutein cyst.
  • PCOD
  • Endometrial cyst
  • Epithelial tumor
  • Sex cord tumor
  • Germ cell tumor
  • Unclassified
  • Lipid cell tumor
  • Secondaries

 

Option A, B, C: Mesentric cysts, duplication cysts and omental cysts are all abdominal masses and hence fingers can be insinuated between mass and pelvic bone. Mesenteric cyst have only length wise mobility not side-wise

questions.text: Which of the following long-term health effects is NOT associated with PCOS?
questions.solution:
Option D: Postdated pregnancy

  • The woman has delayed cycles (oligo-ovulation) and polycystic ovarian morphology on USG. These are suggestive of PCOD.
  • OCPs are used for the management of PCOD for the regularization of cycles.
  • Pregnancy complications of PCOS include preterm birth and not postdates.
  • Health risks associated with Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):

 

  • Type II Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Lipidemias
  • Premature Ovarian failure
  • Breast Cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Pregnancy risks associated with Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Gestational diabetes (diabetes that occurs during pregnancy)
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Preterm birth
  • Babies from PCOS mothers have a higher rate of admission to the neonatal intensive care unit & perinatal death.

Option A: Type II Diabetes

  • PCOS is related to abnormal glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, and raised serum insulin levels and later may be complicated as type II diabetes.

Option B: Infertility

  • PCOD causes anovulatory infertility.

Option C: Abnormal glucose tolerance test

  • PCOS is related to abnormal glucose tolerance, insulin resistance, and raised serum insulin levels and later may be complicated as type II diabetes.

questions.text: A 41 year old woman presents to the OPD with a paps smear report suggestive of 'LSIL' (Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesion). The gynaecologist explains that this report means that there are some suspicious changes seen in the lining of the cervix involving?

choices.text: Whole thickness except the superficial layers

questions.solution:
Option A : A paps smear report depicting 'LSIL' (Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesion) is suggestive of suspicious changes in the form of dysplasia seen in the lining of the cervix involving up to lower 1/3rd.

Bethesda system of describing dysplasia in cervical epithelium is as follows:

DYSPLASTIC CELLS DYSPLASIA CIN BETHESDA SYSTEM
Normal Normal/inflammatory Inflammatory/ ASCUS/ASC-H  
<1/3rd epithelium Mild dysplasia CIN-1 LSIL
1/3rd- 2/3rd epithelium Moderate dysplasia CIN-2 HSIL
>2/3rd epithelium Severe dysplasia CIN-3 HSIL
Almost entire epithelium with intact basement membrane Carcinoma-in-situ CIN-3 HSIL
Basement membrane invaded Invasive carcinoma    

Option B : Dysplasia involving basal half to two third would be described as a high grade lesion, CIN II.

Option C : Dysplasia involving whole thickness of cervical epithelium except superficial layers is CIN III, high grade lesion.

Option D : Dysplasia involving whole thickness of cervical epithelium with involvement of basement membrane is invasive carcinoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with abnormal menstrual bleeding and a pelvic mass undergoes a hysterectomy. The image shows the gross specimen removed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Leiomyoma.

  • The image shows a gross hysterectomy specimen showing a fibroid/ leiomyoma.
  • This can present as abnormal uterine bleeding (usually menorrhagia) and pelvic mass.
  • Recognition is based on a solid, well-defined lesion, inside a pseudo capsule, without any surrounding invasion, with a whirling pattern, which differentiates it from malignancy and adenomyosis.
  • Fibroids are the most common uterine tumours and are made of smooth muscle with varying amounts of fibrous connective tissue.
  • Fibroids are classified as submucosal, intramural, or subserosal; the latter may become pedunculated and simulate ovarian tumours.
  • Although most fibroids are asymptomatic, patients may present with abnormal menstrual bleeding, pressure on adjacent organs, pain, infertility, or a palpable abdominal-pelvic mass.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most accurate imaging technique for detecting and locating fibroids.

Option B: Adenomyosis

  • Adenomyotic uterus appears  asymmetrically enlarged, globular uterus due to associated myometrial hypertrophy reflected by thickened myometrium, with trabeculated cut surface with ill defined hypertrophic swirls of smooth muscle and petechia-like gray foci of endometrium.
  • A clear demarcation or capsule is absent, unlike as shown in the specimen in the question, which suggests fibroid

Option C: Ovarian neoplasm

  • The image in the question shows a solid benign looking growth arising from the uterus, hence ovarian neoplasm is unlikely, which are mostly cystic and are seen adjacent to the ovary.

Option D: Carcinoma of the uterus

  • Carcinoma is a malignant condition, hence a clear demarcation or capsule as evident in the picture, is unlikely

questions.text: What is the most appropriate next step in managing a 39-year-old woman with irregular menstrual bleeding, a negative pregnancy test, and a 2 cm diameter, well-defined, homogeneous polypoid lesion with a single vascular pedicle in the endometrial cavity on transvaginal ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Option A : Hysteroscopy biopsy

Endometrial polyps

  • The above given is a case of endometrial polyps.
  • It can cause intermenstrual bleeding, heavy menstrual bleeding, irregular bleeding and post-menopausal bleeding.
  • Also associated with infertility and dysmenorrhea.
  • Diagnosis suspected based on endometrial thickening on TVS (Transvaginal sonogram).
  • The prevalence rises with age. 
  • Risk factors:
    • Hypertension
    • Obesity
    • Tamoxifen or hormone replacement therapy.
    • History of cervical polyps
    • Lynch syndrome
  • Diagnostics
    • Transvaginal ultrasound
    • Hysteroscopy with endometrial biopsy to diagnose polyp and to rule out other conditions.
  • Treatment
    • Asymptomatic observation and follow-up
    • Symptomatic : hysteroscopic removal 
  • Differential diagnosis
    • Endometrial carcinoma
    • Endometrial hyperplasia
    • Uterine leiomyoma

 

Option B: Doppler

  • Doppler sonography can detect the presence of polyps and establish increased vascularity and identify a pedicle, however the diagnosis can be confirmed best with hysteroscopy

 

Option C: CT scan

  • CT scan can detect an endometrial polyp but definitive diagnosis can be made with hysteroscopy.

 

Option D: Endometrial aspiration

  • Endometrial aspiration is an office procedure, wherein endometrial cells are aspirated and sent for histopathology, however it is a blind procedure and thus cannot visually diagnose a polyp

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents in the outpatient clinic with the complaint of primary amenorrhea. She has short stature; on the examination, there is no breast development. Ultrasound reveals a hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries. The doctor ordered hormonal assays, which showed high levels of FSH. Karyotyping is suggested to confirm the suspected condition, which is XO. What is the probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gonadal dysgenesis

  • The above scenario findings of short stature, hypoplastic uterus, streak ovaries and raised FSH suggest the diagnosis of Turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is an XO genotype with either incomplete penetration or the absence of another X chromosome.
  • Turner syndrome is the most common cause of gonadal (ovarian) dysgenesis.
  • Features of gonadal dysgenesis
    • Hypoplastic uterus
    • Functional ovarian tissue absent
    • Thelarche is absent as it depends on ovarian steroids
    • FSH & LH are high due to absent negative feedback on the pituitary by ovarian hormones, i.e.Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism
    • Pubic and axillary hair present (Depends on Androgen)
    • External genitalia are female-like (Hypoplastic)
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping.
  • Management is lifelong hormonal support.
  • Streak ovaries may be surgically removed to decrease the chances of malignancy.

 

Option B: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a disorder in which the individual has a normal female phenotype in a genetic male.

 

Option C: Kallman syndrome

  • Kallman syndrome is a disorder in which the female suffers from hypothalamic amenorrhea. Since there is no GnRH, there is no FSH & LH.

 

Option D: Adrenal hyperplasia

  • Adrenal hyperplasiais the adult onset counterpart of CAH and can present with amenorrhea
  • However here the uterus will be present and FSH will be normal.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the gynaecology clinic for counselling regarding contraception. She desires to start COCPs. She is a well-controlled diabetic patient. She smokes one pack (of 20) of cigarettes daily. She is also hypertensive, and her blood pressure is 140/90 on drugs and known case of Arterial thrombosis. Total serum cholesterol is 275 mg/dL. COCPs are contraindicated in her more strongly due to which of the following factors in her history?
questions.solution:
Option D: Smoking

  • The most appropriate answer is smoking since it is the only absolute contraindication mentioned.
  • The risk of MI in COCP users increases if the following risk factors are present:
    • Smokers, especially if >15 cigarettes/day
    • Hypertension, especially BP >160/85
    • Hypercholesterolemia and Obesity
    • Diabetes >35 Age
  • Since low-dose OCPs do not alter lipid metabolism, they can be prescribed to this patient, provided she stops smoking altogether.
  • Alternatives like IUCDs are best for this patient.

  • Absolute contraindications

    • < 6 wks postpartum
    • smoker over the age of 35 (>15 cigarettes per day)
    • hypertension (systolic > 160mmHg or diastolic > 100mmHg)
    • current or past history of venous thromboembolism (VTE)
    • ischemic heart disease
    • history of cerebrovascular accident
    • complicated valvular heart disease (pulmonary hypertension, atrial fibrillation, history of subacute bacterial endocarditis)
    • migraine headache with focal neurological symptoms
    • breast cancer (current)
    • diabetes with retinopathy/nephropathy/neuropathy
    • liver tumour (adenoma or hepatoma)
  •  

  • Relative contraindications

    • smoker over the age of 35 (< 15 cigarettes per day)
    • adequately controlled hypertension
    • hypertension (systolic 140 - 159mmHg or diastolic 90 - 99mmHg)
    • migraine headache over the age of 35
    • currently symptomatic gallbladder disease
    • history of combined OCP-related cholestasis

 

Option A: Diabetes

  • Diabetes in this patient is well controlled and COCs can be used in well controlled diabetics.

Option B: Cholesterol

  • Since low dose OCPs do not alter the lipid metabolism too much, it is not the most important contraindication.

Option C: Hypertension

  • Hypertension too in this patient is well controlled, and forms only a relative contraindications to COCs.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who has been using IUCD for contraception for a year now presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, fever and pain in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response, and then decide on IUCD removal.
Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD
Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics
Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

questions.solution:
Option A: Keep the IUCD, give an antibiotic, follow up for antibiotic response and then take a decision regarding IUCD removal

  • The history suggests that pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) occurred in an intrauterine copper device (IUCD) user.
  • PID generally arises within 4 weeks of insertion and is caused by an undetected vaginal infection or the tail of IUCD generating ascending infection.
  • The presence of PID in and of itself is not an indicator of IUCD removal because there might be other reasons for PID, which are normally treatable with antibiotics. Because sterile standards are maintained, it is uncommon for PID to arise due to IUCD implantation.
  • PID without abscess formation is initially treated with systemic antibiotics and then monitored for the response.
  • Actinomycosis is a frequent infection linked with IUCD. If signs or symptoms of infection appear in women harbouring Actinomyces species, the device should be removed, and antimicrobial therapy should be started. Actinomyces species are susceptible to gram-positive antimicrobials, particularly penicillins.

Option B: Start antibiotics and then remove IUCD

  • If there is no clinical improvement after 48-72 hours of starting antibiotic therapy, then the decision about the removal IUD can be made.

Option C: Remove IUCD and then start antibiotics
