  • When PID is diagnosed in an IUD user, the IUD does not have to be taken out.
  • A comprehensive assessment of the literature showed that treatment results did not differ significantly between women with PID who kept the IUD and those who had the IUD removed.

Option D: Wait till the next menstrual cycle for any intervention

  • If PID develops in an IUCD user, appropriate antibiotic therapy can be started without waiting for the next menstrual cycle.
  • Antibiotic therapy can be started at the onset of symptoms, and if there is no clinical improvement after 48-72 hours of antibiotic therapy, then the decision about removing IUCD can be made.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G1P0, at 24 weeks of pregnancy, presents to the outpatient department for a routine prenatal visit. The pregnancy was planned. She takes no medications except folic acid and iron tablets. On examination, S2 and S3 are easily audible, and a systolic ejection murmur is greater during inspiration. Which of the following is true regarding these findings in the patient?

choices.text: The presence of S3 is abnormal
The systolic ejection murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term
Wide pulse pressure is rare in pregnant women
All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Option D: All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

In Pregnancy

  • Heart rate increases by about 10 to 15/min.
  • Exaggerated splitting of the first heart sound
  • Increased loudness of both S1 & S2 components,
  • A loud, easily heard S3
  • >95% develop systolic murmur whih disapperas after delivery
  • >20% have a transient diastolic murmur.
  • 10% develop continuous murmur due to increasing mammary blood flow.

 

 

Option A: The presence of S3 is abnormal

  • The presence of an audible S3 is normal in pregnancy due to a hyperdynamic state, and this resolves as soon as the baby is delivered

 

Option B: The systolic ejection murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term

  • The presence of an ejection systolic murmur is normal in pregnancy due to a hyperdynamic state, which resolves as soon as the baby is delivered.

 

Option C: Wide pulse pressure is rare in pregnant women

  • Wide pulse pressure is not an uncommon finding in pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 30 weeks gestation with nausea and dizziness every time she lies down. She states that the symptoms subside when she turns on her side. Which of the following is the best explanation of such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior vena cava (IVC) compression

  • Pregnant patients in the supine position have compression of the inferior vena cava and aorta by the gravid uterus, which leads to decreased venous return and, thus, hypoperfusion.
  • Symptoms include tachycardia, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, pallor, weakness, lightheadedness and dizziness.

Option A: Raised intragastric pressure

  • Normal pregnancy leads to chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure, and the stomach is increasingly displaced upwards, leading to an altered axis and increased intra-gastric pressure.
  • The patient’s symptoms are more likely due to inferior vena cava compression due to a gravid uterus rather than raised intragastric pressure.

Option C: Decreased fluid in semicircular canals

  • The semicircular canals are activated by a circular motion and are filled with endolymph.
  • The semicircular canals play a crucial role in detecting the head’s rotational position.
  • Decreased fluid in semicircular canals causes nausea and dizziness every time with rotational head movement rather than when the patient lies.

Option D: Peripheral venous Pooling in pregnancy

  • The diameter of lower extremity veins and venous volume significantly increase in pregnant women.
  • This factor predisposes pregnant women to thrombosis through components of Virchow’s triad, which include endothelial injury, venous stasis and hypercoagulability.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female comes for an antenatal check-up. She is 7 weeks pregnant and had a missed abortion 2 years ago. She is really worried and wants to know the well-being of the fetus. Which of the following is the best modality to detect fetal cardiac activity?
questions.solution:
Transvaginal sonogram(TVS) will be able to detect the fetal cardiac activity as early as 5 weeks of gestation.

  Sac Cardiac activity
TVS 4+ weeks 5+ weeks
TAS 5+ weeks 6+ weeks

 

A, B : Regular stethoscope and fetoscope can detect fetal heart sounds by 20 to 24 weeks of gestation.

C : >12 weeks FHS heard with fetal doppler

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks of gestation, presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her routine antenatal evaluation. She has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and is currently concerned about the viability of her pregnancy. Subsequently, ultrasonography was advised to look for fetal viability. Her ultrasound scan revealed a frog-like appearance of the fetal eyes. Based on the patient's history and ultrasonographic findings, the fetus is most likely to develop which of the following congenital anomalies?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anencephaly

  • Ultrasound done in the first trimester helps in dating the pregnancy.
  • Fetal malformations are best looked for at 18–20 weeks of gestation (anomaly scan).
  • If there is a malformation that is not viable, then a decision for the termination of pregnancy can be taken at this time 
  • However, in the first trimester, i.e., around 9–11 weeks, gross malformations of the fetus, like anencephaly, acrania, or spina bifida, can be picked up.
  • A routine first-trimester ultrasound scan is done for:
  • Pregnancy dating
  • Fetal viability
  • Intrauterine or extrauterine pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Nuchal translucency and nasal bone are checked at 11-13 weeks (markers for downs syndrome)
  • Anencephaly is a congenital anomaly in which the fetal skull, scalp, and brain do not develop properly.
  • It is a type of neural tube defect. Failure of rostral neuropore closure results in this condition. 
  • Ultrasound examination shows a frog-eye sign.

Option B: Dysplastic kidneys

  • Dysplastic kidneys are characterized by improper development of kidneys in utero.
  • The diagnosis is often made antenatally as early as the 15th week of gestation.
  • They do not appear with a frog sign in the ultrasound.

Option C: Microcephaly

  • Microcephaly is a condition where a baby has a head size much smaller than other babies of the same age and sex.
  • Ultrasonography is to be done at 18–20 weeks of gestation and not in the first trimester to detect specific deformities like microcephaly.

Option D: Holoprosencephaly

  • Holoprosencephaly is a disorder caused by the inability of the embryonic forebrain to sufficiently divide into the double lobes of the cerebral hemispheres.
  • A detailed anomaly scanning must be performed at 18-20 weeks to detect holoprosencephaly.

questions.text: The image shows the uterine sutures in a woman with PPH. Identify.
questions.solution:
Option A: B-Lynch suture

  • B-Lynch suture
  • Two sutures are applied longitudinal, which look like a "brace-suspender,"
  • The b-Lynch suture is referred to as the "brace suture."

Option B: Hayman suture

  • Hayman procedure is considered a uterine compression suture using two longitudinal threads and transfixing the entire uterine wall.
  • This suture is simpler than the B-Lynch suture, sometimes called the "simple brace."

Option C: Cho suture

  • Also called 'multiple square sutures.'
  • In an atonic uterus, four to five square sutures should be made.
  • If the bleeding point is evident, suturing should be performed to compress the bleeding site

Option D: Arterial embolization

  • Arterial embolization is done through interventions such as radiological guidance, and the artery is blocked with an embolizing agent.

questions.text: A primigravida is shifted for delivery in the second stage of labour. Immediately after the baby's delivery, the resident pulls the cord,  and the placenta pulls the fundus of the uterus out of the cervix. The senior obstetrician is called. What should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Administer oxytocin to prevent mortality due to hemorrhagic shock and then attempt repositioning
Urgently take-up patient for Huntingtons surgery

questions.solution:
Option D: Manual Reposition under tocolytics

 

The scenario explained, wherein undue traction on umbilical cord has pulled the fundus out of the cervix is suggestive of uterine inversion.

  • Uterine inversion usually occurs due to:
    • fundal implantation of placenta
    • uterine atony
    • cord traction applied before placental separation
    • abnormally adhered placentation e.g. placenta accreta.
  • Manual Reposition under tocolytics such as terbutaline, MgSO4, can be done initially to reposition the uterus, thus oxytocin is not to be given.
  • In most cases, manual reposition works.
  • If it fails, surgical interventions like haultain surgery and huntington procedure may be done.

 

Option A: Administer oxytocin to prevent mortality due to hemorrhagic shock and then attempt repositioning

  • Oxytocics are not to be given as patient requires tocoysis for reposition. Oxytocin is to be given immediately after successful repositioning so the uterus contracts preventing PPH.

Option B: Urgently take up the patient for Huntington surgery

  • It is not the initial step in the management of uterine inversion.
  • If the manual repositioning technique has not worked out, the Huntington procedure should be carried out.

 

Option C: Hydrostatic Reposition

  • Hydrostatic reduction of acute uterine inversion is an option if manual repositioning has failed and surgical intervention is not possible.
  • The patient is placed in reversed Trendelenburg lithotomy position.
  • A bag of warmed fluid is hung at least one meter above the patient and allowed to flow by gravity or with light pressure through tubing connected to a silastic ventouse cup in the vagina; the seal between the perimeter of the cup and the vagina prevents significant leakage.
  • The resulting intravaginal hydrostatic pressure may force the inverted fundus back to its normal position. Two to 5 litres of fluid may be needed

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic primigravida, at 36 weeks of gestation, comes to the obstetric department for a routine antenatal check-up. She is completely well, and her pregnancy was uneventful except for a history of fewer fetal activities 2 days ago. Her diabetes is well-controlled, and she takes the multivitamins, iron, and calcium pills as prescribed. Upon physical examination, her vitals were normal, and the physician ordered an NST (Non-Stress test) to assess fetal well-being. The patient may be sent back home and asked to return after 1 week if the NST shows any of the following findings:

choices.text: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5-25 bpm
One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with a baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm
Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm
Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

questions.solution:
Option A: At least two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability of 5-25 bpm

  • The Non-Stress test is primarily a test of sympathetic and parasympathetic fetal well-being.
  • In normal conditions, fetal heart rate raises at least 15 beats whenever it moves.
  • If the baby shows two accelerations in heart rate lasting at least 15 seconds during the 20-minute test, it is read as normal or reactive.
  • A reactive non-stress test (NST) is a reassuring sign of fetal well-being.
  • If the heart rate does not accelerate with movement or another 20 minutes of observation fails to meet the criteria, the NST is considered non-reactive.

Criteria for reactive NST:

  • Baseline fetal heart rate: 110-160 bpm.
  • Baseline variability: 5-25 bpm.
  • Accelerations ≥ 2, in 20 mins.
  • No decelerations.

Option B: One fetal heart rate acceleration is noted in 20 mins with baseline variability of 5- 25 bpm

  • It is not a criterion for reactive NST; Therefore, it is non-reactive.

Option C: Two fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 20 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

  • It does not meet the criteria for reactive NST, so it is non-reactive.

Option D: Three fetal heart rate accelerations are noted in 30 mins with baseline variability > 25 bpm

  • It will be considered a non-reactive NST as it does not meet the criteria for a reactive test.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2 at the gestation of 12 weeks has come to the hospital. She has a history of conisation one year back, and currently, she is on follow-up with no recurrence of cervical abnormalities on the Pap smear. She also has a history of preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks during her last 2 pregnancies. Which of the following would be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical cerclage

Figure: Marked encircled portion showing cervical cerclage

  • History of two preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks and history of conisation performed are indicative that the patient has a short cervix. Since she has lost the first two babies due to preterm deliveries, it is suggested that cervical cerclage be done in this patient.
  • Management of cervical dilation tendency includes cervical cerclage.
  • The cervical cerclage procedure is closing the cervical opening with stitches to prevent preterm birth.

Incompetent OS (Short Cervix [<2.5 cm])

  • Characterised by painless dilatation followed by the expulsion of a foetus.
  • Short cervix effaces early.
  • Predisposes to both preterm labour & abortion.
  • Managed by cerclage: Applied > 12 weeks, removed after 37 weeks.
  • Most Commonly used is MC Donald's cerclage; others include Shirodkar stitch (more complicated) and abdominal cerclage.

Indications of cervical cerclage

  • Multiple previous preterm losses/second-trimester losses.
  • History of painless dilatation of cervix before the onset of labour in a past pregnancy.
  • Previous cervical surgery.
  • Short cervix on USG < 2.5 cm before 24 weeks.

Option A: Termination of pregnancy

  • History of conisation and history of 2 preterm births is indicative that the patient has cervical insufficiency due to a short cervix.
  • Termination of pregnancy is not indicated here, as strengthening the cervix can benefit the patient.

Option C: Complete bed rest

  • Complete bed rest is advised; however, cervical cerclage is more definitive, which should be followed by rest.

Option D: Ecosprin + LMWH

  • Ecosprin with LMWH is indicated in recurrent abortions due to antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is accompanied to the obstetrics and gynecology OPD by her mother. The girl has not yet started menstruation. On examination, she has developed secondary sexual characteristics appropriately. The gynecologist provides counseling and reassurance to them and educates them about the stages of puberty. What is the correct sequence of events in puberty?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thelarche-pubarche-growth spurt-menarche

  • In girls, the sequence of changes in puberty is as follows:
    • Thelarche-pubarche-growth spurt-menarche
  1. Thelarche is the appearance of breast tissue due to the action of estradiol. Estradiol is produced mainly from the ovaries.
  2. Pubarche is the appearance of pubic hair, which is due to the adrenal gland's androgens effects.
  3. The growth spurt is the height increase that affects axial (trunk) and appendicular (limb) components. In later puberty, however, the growth spurt is primarily truncal. Acne first appears.
  4. Menarche is the first menstrual bleed. It occurs 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche. The first menstrual bleed is not associated with ovulation. It is caused by the effect of estradiol on the uterine lining.

Option A: Thelarche-pubarche-menarche-growth spurt

  • Menarche occurs at the end of the growth spurt.
  • It occurs 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche.

Option B: Pubarche-thelarche-growth spurt-menarche

  • The first step of puberty in females is the appearance of breast tissue.
  • It is termed thelarche.

Option C: Menarche-growth spurt-thelarche-pubarche

  • Menarche never occurs as the first step in puberty.
  • It is rather the last event in female puberty.

questions.text: A healthy 25-year-old gravida 2 para 1 at 38 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labour. Shortly after hospital admission, epidural analgesia is initiated at the patient's request. Three hours later, she was fully dilated and gave birth via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery to a healthy baby boy. The umbilical cord is clamped after 30 seconds of birth. What is the advantage of delayed cord clamping?

choices.text: Elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood

questions.solution:
Option C: Lesser chances of shock

  • The umbilical cord is clamped after 30 seconds of the delivery; this is termed as delayed cord clamping
  • In delayed cord clamping, transitional circulation is improved.
  • It helps in the formation of more red blood cell volumes.
  • It decreases the need for blood transfusion.
  • It lowers the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • It decreases the risk of interventricular haemorrhage.
  • It decreases the risk of shock.
  • As more blood is supplied to the muscles and tissues
  • Good tissue perfusion.
  • Better supply to the tissues will decrease the risk of ischemia
  • Advantages of delayed cord clamping:
    • Lesser chances of anaemia
    • Higher blood pressure
    • Lesser chances of shock
    • Lesser intraventricular haemorrhage
  • Immediate resuscitation of the newborn can save the baby from lifetime disability or death.

Option A: Early hemolysis of RBC

  • Hemolysis of RBCs will lead to hemodilution.
  • Hemodilution will lead to anaemia.

Option B: Release of bilirubin

  • Bilirubin is a product of RBC breakdown.
  • Bilirubin is released when RBCs undergo hemolysis.
  • It may also be elevated in case of liver disorders or defective hepatic metabolism.

Option D: Elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood 

  • In delayed cord clamping, the clamped RBCs are broken down in the circulation.
  • RBC breakdown causes the release of excessive bilirubin.
  • Levels of bilirubin are thus elevated in the bloodstream.

questions.text: An 8-day-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department by his mother with complaints of fever and poor feeding for the past 8 hours. Her mother has a history of premature membrane ruptures leading to an emergency cesarean section. The child has no other abnormalities. On examination, the neonate has a temperature of 104°F, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and chest pain. Which of the following will be the best step of management to prevent further deterioration of the patient's current pathology?

choices.text: Start IV antibiotics immediately after taking a sample for blood culture
Start oral antibiotics and monitor for worsening of the clinical condition
Monitor the baby and start IV fluids only

questions.solution:
Option A: Start IV antibiotics immediately after taking a sample for blood culture

  • This is a case of neonatal sepsis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and poor feeding for 8 days.
  • The neonate has a perinatal risk factor of premature rupture of membranes, and the examination findings suggest early-onset sepsis symptoms, so IV antibiotics should be started immediately after taking a sample for blood culture.
  • Early empiric therapy for neonates with sepsis should cover group B Streptococcus and gram-negative enteric organisms, especially Escherichia coli. After retrieving the blood culture report, the treatment is modified accordingly.
  • The course of therapy is 10 days.
  • A repeat blood culture monitors the response to antibiotics at 24 to 48 hours and by improvement in the clinical condition.

Option B: Start oral antibiotics and monitor for worsening of the clinical condition

  • Baby has a history of poor feeding, so starting oral antibiotics is not a good step.
  • Baby has tachypnea, and oral antibiotics can lead to aspiration.
  • IV route has good bioavailability as compared to the oral route.

Option C: Reassure and do nothing

  • Neonatal sepsis requires management.
  • Reassurance and not doing anything will only worsen the condition.

Option D: Monitor the baby and start IV fluids only

  • IV fluids will only help in maintaining the hydration of the baby.
  • If there is ongoing sepsis, antibiotics are an absolute indication, preferably through the intravenous route.

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia delivers a baby at 32 weeks of gestation. She was given magnesium sulfate. As the delivery is prolonged and the umbilical cord becomes wrapped around the baby's neck, it leads to perinatal asphyxia; his APGAR score is calculated and shifted to the NICU. What are the essential criteria for defining the condition mentioned above?

choices.text: Persistence of APGAR score of 5-7 for >5 minutes
Presence of neurological manifestations in the long neonatal period
Evidence of single organ dysfunction in the long neonatal period

questions.solution:
Option B: Prolonged umbilical arterial blood pH <7.0

  • In the above-diagnosed case of perinatal eclampsia asphyxia main criteria is prolonged umbilical arterial blood ph<7.0
  • Essential criteria for defining perinatal asphyxia include:
  • APGAR score of 0-3 persisting for >5 minutes
  • Prolonged acidemia (pH <7.0) on an umbilical arterial blood sample
  • Neurological manifestations, e.g. seizures, coma, hypotonia or HIE in the immediate neonatal period
  • Evidence of multi-organ dysfunction in the immediate neonatal period

Option A: Persistence of APGAR score of 5-7 for >5 minutes

  • The Apgar score is used to evaluate neonates quickly. Low five-minute Apgar scores have been linked to an increased chance of catastrophic neurologic sequelae, but there are long-term data on milder consequences.
  • We investigated the relationship between the five-minute Apgar score and early adulthood prevalence of neurologic impairment and cognitive performance.

Option C: Presence of neurological manifestations in the long neonatal period

  • After a long time, the neurological manifestations in the neonatal period are immediate.
  • It's all due to neonatal bacteremia, which causes these manifestations.

Option D: Evidence of single organ dysfunction in the long neonatal period

  • It involves multi-organ dysfunctioning.
  • And it is also an immediate neonatal involving period.

questions.text: Expressed breast milk should be stored under which of the following conditions?

choices.text: EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 24 hours in a refrigerator
EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 24 hours and 6 days in the refrigerator
EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 18 hours and 1 month in the refrigerator
EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 6 days in a refrigerator

questions.solution:
Option A: EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 24 hours in a refrigerator

  • It is important to use or properly save breast milk within four hours, especially if the room is warm.
  • Before expressing milk, hands should be properly washed.
  • Express milk in a clean, capped food container or hard plastic container.
  • The container should BPA free.
  • Plastic bags especially designed for milk storage should be used.
  • Expressed breast milk can be stored in a deep freezer for 12 months
  • Firstly, thaw the oldest milk.
  • Mother should place the milk in the refrigerator one night before use.
  • Milk can also be thawed by placing it under running water.
  • Do not microwave milk or warm it directly on the stove.
  • If the baby does not finish the bottle, the remaining milk must be used within 2 hours

Option B: EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 24 hours and 6 days in a refrigerator

  • EBM cannot be stored at room temperature for 24 hours.
  • It can be stored at room temperature for only 4-6hours.

Option C: EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 18 hours and 1 month in the refrigerator

  • EBM cannot be stored at room temperature for 18 hours.
  • It can be kept for only 6 hours.
  • It can be stored in the refrigerator for 2-3, not for 1 month.

Option D: EBM can be stored at room temperature for about 6 hours and 6 days in a refrigerator

  • EBM can be stored in the refrigerator for 2-3, not for 6 days.
  • EBM can be stored in insulated coolers containing icepacks for 1day

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with growth retardation associated with intellectual disability. Further history revealed that the patient had delayed milestone development. Further examination revealed kinky hair. Lab investigations revealed low serum copper levels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Menke's disease

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of Menke's disease.

  • Menke's disease, also known as kinky hair disease, is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by gene mutation coding for the copper transport protein ATP7A.

  • The copper level is low in the liver and brain and is high in enterocytes and fibroblasts.

  • Clinical features include:

    • Sparse hypopigmented kinky hair

    • Trichorrhexis nodosa (fractures along the hair shaft) and pili torti (twisted hair) on microscopic examination of the hair

    • Growth retardation

    • CNS involvement includes intellectual disability, delayed milestones, seizures, and hypotonia.

    • Hypothermia

Option B: Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, is the most common chromosomal abnormality.

  • Down’s syndrome is associated with intellectual disability, congenital heart disease, most common heart disease, endocardial cushion defects, acute leukaemia, Alzheimer’s disease, congenital hypothyroidism and atlantoaxial instability.

  • Clinical features include:

    • Round face

    • Protruding tongue

    • Occiput flat

    • Wide fontanelle

    • Flat nasal bridge

    • Low-set and dysplastic ears

    • Oblique palpebral fissure and epicanthic fold

    • Brushfield spots in the iris

    • Brachycephaly

    • Hypotonia

    • Simian palmar crease

Option C: Lesch Nyhan syndrome

  • It is an X-linked disease caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which is important in the purine salvage pathway.

  • Clinical features include:

  •  

     

     

    • Developmental delay

    • Neurologic signs such as dystonia, spasticity, and dysarthria

    • Self-mutilating behaviour

    • Elevated serum uric acid levels >5 mg/dl

Option D: Wilson disease

  • Wilson disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation of the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13.

  • The clinical features include:

  •  

    • Hepatic: Hepatomegaly, hepatitis, liver failure, portal hypertension, and ascites

    • Hematologic: Hemolytic anaemia

    • CNS: Tremors, dysarthria, dystonia, and chorea

    • Eye: Kayser Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract

    • Renal: Fanconi syndrome and renal failure

questions.text: A 30-month-old deaf boy whose development is slower than normal is being followed for congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in your clinic. The child's mother is pregnant again and is worried about her new baby. Which of the following is advisory information to be given to the patient?

choices.text: The mother has antibodies to CMV that is passed to the fetus
The mother’s infection cannot become reactivated
The new infant should be isolated from the older child

questions.solution:
Option A: The mother has antibodies to CMV that are passed to the fetus

  • In case of reactivation of CMV infection during pregnancy, maternal IgG antibodies pass transplacentally and protect the baby against infection.

Option B: The mother's infection cannot become reactivated

  • The mother's infection can be reactivated during secondary pregnancy.

  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Termination of pregnancy is advised

  • Termination of pregnancy is not advised because most infants infected during this secondary maternal infection are asymptomatic, but about 10% of them eventually manifest hearing and neurologic problems.

  • The symptomatic congenital disease usually occurs when the mother has a primary CMV infection in the first trimester of pregnancy. Many of these babies die, and those who survive are severely affected.

Option D: The new infant should be isolated from the older child

  • Some recommend keeping a child with congenital CMV infection away from susceptible pregnant women because CMV excretion can persist for months to years.

  • If infected shortly after birth, the younger sibling will probably be asymptomatic since he or she has maternal IgG antibodies in circulation

questions.text: A female infant is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child exam. The mother starts to wean her child from breastfeeding and started on semi solid foods. When the mother gave one biscuit in her baby's hand, to her surprise, the child could take the biscuit to her mouth all by herself. At what age can the child do that?
questions.solution:
Option C: 6 months

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which an infant is brought to the physician's office by her mother. The mother starts to wean off her child from breastfeeding. She gradually starts giving her semi-solid food like cereals, porridge, and biscuits.
  • The child was able to take the biscuit to her mouth all by herself while her mother was feeding him a biscuit.
  • By 5- 6 months, a child can begin to take the biscuit to his mouth.
  • By 12 months, he can try to feed herself with a cup but spills some of the contents.
  • By 15 months, he can drink from a cup without spilling
  • By 18 months, he can feed himself well with a spoon

Option A: 2 months

  • At the age of 2, the baby holds his head up when on his tummy.
  • Have a social smile.
  • Can move both arms and legs.
  • Opens hands briefly.

Option B: 4 months

  • At the age of 4, he holds his head steady without support when you are holding him.
  • Can hold a toy when you put it in his hand.
  • Brings his hands to mouth.

Option D: 9 months

  • At the age of 9, a child can sit without support.
  • Drops an object and looks at a fallen object.
  • Uncovers toy after seeing it hidden.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of scanty, foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge from the ear associated with conductive hearing loss. Further examination revealed the migration of the external auditory canal epithelium into the middle ear. Which of the following is the treatment for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Modified radical mastoidectomy

  • The above-given case is acquired cholesteatoma.
  • It is a bag-like cystic structure lined by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium containing desquamated epithelium having erosive property and mostly seen in the temporal bone.
  • Squamous epithelium from the external auditory canal migrates/invades into the middle ear along the marginal perforation and causes squamous metaplasia.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatoma. In these cases, there is already a pre-existing perforation in pars tensa.
  • This is often associated with posterosuperior marginal perforation or sometimes large central perforation.
  • The treatment of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy.
  • The attico-antral disease is usually associated with cholesteatoma.
  • Cholesteatoma is the most common condition in chronic suppurative otitis media of unsafe variety.
  • Cholesteatoma causes destruction of bone or whatever structure comes in its way, eroding aditus and or antrum.
  • The facial nerve may be similarly injured.
  • It may erode the lateral sinus plate resulting in lateral sinus thrombosis.
  • It causes otorrhoea-usually scanty and foul smelling, hearing loss, marginal perforation, or retraction pocket with cholesteatoma debris.
  • Pus culture may be positive for Pseudomonas pyocyaneus.
  • X-ray mastoid may show sclerosis in mastoid bone with erosion.
  • Depending upon the extent of the disease, simple/modified or radical mastoidectomy may be done to treat cholesteatoma.

Option B: IV antibiotics

  • Surgery is always indicated in cholesteatoma due to the risk of complications.
  • The reconstruction of the middle ear and sound-conducting apparatus is indicated.
  • IV antibiotics are not useful for the treatment of acquired cholesteatoma.
  • Cholesteatoma produces the cyst by modification of the eardrum, and the cyst should be removed surgically.
  • Mostly IV antibiotics are used during the surgical procedure of mastoidectomy.

Option C: Oral antibiotics

  • Oral or IV antibiotics are not useful for the treatment of acquired cholesteatoma.
  • Oral antibiotics are recommended after the surgery procedure to avoid infection.

Option D: No treatment

  • Surgery is always indicated in cholesteatoma due to the risk of complications.
  • Mostly IV antibiotics are used during the surgical procedure of mastoidectomy.
  • Oral antibiotics are recommended after the surgery procedure to avoid infection.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the hospital outpatient department with the complaint of fever, cough associated with discharge in the ear, and decreased hearing. On examination, the below image depicted which found to be the complication of the above-described symptoms. Which of the following describes best about the image?
questions.solution:
Option B: Formed over the occipital bone

  • This child presented with the sign and symptoms of fever, cough associated with ear discharge and decreased hearing is suspected for the diagnosis of Citelli’s abscess.
  • It is an extratemporal complication of otitis media.
  • The case discussed above is otitis media. An abscess is formed due to the extrusion of cholesteatoma from the medial surface of the mastoid process at the attachment of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • It generally appears behind the mastoid more towards the occipital bone in comparison to the postauricular mastoid abscess, which forms over the mastoid.
  • Few authors consider the abscess of the digastric triangle, which is formed by tracking of pus from the mastoid tip, as Citelli’s abscess.
  • An abscess is formed behind the mastoid more towards the occipital bone (compared to a postauricular mastoid abscess which forms over the mastoid).

Treatment:

  • Incision and drainage.
  • Injectable antibiotics.
  • Operating for the underlying cause.

Abscesses in relation to mastoid infection:

  • Postauricular abscess: This is the commonest abscess that forms over the mastoid.
  • Pinna is displaced forwards, outwards, and downwards.
  • In infants and children, abscess forms over mac-ewen’s triangle; pus, in these cases, travels along the vascular channels of lamina cribrosa.
  • A zygomatic abscess occurs due to infection of zygomatic air cells situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.
  • Swelling appears in front of and above the pinna.
  • There is associated oedema of the upper eyelid. In these cases, pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.
  • Bezold abscess: It can occur following acute coalescent mastoiditis.
  • When pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

Option A: Drained through external meatus

  • This option is wrong because the image shows the abscess in relation to otitis media which is Citelli’s abscess.
  • After all, it is more towards the occipital bone.
  • Whereas in meatal abscess, pus breaks through the bony wall between the antrum and external osseous meatus.
  • Citelli’s abscess can be drained through small incision.
  • The abscess may be drained through external meatus if it burst into the meatus.

Option C: Presents as lower neck swelling

  • This option is also wrong because lower neck swelling is not usually related to otitis media.
  • Mostly it is seen in cases of thyroid disease, thyroglossal cyst, parapharyngeal, or retro-pharyngeal abscess.

Option D: Retro-orbital abscess

  • This option is also wrong because the image depicted above shows an abscess in relation to the mastoid and more above the occipital bone.
  • Whereas retro-orbital abscesses occur in infections of the soft tissue of the eye in orbit.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of tinnitus associated with sensorineural hearing loss that is followed by vertigo. You made a provisional diagnosis of Meniere's disease. But in this case, the symptoms improved during the episode of vertigo. Meniere's disease occurred in reverse order. Which of the following describes the best about this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lermoyez syndrome

  • The above given is a case of Lermoyez syndrome
  • Lermoyez syndrome is a rare variant of Meniere's where symptoms appear in reverse order.
  • Tinnitus and loss of hearing prior to an attack of vertigo, after which hearing improves.
  • Some authors believe that lermoyez also has other features of Meniere's disease like endolymphatic hydrops
  • Another theory says that Lermoyez is due to hydrops caused due to obstruction of the ductus reuniens
  • ductus reuniens is a narrow duct that connects the labyrinth to the cochlea
  • Treatment of lermoyez syndrome is the same as Meniere's disease.
  • Migraine and vascular treatment can also be done but are controversial.

Option B: Lemierre's syndrome

  • It is a condition characterized by thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and bacteremia caused primarily by anaerobic organisms following a recent oropharyngeal infection.

Option C: Leriche syndrome

  • It is also commonly referred to as an aortoiliac occlusive disease and is caused by severe atherosclerosis affecting the distal abdominal aorta, iliac arteries, and femoropopliteal vessels.
  • Leriche syndrome presents with a triad of claudication, impotence, and absence of femoral pulses.

Option D: Le Riche syndrome

  • The disease of peripheral arty at aortic bifurcation leads to the classic triad of bilateral buttock, hip, or thigh claudication.
  • It also causes absent/diminished femoral pulses and erectile dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with an acute onset of nasal discharge, a frontal headache, and a temperature of 39.5°C. X-ray investigation reveals the below-depicted image:



The marked structure is lined by which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ciliated Columnar Epithelium

  • Paranasal sinuses are lined by a mucous membrane that is continuous with that of the nasal cavity through the ostia of the sinuses. Histologically, it is a pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells that secrete mucus.
  • The normal function of the nose and paranasal sinuses depends upon the health and integrity of the ciliated, columnar mucosal epithelium, and the overall anatomical pathways for mucus clearance, aeration, and sinus drainage.
  • The osteomeatal complex (OMC) is central to these considerations, which functionally represents the final common drainage pathway for the majority of the paranasal sinuses (frontal anterior/middle ethmoid cells and maxillary sinuses).
  • The OMC comprises five structures:
    • Maxillary Ostium: The main drainage channel of the maxillary sinus into the middle meatus.
    • Infundibulum: A common channel draining the Ostia of the maxillary and ethmoid sinuses to the hiatus semilunaris.
    • Bulla Ethmoidalis: A single air cell that projects infero-medially over the hiatus semilunaris.
    • Uncinate Process: A crescent-shaped process arising from the posteromedial aspect of the nasolacrimal duct, forming the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris.
    • Hiatus Semilunaris: The final drainage passage between the bulla ethmoidalis superiorly and the free edge of the uncinate process.

Option A: Keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium

  • Besides the skin, the keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is also found in areas of the oral mucosa that are subject to frictional stress, such as the gingiva, hard palate and parts of the tongue.
  • While pseudostratified epithelium is found in the paranasal sinuses.

Option B: Nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelium

  • The stratified squamous epithelial cells that lack the keratin protein are called the nonkeratinized epithelium.
  • It is found in the buccal cavity, lips, the underside of the tongue, upper oesophagus, conjunctiva of eyes, rectum and vagina
  • Paranasal sinuses contain pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells that secrete mucus.

Option D: Transitional epithelium

  • Bladder contains transitional epithelium while paranasal sinuses are lined by a mucous membrane which contains pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells that secrete mucus.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to your clinic with complaints of headache and runny nose for the last 4 days. The patient gives a history of worsening symptoms during summer while playing outside. On examination, you found the features depicted below in the image. Which of the following will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allergic Rhinosinusitis

  • The above clinical features are seen in allergic rhinosinusitis
  • The image depicted explains Dennie morgan's folds
  • Most common allergen- House dust mite/ carpet dust
  • Most common in urban areas & developed countries.
  • Most common in snow-covered area Symptoms® Intermittent < 4 days/ week or < 4 weeks®
  • Persistent > 4 days /week or < 4 weeks
  • On examination
    • Atopic facies
    • Dennie Morgan lines
    • Nasal crease/ allergic salute
  • On Nasal examination: Mucoid secretion in the nasal cavity, the Mulberry appearance of the nasal mucosa. The nasal mucosa is hypertrophied
  • Treatment Steroids (Intranasal spray)

Option B: Vasomotor Rhinosinusitis

  • Results from changes in vascular tone and permeability: Stimulation of afferent sensory nerves is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism, and it activates the parasympathetic nerves that supply the nasal mucosal glands
  • Symptoms include clear watery rhinorrhea and occasionally sweating/epiphora.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

Option C: Atrophic Rhinosinusitis

  • Causes include aggressive turbinectomy, excessive nasal surgery, nutritional deficiencies (iron or vitamin A or D deficiency), chronic bacterial infection (e.g., Klebsiella ozaena, less common in the antibiotic era), trauma, manifestations of granulomatous diseases, chronic cocaine abuse, and radiation therapy
  • Symptoms include paradoxical nasal congestion/obstruction despite a wide nasal cavity, nasal crusting, and odor.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

Option D: Rhinitis Medicamentosa

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa (RM), also known as rebound rhinitis, is a condition characterized by nasal congestion that is triggered by the overuse of topical vasoconstrictive medications, most notably intranasal decongestants; recreational use of intranasal cocaine may also cause a similar condition.
  • Underlying reasons for intranasal decongestant use can usually be identified, such as allergic or nonallergic rhinitis, acute or chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyps, night-time use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), or upper respiratory tract infection.
  • With regular daily use, some patients may develop rhinitis medicamentosa in 3 days, whereas others may not have evidence of rebound congestion after 4 to 6 weeks of use.
  • Management of rhinitis medicamentosa is focused on withdrawal of intranasal decongestants and treatment of congestion and underlying conditions with appropriate interventions.
  • Dennie morgan's folds are not seen here.

questions.text: Eight years old male came to the hospital with complaints of frequent nose bleeding and difficulty breathing through the nose. On M.R.I. investigation, the below image is depicted. A biopsy of the mass is done, and the histopathological examination depicts that the mass is found to be arising from the olfactory epithelium. Which of the following classification is useful for the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Kadish Classification

  • The above-given case is the diagnosis of olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Aka Esthesio-neuroblastoma.
  • Also called an olfactory placode, a tumour arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of the nose. Bimodal incidence peaks at 10–20 and 50–60 years are seen. The most common symptoms are unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Other symptoms like proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision can also arise when a tumour invades orbit and the surrounding structures. Lymph node metastases in the neck can occur in 10–15%.
  • Rare.
  • Arises from the olfactory epithelium.
  • Most common  site: Roof of the nasal cavity.
  • Histology shows neurofibrillary stroma and neurosecretory granule.
  • Kadish classification is used for staging the olfactory neuroblastoma
    • Initially proposed by Morita et al. (1993) – Kadish A: tumour confined to nasal cavity.
    • Kadish B: tumour involves the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses.
    • Kadish C: tumour spread beyond nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, including involvement of the cribriform plate, base of the skull, orbit, or intracranial cavity.
    • Kadish D: tumour with metastasis to cervical lymph nodes or distant sites.
  • Treatment
    • Endoscopic excision followed by radiotherapy.

Option A: Enneking Classification

  • The Enneking surgical staging system is based on tumour grade, local spread and metastatic disease of malignant musculoskeletal tumours and also for benign bone tumours, not for olfactory epithelium nasal cavity tumours.

Option C: Dingman Classification

  • Dingman classification for Fractures of the mandible. Condylar fractures are the most common, followed by the Angle, Body and Symphysis of the mandible. Remember CABS.

Option D: Ohngren's Classification

  • Ohngren's Classification is for maxillary carcinoma.
    • Ohngren's Classification: An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between the eye's medial canthus and the mandible's angle. Growths above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: A 70-year-old Chinese male presents to the clinic due to right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy for 4 months. It is associated with 3 episodes of epistaxis. On physical examination, unilateral serous otitis media, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia, and ipsilateral palatal palsy are seen additionally. The patient is a suspected case of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma. Which of the following is the best prognostic factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.?
questions.solution:
Option B: WHO type III histology

  • The Chinese population has a higher susceptibility to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Epstein-Barr (EB) virus is closely related to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Environmental factors include polluted air, tobacco smoke, opium, nitrosamine from dry salted fish, and smoke from incense and wood.
  • Clinical features include nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, denasal speech, conductive hearing loss, and serous or suppurative otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage.
  • Tumours extending into the surroundings involve CN II, III, IV, V, VI, IX, and X.
  • The cervical nodal enlargement usually occurs between the jaw angle and the mastoid.
  • Distant metastasis is to the bone, lung, liver, and other sites.
  • Histology:

WHO type PATHOLOGY Risk factor Other factors Survival/ Recurrence
I 25% Keratinizing Squamous cell differentiated carcinoma Smoking Low-risk population Older age Non-familial factors 10% Survival
II 12% Non-keratinizing Squamous cell differentiated carcinoma EBV Preserved foods Familial factors 50% Survival
III 60% Non-keratinizing Squamous cell undifferentiated carcinoma EBV High a risk population, Children Preserved foods Familial factors 60% Survival Best prognosis

 

  • Diagnosis is by endoscopic evaluation, imaging studies, audiogram, and biopsy.
  • Treatment includes radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
  • Treatment is based on TNM staging.

 

Tumour/Node/Metastasis Staging of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
Stage Description
T Classification
Tx Primary tumours cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of a tumour
T1 Confined to the nasopharynx or extends to the oropharynx and/or nasal cavity
T2 The tumour extends to the parapharyngeal space
T3 Tumour involves sinuses and/or the skull base
T4 Intracranial, infratemporal/masticator space involvement, cranial nerve involvement, orbit, or hypopharynx
N Classification
N0 No nodal involvement
N1 Unilateral cervical lymph nodes ≤6cm, or unilateral or bilateral retropharyngeal nodes ≤6 cm above the supraclavicular fossa
N2 Bilateral cervical lymph nodes ≤6 cm above supraclavicular fossa
N3a Lymph node >6 cm
N3b Supraclavicular lymph node
M Classification
M0 No distant metastasis
M1 Distant metastasis (includes mediastinal nodes)
Stage Classification
Stage I T1N0M0
Stage II T1N1M0, T2N0M0 and T2N1M0
Stage III T3N0M0, T3N1M0, and T1 to T3N2M0
Stage Iva T4, any NM0
Stage IVb Any TN3M0
Stage IV Any T; any N, M1

Option A: High angiogenesis in the tumour

  • New growth in the vascular network is essential for the proliferation and metastatic spread of cancer cells.
  • HIF-1α and VEGF play roles in angiogenesis.
  • It has been reported that the overexpression of HIF-1α in nasopharyngeal carcinoma correlates with carcinogenesis proliferation and poor prognosis.

Option C: Lung metastases

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is known for its propensity for distant metastases.
  • Lung metastasis is one of the most important causes of death for patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option D: WHO type I histology

  • WHO type I has a 10% survival rate and poor prognosis.
  • WHO type III has a 60% survival rate with the best prognosis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the office after he and his girlfriend eloped. He was struck with a cricket bat by his girlfriend's relatives near the temporal area. Later, he had some difficulty in hearing. His examination revealed a problem in his middle ear. Normally, the advantage gained by the middle ear transformer mechanism is?
questions.solution:
Option C: 22 times

  • It is a correct statement.
  • Effective vibratory area- 55mm2
  • Footplate area- 3.2mm2
  • Areal ratio: 17:1
  • Lever ratio- 1.3:1
  • Total transformer ratio= Areal ratio X Lever ratio= 17 X 1.3= 22
  • The sound gets amplified by 22 times (Advantage gained)

Total transformer ratio= 22:1

  • The tympanic membrane and the ossicles function to overcome the mismatch of impedances between air and the cochlear fluids, and thus the middle ear serves as a transformer or impedance matching device.

Middle ear transformer mechanism

  1. Catenary lever – ear drum – 2 times gain in sound pressure
  2. Ossicular lever – ossicles – handle of malleus 1.3 times longer than long process of incus – mechanical advantage of 1.3
  3. Hydraulic lever – diff in surface TM (55 sq mm) & stapes (3.2 sq mm) – areal ratio – 14:1

  • The outer ear is air-filled, and the cochlea is filled with liquid, which causes an impedance mismatch. This impedance mismatch would cause much of the sound entering the ear to be reflected, and the auditory system would lose much of its sensitivity.
  • For purposes of simplicity, the conductive mechanism of hearing can be divided into three parts: (1) air medium, (2) impedance matching mechanism, and (3) fluid medium between the listener and the sound source, as representing the first part of the conductive mechanism of hearing.
  • The major function of the middle ear is to match relatively low-impedance airborne sounds to the higher-impedance fluid of the inner ear. The term “impedance” in this context describes a medium's resistance to movement.
  • The area ratio (pressure) transformer is the first and most effective of the three impedance matching mechanisms. It results from the difference in surface area between the tympanic membrane and the membrane covering the oval window.
  • Impedance matching is the force delivered through the mechanical advantages of the lever action of the tympanic ossicles and the areal ratio of the tympanic membrane to the oval window to overcome the acoustic impedance between the ambient air and the fluid in the inner ear.

Option A: 18 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

Option B: 19 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

Option D: 24 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a dull ache in the right eye following blunt ocular trauma. Three days earlier, he had been hit in the right eye with a cricket ball. Injury of Wiegert's ligament is suspected. Wiegert’s ligament is seen at which of the following site?

choices.text: Attachment of vitreous to posterior surface of the lens

questions.solution:
Option D: Attachment of vitreous to the posterior surface of the lens

Vitreous Cavity:

  • The vitreous is an inert, avascular, transparent, jelly-like structure which serves only optical functions.
  • It consists of a delicate framework of collagen and hyaluronic acid. It is a hydrophilic gel which becomes "fluid" when its protein basis is thickened due to the:
    • Advancing senile age
    • Degenerations, e.g. as in high myopia
    • Chemical and mechanical trauma.
  • Attachments of vitreous:
    • It is attached anteriorly to the lens (Hyaloid Capsular ligament of Wiegert) and ciliary epithelium in front of the Ora serrata. The part of the vitreous about 4 mm across the Ora serrata is known as the "base of vitreous," where the attachment is strongest.
    • It is attached posteriorly to the edge of the optic disc and macula lutea (foveal region), forming a ring-shaped structure around them.

Option A: Suspension of the ciliary body

  • The Wiegert's ligament attaches the lens to the vitreous.
  • The lens is suspended on the ciliary body by the zonule fibers.

Option B: Junction of cornea and sclera

  • The sclera-corneal junction is called the limbus.
  • Here, the deep surface of the suprachoroidal lamina is covered by the scleral endothelium, a simple squamous epithelium.
  • The limbus is the location of corneal stem cells.

Option C: Posterior chamber

  • Wiegert's ligament is attached between the lens and vitreous.
  • Posterior chamber is the region between the posterior surface of iris and the anterior surface of the lens. This is not the location of attachment of the Wiegert's ligament.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings:



Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chalazion

  • The given image shows Arlt's line on the upper palpebral conjunctiva - a feature of trachoma.
  • It does not cause chalazion.

Chalazion:

  • A chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Etiology:
    • It is probably due to chronic irritation caused by an organism of low virulence.
  • The glandular tissue is replaced by granulation tissue containing giant cells predominantly.
  • It is often multiple occurring in crops. 
  • It is more common in adults than in children. 
  • Seen in people with oily skin and ocular rosacea.
  • Symptoms
    1. There is no pain unless the chalazion is secondarily infected.
    2. There is disfigurement due to the presence of swelling in the lid.
    3. It may be single or multiple.
  • Signs
    1. A small non-tender hard swelling in the lid, slightly away from the lid margin, is seen.
    2. There are no signs of acute inflammation.
    3. On everting the lid, the conjunctiva over the swelling is red or purple. It is grey in later stages. It may be yellow when secondarily infected by pyogenic organisms.
  • Treatment:
    • It is incised and thoroughly scraped.
    • Injection of triamcinolone directly into the chalazion may cause complete resolution.

Option A: Corneal opacity

  • Trachoma can cause corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness.

Option C: Entropion

  • Entropion is the inward turning of the eyelashes, which can lead to conjunctivitis due to constant irritation.
  • It is a feature of trachoma.

Option D: Herbert's pits

  • In trachoma, regression of the follicles leads to depressed, round, thinned areas known clinically as Herbert's pits.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to ER after her brother threw a caterpillar into her right eye. On examination, she has conjunctival redness, swelling and decreased vision. She also complains of ocular pain. The visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Numerous caterpillar hairs are embedded in the periocular skin, eyelids, and the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva of the right eye. Which of the following is a likely complication seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ophthalmia nodosa

  • Conjunctival inflammatory nodule due to caterpillar hair or tarantula hair.
  • It can lead to chronic conjunctivitis and visually disabling corneal scars, cataracts, vitreous and macular edema.
  • Treatment: Removal of the offending agent and managing inflammation through topical anti-inflammatory agents such as NSAIDs and steroids with antibiotic cover to prevent secondary infections.

Option A: Intraocular melanoma

  • Malignant melanoma occurs typically at the limbus in older adults.
  • It spreads over the surface of the eyeball.
  • Recurrences and metastases occur elsewhere in the body commonly.
  • It is treated by enucleation of the globe or exenteration of the orbit in cases of extraocular extension.

Option C: Pterygium

  • Degenerative and hyperplastic condition of the conjunctiva.

Option D: Pinguecula

  • It is a triangular yellow patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus in the palpebral aperture.
  • It commonly occurs in elderly persons exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • It is seen first on the nasal side.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old female complains of blurry vision, foreign body sensation, and photophobia in her right eye. Her symptoms are sudden in onset and progressively worsening for one week. On inspection of the eye, the following findings are noted:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis

  • The given image shows a Fascicular ulcer which is seen with phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis.

PHLYCTENULAR KERATOCONJUNCTIVITIS

  • Nodular affection is an allergic response by conjunctival and corneal epithelium in response to endogenous allergens to which they have been sensitized.
  • Delayed (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous allergens
    • Staphylococcal  > Tubercular proteins
    • Others - Moraxella, worm infestations
  • Predisposing factors
    • 3-15 years of age
    • Girls > Boys
    • Malnourishment
    • Overcrowded, unhygienic conditions
    • Spring, summer seasons
  • Characterized by the stage of nodule formation leading to ulceration (at the apex of the nodule). Other findings are granulation with healing (without scarring).
  • Clinically varieties:
    • Simple: localized typical pinkish raised nodule with surrounding hyperemia on bulbar conjunctiva, usually near the limbus
    • Necrotizing: more marked necrosis and ulceration at the apex of the lesion
    • Miliary: multiple phlyctens.​​​​​​​
  • Management
    • Usually, self-limiting healing within 10 days with rare recurrences.
    • Local therapy
      • Topical Steroids
      • Topical antibiotics
      • Topical lubricants
      • Topical mydriatics (in corneal involvement).
    • Specific therapy for underlying septic focus (Staphylococcal), tubercular infection, or worm infestation.
  • General measures: correct malnutrition, including a high protein diet, Vitamin A and Vitamin D supplementation.​​​​​​​

Option A: HSV keratitis

  • The hallmark of HSV keratitis is the presence of multiple small branching epithelial dendrites on the surface of the cornea.​​​​​​​

Option B: Spring catarrh

  • Also known as vernal keratoconjunctivitis.
  • A stringy rope-like discharge is seen.
  • Cobblestone appearance due to enlarged papilla (hallmark)
  • Maxwell Lyon sign - Coagulated ropy discharge forming pseudomembranes seen on the eversion of the eyelid.
  • Horner trantas spots
  • DOC is Sodium cromoglycolate

Option C: Riboflavin deficiency

  • Riboflavin deficiency leads to cheilosis and corneal vascularization.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought by his parents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of ocular misalignment and also explains that when the child focuses on an object, his eyes are crossed. The doctor, after examination, advises the parents that this disorder has an enthusiastic sequel. If management is beginning on time, only 15-degree misalignment is noted. What will be the best management for the patient’s current pathology?

choices.text: Refraction under atropine followed by full correction

questions.solution:
Option A: Refraction under atropine followed by full correction

  • The case mentioned above is of accommodative esotropia, best treated by refraction correction.
  • A form of strabismus, often known as eye misalignment or accommodative esotropia.
  • One of the most prevalent types of esotropia (crossed eye) in children is refractive esotropia.
  • One or both eyes may cross when trying to focus, which is known as accommodating esotropia.
  • Children who are generally more farsighted (hyperopic) than usual experience this. This implies that clear vision requires more effort from the eyes, especially when viewing close-up objects.
  • Accommodation is the term for this concentrating endeavor.
  • The quantity of accommodation needed increases with the proximity of an item to the eye.
  • Excessive convergence or eye crossing might be a side consequence of the accommodative effort.
  • The algorithm for management of accommodative squint:

Refractive correction

↓

Orthoptics/occlusion for amblyopia

↓

Operative correction

↓

Prism correction

Option B: Surgical correction

  • Surgery is only necessary if wearing glasses does not completely straighten the eyes.
  • In this situation, strabismus surgery (eye muscle surgery) may be advised to reduce the degree of crossing in the spectacles.

Option C: Occlusive patches

  • If the lazy eye has a focusing issue, glasses must be worn to remedy it first.
  • The vision in the lazy eye can occasionally be corrected by just wearing the glasses as directed.
  • Occlusion therapy (patching) can enhance vision in the lazy eye, if it is still limited or if glasses are not required.

Option D: Ocular exercises

  • Exercise shouldn't be used as a replacement for medical care.
  • Patient-directed eye exercises alone should not be considered the only treatment for strabismus because the origins and presentations of the condition vary widely.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus for 9 years presented with complaints of sudden drooping of his left eyelid and double vision in the left eye. On examination, the pupil of the left eye had a sluggish reaction to direct light and measured 6 mm, compared with 3 mm in the right eye with a normal reaction to light. The cover test revealed that the patient could not adduct, supraduct, or infraduct, his left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oculomotor palsy

  • This patient is experiencing oculomotor (CN III) nerve palsy. The oculomotor nerve innervates most extraocular muscles, including the superior rectus, medial rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles.
  • CN III palsy should be considered an emergency; it is critical to obtain imaging looking for an aneurysm or tumour, including a mass causing uncal herniation.
  • CN III has both motor (central) and parasympathetic (peripheral) components.
  • Depending on the nerve fibres affected, initial symptoms and signs may differ. Motor (central) components tend to be affected primarily by vascular diseases such as diabetes and hypertension, while parasympathetic (peripheral) components are first affected by compression, often by aneurysms or uncal herniation.
  • In this case, CN III nerve palsy is a consequence of vascular disease because of diabetes mellitus.
  • It is important to mention that internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a purely horizontal motility issue, whereas a CN III palsy can involve vertical muscles and the eyelid.
  • The diagnostic work-up includes visual field measurement and CT and MRI scans of the brain.
  • The treatment includes managing the underlying condition responsible for the symptoms.

Option A: Lateral rectus palsy

  • Lateral rectus palsy results from a lesion of CN VI. However, in this case, the pupils would be equal and reactive. Further, the extraocular movements would reveal a complete lack of abduction in the left eye with a large left esotropia.

Option B: Myasthenia gravis

  • It is an autoimmune neuromuscular disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness.
  • The pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis involves autoantibodies directed against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AchR), which induce T-cell-mediated destruction of those receptors.
  • Clinical manifestations include eye muscle weakness.
  • The most common initial manifestation is a triad of ptosis, diplopia, and blurred vision.
  • Further, bulbar muscle weakness, slurred speech, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and proximal limb weakness are also seen. 
  • Muscle fatigue worsens throughout the day and with increased activity.
  • These features are not present in this patient, so we can exclude this option.

Option D: Presbyopia

  • This is an age-related decrease in the power of accommodation of the eye caused by decreased elasticity of the crystalline lens and increased weakness of the ciliary muscles.
  • Presbyopia typically leads to an inability to focus on nearby objects. These features are not present, so we can rule out this option.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman came to the Medical outpatient department complaining of blurry vision; on inquiring, she told me she had been a patient of diabetes for 10 years. Moreover, have uncontrollable Blood pressure and kidney disease. She told the doctor that she had been diagnosed with proliferative diabetic retinopathy a few months ago. Now she complains of floaters and painless loss of vision. The doctor thinks of retinal detachment. Which type of retinal detachment is most commonly seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tractional

  • The most severe type of diabetic retinal illness is called tractional retinal detachment.
  • Tractional refers to tugging on the retinal surface, but "retinal detachment" denotes pulling powerful enough to pull the light-sensing retina away from the back of the eye. 
  • Damaged retinal blood vessels give rise to abnormal blood vessels that eventually form the vitreous, the jelly inside the eye.
  • These blood arteries densify and develop into membranes of fibrous scar tissue as they expand into jelly.
  • When the scar tissue eventually contracts, the retina is pulled away.
  • There are occasions when the retina is under such a lot of strain that tears or holes develop.
  • Diabetic tractional retinal detachment is the most advanced form of diabetic retinal disease. "Tractional" means that there is pulling on the retinal surface, and "retinal detachment" means that the pulling is strong enough to separate the light-sensing retina from the back of the eye.

Pathophysiology

  • Contractile vitreoretinal, epiretinal, intraretinal (rarely), or subretinal membranes pull the neurosensory retina away from the RPE in TRD related to proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) and penetrating trauma. 
  • PVR might be viewed as an improper or uncontrolled response to the healing process. The cellular makeup of these membranes was discovered through microscopic analysis.
  • These membranes contain RPE cells, glial cells, fibrocytes, macrophages, and collagen fibrils, among other critical components. 
  • The main participants in these membranes are RPE cells.
  • When the retina breaks form, they can enter the vitreous cavity.
  • It has been demonstrated that the magnitude of the retinal fractures correlates with the number of RPE cells in the vitreous cavity.
  • There are more RPE cells intravitreally when the break is greater.
  • Additionally, severe cryotherapy, cryotherapy applied to bare RPE, and scleral indentation after cryotherapy can all cause RPE cells to disseminate into the vitreous cavity.
  • The RPE cells undergo morphological changes once they are inside the vitreous cavity, where they have fibroblast-like activity and secrete growth factors that encourage collagen synthesis.
  • Causes:
    • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
    • Penetrating trauma
    • Proliferative sickle retinopathy
    • Retinal venous occlusions

Option A: Rhegmatogenous

  • The most typical form of retinal detachment is Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. If your retina has a little tear or crack, it may occur. 
  • If the retina tears or fractures, the gel-like fluid in the center of your eye, known as the vitreous, may get behind your retina. The vitreous then pushes the retina away from the rear of the eye, causing it to split. 
  • The commonest cause of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is aging. As you age, the vitreous tissue in your eye may shrink and change in texture. Your retina may occasionally injure if the vitreous shrinks and pulls on it.
  • Nearsightedness, eye injury, and rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Option B: Exudative

  • Exudative retinal detachment occurs when fluid accumulates behind the retina, but the retina is neither torn nor broken. Your retina may be pushed away from the back of your eye and detached if enough fluid becomes trapped behind it.
  • The most common causes of exudative retinal detachment are leaking blood vessels or swelling in the back of the eye.
  • Several things can cause swelling in your eye:
    • Injury or trauma to your eye
    • Tumors in your eye
    • Diseases that cause inflammation inside the eye
    • Coats disease, a rare eye disorder

Option D: Retinoschisis

  • A disorder known as retinoschisis occurs when a portion of the retina, which lines the interior of the back of the eye and transmits visual information to the brain and optic nerve, has split into two layers.
  • There will be poor vision in the area of the retina that is afflicted by retinoschisis.
  • This can happen in various retinal layers and for various reasons.

questions.text: A 30-year-old young male came with sudden onset visual loss with no history of trauma. The fundus details cannot be appreciated on fundoscopy, and there is no significant systemic history. The other eye has evidence of sheathing of vessels in the periphery. Regarding the above-given condition, which one is the most common presenting symptom of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Recurrent vitreous hemorrhage:

  • The above-given condition is Eales disease
  • Most patients complain about blurring or decreased vision, floaters and cow webs due to vitreous hemorrhage.
  • Recurrent Vitreous Hemorrhage in the young is the most common and pathognomic identifying feature.
  • Eales disease:
    • Also known as Antiopatia retinae juveniles, Periphlebitis retinae.
    • Eales disease is an Idiopathic occlusive vasculopathy. Tubercular protein hypersensitivity is postulated as a possible etiology.
    • The most common site is the peripheral retina.
    • Causes perivasculeritis of the retina
    • Also causes peripheral periphlebitis, usually bilateral
    • Common in young males in the Indian subcontinent
    • 3 overlapping stages - Inflammatory, occlusive and retinal neovascular stages
    • It is primarily a diagnosis of exclusion
    • Visual prognosis is good in most the cases

Clinical features:

  • Peripheral periphlebitis - sheathing, superficial retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots
  • Branch Retinal Vein Occlusions
  • Peripheral capillary non-perfusion with microaneurysms, tortuosity, vascular shunts and neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage
  • Complications: vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, macular epiretinal membrane, neovascular glaucoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neovascularization:

  • Eales disease has 3 overlapping stages - Inflammatory, occlusive and retinal neovascular.
  • Neovascularization is not an early feature but rather a late feature of Eales's disease.

Option C - Macular edema:

  • Eales disease predominantly involves the retina, but macular involvement can also be seen.
  •  Macular edema is not the most common feature but can be seen in OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography)

Option D - Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • The major etiological factors for posterior subcapsular cataracts are diabetes, ionizing radiation and aging.
  • Eales disease commonly presents in the young population.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a yellowish "birthmark" on the scalp. Her mother reports that the lesion has progressively become thicker and warty. She is asymptomatic, but they are concerned regarding the cosmetic appearance. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Nevus sebaceous

  • Congenital, hairless plaque that typically occurs on the face or scalp.
  • Epidemiology: onset commonly during childhood.
  • Etiology: unclear, probably due to gene mutations.
  • Clinical features: Skin-colored, elevated lesion with surrounding alopecia.
  • Localization: usually occurs as a single lesion on the scalp.
  • Diagnosis: based on clinical appearance.
  • Treatment: prophylactic excision if sebaceous nevus persists after puberty.
  • Prognosis: Usually regress after puberty.

Option A: Sebaceous hyperplasia

  • Definition: a benign and common condition of sebaceous glands manifesting as single or multiple soft, yellow papules.
  • Pathophysiology: Decreased androgen levels lead to less sebocyte turnover and ultimately activation of sebocyte proliferation and hyperplasia.
  • Clinical features: Solitary nodule or multiple skin-colored or yellowish papules on the face (mainly forehead, cheeks, chin) and on the upper trunk

Option B: Congenital warts

  • Definition: hyperkeratosis and hyperplasia of epidermis commonly caused by human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • Etiology: Transmitted by direct skin contact and common clinical manifestation of HPV
  • Localization: elbows, knees, fingers, palms
  • Appearance: skin-colored or whitish, soft, rough-surfaced, scaly papules or plaques (sometimes with a cauliflower-like appearance)

Option D: Aplasia cutis 

  • A congenital dermatological condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin in a localized or widespread area at birth.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents with a lesion on his toe that has doubled in size in the past year. It is non-tender and does not bleed, but his wife says it’s getting bigger and darker on one side. On examination, the macule is 7mm in diameter. Which of the following is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Option A: Excisional biopsy

  • The lesion in the above-mentioned patient is suspicious of malignant melanoma. The most important next step is to perform an excisional biopsy.

The following points should be kept in mind:

  • Any pigmented cutaneous lesion that has changed in size or shape or has other features suggestive of Malignant melanoma is a candidate for biopsy.
  • An excisional biopsy with a 1-3 mm margin is suggested.
  • Accurate measurement of thickness if the lesion is melanoma and constitutes definitive treatment if the lesion is benign.
  • For large lesions or anatomic sites where excisional biopsy is not feasible (such as the face, hands, and feet), an incisional biopsy through the most nodular or darkest area of the lesion is acceptable.

Option B: Topical imiquimod cream

  • Topical imiquimod cream is used for actinic keratosis. This patient’s lesion is suspicious of melanoma. The diagnosis must be confirmed first with a biopsy.

Option C: Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy

  • Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy is used to treat warts. This patient’s lesion is suspicious of melanoma. An excisional biopsy should be performed to diagnose it first.

Option D: Reassurance and observation

  • Reassurance and observation are recommended for benign lesions. This patient’s lesion is suspicious of malignancy. Therefore, this is not the right choice.

questions.text: A 63-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic with a history of chronic leg swelling for several years. She reports that her legs get intermittently red and swollen. When this happens, she applies a combination of lanolin and Neosporin. She further explains that one week ago, she applied the same drug combination, and her legs got inflamed, and she developed blisters, oozing, and severe pruritus within a few minutes. Which of the following condition has likely caused her skin symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allergic contact dermatitis

  • This patient has obesity which puts her at risk of varicose veins.
  • Her leg swelling is most likely caused by varicose veins. Her symptoms that include inflamed legs, blister development, and severe pruritis after application of topical drugs most likely suggest allergic contact dermatitis.

Following are the essential features of allergic contact dermatitis:

  • Complication of dermatitis of lower legs.
  • Clinically this may present as an eczematous eruption with a sharp, linear cut-off matching the application of topical therapy, wound dressing, or compression hosiery.
  • Common complication of venous eczema, possibly because of the large number of antigen-presenting cells in the inflamed skin and also because of prolonged contact with topical therapies and compression hosiery.
  • Allergens include topical antibiotics, topical steroids, preservatives, fragrances, and rubber accelerators.

Option B:  Bullous Impetigo

  • Bullous impetigo begins with small vesicles that become flaccid bullae which contain a clear or yellow fluid that eventually progresses to become purulent or dark.
  • Surrounding erythema and edema are typically absent.
  • This patient's symptoms which developed after applying an allergenic medication, most likely suggest allergic contact dermatitis.

Option C: Cellulitis

  • Cellulitis presents with a poorly demarcated, warm, and erythematous area with associated edema and tenderness to palpation.
  • It is caused by bacterial infection, most commonly by gram-positive bacteria. Fever is often present.

Option D: Erysipelas

  • In erysipelas, there are areas of skin erythema that are sharply demarcated with raised edges.
  • The patient usually complains of burning, tenderness, and itchiness at the site. It is caused by gram-positive organisms.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female visits the clinic with a complaint of fever, painful swelling of the vulva, and dysuria for the last three days. On examination, multiple red vesicles are found on the genital area. There is a history of new sexual contact seven days back. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acyclovir

  • This patient, with fever, painful swelling of the vulva, dysuria, multiple red vesicles on the genital area, and a history of new sexual contact, most likely suffers from herpes genitalis.
  • The most common pathogen involved is HSV-2.
  • Painful lymphadenopathy may also be seen.
  • Punched-out lesions appear that ulcerate later.
  • Diagnosis is made clinically. However, a Tzanck smear of the lesions, PCR, or viral culture can be used for confirmation.
  • Acyclovir is the first-line treatment option.
  • Recurrences are common

Option A: Fluconazole

  • It is used in the management of vaginal candidiasis, which is typically associated with a curdy white vaginal discharge.
  • Vaginal burning and pruritus are also a feature of this condition.

Option B: Metronidazole

  • It helps manage vulvovaginitis associated with an infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Trichomoniasis is typically characterized by a foul-smelling yellow-green vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix.

Option C: Oseltamivir

  • It is an antiviral neuraminidase inhibitor, helpful in managing influenza virus infection.
